—Written by the ACTU.

—If Senator Maguire's speech was written by the Australian Council of Trade Unions-which it was not-or if it was written by anyone else, what does that matter when he pointed out the great benefits that will come to this country through the Government's program? If the benefits are there, if what Senator Maguire was saying is true and correct, if, as he said, there will be benefits to everyone, if he says, `I am here to look after the 95 per cent of the population, as distinct from Opposition speakers who look after the 5 per cent'-that does not seem to be denied-what does it matter who wrote the speech? That is the point I make. I think that the speech has about it all the hallmarks of Senator Maguire. It is clearly a speech by him. Senator Boswell would agree with that. He wants to help the poor, does he not?
—I do, but I don't want to help by putting them out of work, and that is exactly what you are doing.
—Of course Senator Boswell does. Of course he wants to help those who are less fortunate. This is the program by which we have set out to do it.
—It will help the accountants and lawyers; that is about it.

—I will not, on Senator Messner's invitation, go into a hatred session on accountants and lawyers. I think accountants and lawyers perform very good and proper functions. With great respect to Senator Messner-I know that he did not intend this-the effect of his comment is to condemn the lawyers and accountants of this country; they are members of very honourable and very productive professions. The fact that some lawyers and accountants might do the wrong thing does not mean that all accountants and all lawyers do it. In fact, they are both very traditional and very honourable professions. I defend them and rebut the suggestion that in some way they should be condemned. In any event, the reality of the whole matter is that this is a great scheme and, as Senator Siddons has said, an historic scheme, encompassing the greatest reforms that have been made in this country in the last 40 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The simple answer to the argument of Senator Cooney and the simple explanation of the Opposition's position, which has been put already by Senator Messner, is that the Opposition believes that any expense legitimately incurred in the earning of income should be allowable for the purposes of income tax. That is in essence what we are asserting, and that is what the Government is setting aside. All the sophistry and all the arguments relating to non-legitimate expenditure do not go to the issue we have raised-that expenses legitimately incurred should be allowed. We will continue to make that principle known in the community, and the Australian Labor Party in the end will have to explain why it has now moved to a situation in which legitimate costs to business will no longer be allowed to be offset as expenses.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate is debating a package of Bills, one of which is the Social Security (Poverty Traps Reduction) Bill 1985. I wish to address a few words to that Bill. It is timely that we do so. Senator Cooney drew attention in his speech to the need to support the most needy people in society. Indeed, he drew attention to the provisions of this part of the tax package, and it was timely that he did so. Poverty in Australia, as measured, is increasing. I note from the Sydney Morning Herald of 11 November-a notable date, the sixty-seventh anniversary of Armistice Day 1918-that the number of people below the poverty line in Australia is measured at 800,000 and rising. The Canberra Times of the same day, referring to the same figures on deprivation, talked about a major departmental study revealing 40,000 people homeless and more on the verge. There is no doubt, when we look at deprivation and need, that Australia has an urgent requirement to respond to that need today and now. Indeed, the Government, in its taxation package, saw fit to identify certain poverty traps and to indicate that it wished to respond to them.

What is a poverty trap? A poverty trap is a disincentive created by a combination of a taxation rate and a benefit withdrawal, so that when people who earn a certain income lose a part of their benefit and have to pay tax end up paying tax at such a punitive marginal rate that they give up trying. They may discover that they are better off not trying or that for every dollar they earn they may keep as little as 1c.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty-four cents in the dollar.

—I notice that the senator from South Australia, who has had his go, continues to chatter on. There are very many poverty traps in existence. The Government has determined that it will address three of them. In one case the Government has addressed the trap by indicating that it will take steps to overcome it. For one of the three poverty traps, the one involving the separate income test on rental assistance, it has proposed measures which will actually address the question of the high effective marginal tax rate. On that issue only can the Government be said to have addressed the poverty trap. We say to the Government: Congratulations. That is a worthwhile endeavour. We welcome the fact that the Government has looked at that poverty trap, and that part of the legislation is welcome.

SPEECH.PARA: The two other poverty traps which the Government says it has addressed, it has not addressed. It has increased the income free margin before the poverty trap applies, but the people who are receiving certain benefits will discover that the poverty trap is still there. The high effective marginal tax rate-that is what a poverty trap really is-will continue to operate at exactly the same level except at a higher level of income. So, while the Government has given some useful relief to many people, it has done nothing and proposed nothing to touch the poverty trap itself; the poverty trap being, as I said, a combination of a high marginal tax rate and a benefit withdrawal as people earn their income. The Government must acknowledge that it has done nothing to affect the poverty trap itself in the other two matters. When the Government seeks to increase the pension free area by $10 a week for single pensioners and $20 a week for married pensioner couples, and when it seeks to increase the disregarded income for pensioners with children, it is giving people some temporary relief, but when their income increases exactly the same poverty trap will operate and those people will be caught.

I ask the Government to acknowledge that it has not touched the poverty traps about which it has trumpeted so much. It is bad enough that it is trying to sell to the public something which it has not in fact done, except in one of the three cases. In the other two cases it has not done it. But, worse than that, the Government has acknowledged that the poverty traps exist. I have indicated that the level of poverty is rising; yet the Government has said that it is unwilling to take any action to relieve these poverty traps until the end of next year. The people who are caught by the combination of benefit withdrawal and high marginal tax rates will get no benefits whatsoever for another 12 months from a government which says: `These measures are necessary to help the least able to look after themselves, to help the needy, to help people who are caught in what the Government acknowledges are undesirable poverty traps'.

Why will they not be helped until next year? The Government has found its way open to do some other things this year. I had occasion to look at the Budget Speech for 1985-86. I have just picked out the Government's announcement for benefits to the racing industry. The Government has found its way clear to say:
Three measures are to be adopted to assist the horse racing industry.
By the way, I am not objecting to the measures but I want to contrast the readiness of the Government to respond to the racing industry and its slowness to relieve poverty traps. The Government said:
First, the income tax exemption currently applying to some sporting clubs, such as football and athletic clubs, is to be extended to horse and greyhound racing clubs.

That measure will apply immediately, by the way. But the pensioners caught by these poverty traps will wait a further 12 months. That is one indication of the Labor Government's priorities. The Budget Speech states further:
Secondly, a more generous livestock valuation option will be available to horse breeders for the purpose of the trading stock provisions of the income tax laws.
But the pensioners will wait another 12 months before any action is taken to ease the poverty traps in which they are caught. The Budget Speech continues:
Thirdly, to assist in improving Australia's thoroughbred bloodstock, all horses imported after tonight are to be exempt from sales tax.

The Government is able to take that action on Budget night, but when it comes to relieving the poverty traps in which needy Australians are caught, they have to be grateful that the measures will take effect in October 1986. Surely if it is worthwhile responding to these poverty traps it is worthwhile doing so now, today, when this legislation passes.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not showing much horse sense.

—I say to my colleague, Senator Kilgariff: The Government is not showing much compassion. That is the point. Again, by looking at the Budget Speech and looking at this measure we get a clear idea of the Australian Labor Party's priorities: Improving Australia's thoroughbred bloodstock is a priority which must be responded to immediately on Budget night, but the pensioners can wait until October 1986. The public should understand that that is the set of priorities of the Australian Labor party.
—Pensioners lose by the length of the straight.

—My cousin says: `Pensioners lose by the length of the straight'. I think that the pensioners of Australia can dwell upon this and reflect upon the priorities that drive the Treasurer, Mr Keating, on. Secure behind the very high income that he draws for himself, he will never be in the position in which the people caught in poverty traps find themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, many other people are caught in poverty traps and no help has been offered for them. I have had some tables prepared within the Parliamentary Library. They are based upon a number of assumptions about the way we and the Library believe the taxation system works. If these figures are correct-I have every reason to believe they are-they indicate that poverty traps are a serious problem today for very many pensioners. For example, let us look at the effective tax rates which age pensioner couples are paying. For every dollar they earn over $70 per week or have as other income, they are paying tax at effective marginal tax rates that are higher than the rate of the highest income earner in Australia. In fact, a pensioner earning $70 per week is paying effective tax of 68c in the dollar when we combine the tax he has to pay and the benefits which are withdrawn. That goes as high as 80c in the dollar when a pensioner's income is about $180 a week and later on even goes as high as 94c in the dollar. These are the effective marginal tax rates which pensioners are facing.

Let us look at the situation of supporting parents with, say, two children. This group of people are often desperately anxious to earn more income for themselves, to get out of dependency and become independent again. For every cent they earn over $64 per week they are paying tax at an effective marginal tax rate that is higher than that of the highest income earner in Australia. They are paying 62c in the dollar and it rises later on to 99c in the dollar. There are supporting parents who, at a certain level of income, if they earn an extra dollar, will keep 1c of that dollar. The Labor Government with its set of priorities has not seen fit to try to help with that poverty trap either, the same as it did not help with the other poverty traps; it simply lifted them a little.

Let us look at the situation facing a married unemployment beneficiary with two children. For every cent he earns over $80 a week he is paying tax at an effective tax rate of 100c in the dollar. What kind of incentive is there for any person on the unemployment benefit with two children paying 100c in the dollar to lift a finger to try to improve his situation when every cent he earns will be taken from him either as tax or by way of benefits to be withdrawn? Above $80 and up to a level of about $273, a person does not pay just 100c in the dollar, he has effective marginal tax rates which go as high as 129c in the dollar; that is, for every extra dollar he earns he loses $1.29.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the Labor incentive scheme.

—My cousin says: `A Labor incentive scheme'. It certainly is not an incentive for any of these people to do anything to help themselves. I urge the Government, if it is really going to look at poverty traps, to look at some of those high effective marginal tax rates. How does the Government explain the fact that it is willing to give immediate relief to race horse owners but it is going to make the pensioners wait until October 1986? How does it explain the fact that what it calls poverty trap reduction in fact does not affect two of the poverty traps out of the three to which it has responded?

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition welcomes the relief the Government has given to the one poverty trap it has touched-the one involving the separate income test for rental assistance. We welcome and support that measure. The other measures constitute simply another incomplete, partial and delayed benefit for people-a benefit which, if it is important enough to include, should have been included for immediate relief of the poor, if necessary by delaying some of the other benefits which were given so readily in the Budget. On behalf of the Opposition, I move this amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Social Security (Poverty Traps Reduction) Bill 1985:
At end of motion, add:
` but the Senate notes with concern-
(a) that the measures contained in the Bill will not take effect until November 1986; and

(b) that, in respect of two of the poverty traps, while the Bill increases the levels of income which may be earned without affecting social security benefits, it does not affect the existence of those poverty traps as such'.
That motion does no more than state the facts. I hope the Senate will see its way clear to respond to them.

Finally, I noted earlier the defensive self- aggrandising speech made by Senator Siddons on behalf of the Australian Democrats. Senator Siddons wanted to tell the Australian people how much the Democrats had done. We do not need Senator Siddons to tell us this. It may be better to find out how the cartoonists of Australia regarded the achievements of the Australian Democrats in altering the tax package. First, a cartoon in the Sydney Morning Herald of 29 November shows a dinner-jacketed Paul Keating at the door of his house tossing a one cent coin into the begging cup of Don Chipp while Don Chipp says: `All it takes is grit and determination'. If we do not like that cartoon we can look at the Canberra Times of 29 November, which is an even more accurate commentary on just what the Democrats did and did not achieve. It shows a sphinx-like Paul Keating-that might be the best description-standing behind Don Chipp, the Don Chipp as we know him, I must say-

TALK.START.PARA: —Battered.

—Yes, a battered Don Chipp. There is a tax package all done up in front of them and Don Chipp is saying: `We regard it as a damned important victory. We get to choose the ribbon'. That just about sums up what the Australian Democrats have done. They in fact have sold out on the Australian people. Let no one be in any doubt. They have achieved nothing. They have sold out and the Australian people will be the losers. I commend the amendment and arguments put by my colleague, Senator Messner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have heard some very interesting debate so far on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4). We are yet to figure out what Senator Maguire was saying. I think it is rather disturbing when we have a Government senator who can say that there may be some effects on the restaurant and hospitality industry. I suggest that the best thing Senator Maguire could do would be to go out and check whether there will be any effects on the restaurant and hospitality industry. I can assure him that if he jolly well went out he would find out--
—He is too busy to have a long lunch.

—Not jolly likely! He certainly was not busy preparing his speech because he did not have any facts in it. I have never heard such unadulterated rubbish in this place or in my life as what Senator Maguire said. He had absolutely no regard for the facts or for the people who are or will be, in fact, suffering.
—Which State does he come from?
—South Australia. It is very interesting--
—What would he know about the wine industry?

—Precisely. Senator Maguire has done absolutely nothing to try to protect his wine industry which he said was not even suffering in South Australia. My colleague Senator Peter Baume has already covered very adequately the position the Australian Democrats have taken on this matter. For Senator Siddons to talk about the six concessions the Government has given the Democrats is ludicrous. I think the only concessions the Government has given the Democrats has been to allow them six discussions, and that is about the limit of it. We have only to look at the jolly weak amendment put up by the Democrats. They have sung a song for the last month or so saying that they will be the pirates, the pioneers, who will save Australia from the wrath of this Government. The Democrats' amendment states that they agree to this Bill with reluctance. Is that or is that not weak? That says it all; they agree to it with reluctance. If that is not grandstanding, what is?

SPEECH.PARA: I want to address the subject of the entertainment tax. The blanket disallowance of entertainment expenses, as embodied in this legislation, is a fine example of the Hawke socialist Government's attitude to the private sector and small business in particular. Without attempting to differentiate between legitimate and spurious claims for entertainment deductions and without considering the extent of profit and job losses in the hospitality industry, this Government has just decided to single out a major aspect of business life as a scapegoat for its failure to contain costs and revenue losses in other areas. From the outset, this Government has made no attempt whatsoever to prove its case, to the effect that thousands of dollars are being lost to revenue by deductions that are essentially false. Looking at the statement of 19 September, the basic justification for the disallowance of entertainment expenses is contained in one sentence:
A good deal of claimed business entertainment is done on a reciprocal basis and as much for social and personal benefit as for business purposes.

I ask members of the Senate: Where is the hard evidence to back up this assertion? What percentage is legitimate? The Government has paid absolutely no regard to what percentage is legitimate and I think it is about time it did so. This Hawke Government likes to hide behind vague generalisations and sneering references to the `so-called business lunch'-the free lunch. The Government keeps referring to the free lunch. At the same time, this Government blandly admits that its actions will result in the denial of deductions for general business purposes. But in the Government's words, there is no practical alternative. I suggest that it is about jolly time the Government looked for a practical alternative because there is a legitimate point to be raised here. But the Government says: `No, we can't look at that; it's simply all too hard'. We could all be excused for thinking that this Government could not be bothered with trying to find a way to draw a distinction between legitimate and improper use of claims for business entertainment expenses. Deep down the Hawke Government seems to have felt that a degree of business bashing was in order to appease the trade unions and all the factions within the Australian Labor Party-the Left, the Right, the left right out, the Centre Left and all the rest of them-and as a punishment for failure to support the original tax package at the embarrassing Tax Summit of last July.

Neither is the Hawke Government prepared to elaborate on the estimated savings of $310m in 1986-87 resulting from this measure. For a government which purports to understand the private sector, the Hawke socialist Government shows a profound lack of understanding of the role of entertainment in furthering business growth. Entertainment on a reciprocal basis, which was referred to so disparagingly, is a time-honoured adjunct of business life, especially when dealing with the Japanese. One could hardly say that the Japanese enjoy a reputation for inefficiency or laziness.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could take them to McDonald's.

—Yes, that is what the Government would love-take them to McDonald's. The Japanese are particularly efficient people. They know how to run businesses. We are meant to ignore them completely when they visit us. The point must be made strongly that small businessmen need to use business entertainment as a substitute for expensive marketing and public relations campaigns that only larger businesses can afford. The claim by this Government that it is trying to knock big business on the head is absolutely absurd. The Government is affecting the small businessman more than anybody else. A large company can afford all the alternatives. A small legal firm, for example, may badly need to have an annual party, an annual function or whatever, to encourage its existing clientele and to increase its clientele. The attracting of new clients is surely part of profits. Nor should we accept the arguments of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh)-a Western Australian senator who shows absolutely no regard for the Western Australian situation-and Senator Maguire that somehow the worker with the paper bag of sandwiches is subsidising a businessman in a restaurant. What a childish jolly attitude that is. There again, they have consistently shown that they simply do not understand the problem.
—He is doing his best.

—I can assure the honourable senator that he needs to do a lot better than that. The Senate should take the point made by the Perth restaurateur who noted that the same businessman might over a lunch clinch a deal to create many new jobs for those so-called sandwich eating workers.

SPEECH.PARA: Comments by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Finance display an uncaring arrogance towards their critics and a bland disregard for the wider consequences of their action. On 15 October the Minister for Finance admitted that the Government had made no study of the possible employment consequences of this decision and contented himself with the assertion that money diverted from the restaurant industry would move into other areas where it might do more for the long term health of the economy.

Is not that a very sane, sensible statement? The Minister for Finance does not seem particularly concerned that the hospitality industry of Australia is a major employer of young and unskilled labour. Let us not forget that. According to the labour force survey of the Bureau of Statistics, some 214,000 Australians were employed in restaurants, hotels and clubs in August 1985. I would have thought that a responsible government would have tried to think through the employment consequences of disallowing entertainment expenses which are having a very real effect within Western Australia and across the nation. The contrast has to be drawn between the punitive attack on the business lunch and the mild reduction of tax concessions on films which will still attract a 120 per cent tax free component of earnings. The Government hereby hopes to save $35m, although the tax White Paper earlier identified that this whole tax shelter cost nearly $100m in 1984-85. We can conclude only that if Phillip Adams had lobbied for the restaurant industry instead of the film industry probably a lot fewer Australians would be looking towards diminished livelihoods and lost jobs.

In the Government's supposed zeal to throw the baby out with the bath water by disallowing all entertainment expenses, the Hawke Government has nonetheless created a grey area between business lunches and tax deductible seminars. The Government is saying that one can have a tax deductible seminar as long as it runs for four hours and no refreshments are served. Is not that just fine? Many seminars, especially for the small businessman, are twilight seminars. They start at about 4.30 or five and run for about an hour or maybe two hours. The Government is saving: `You cannot have those. The small businessmen and operators can no longer go to seminars that are going to be educational for them in the long run'. Of course, the Government would not have considered any of those small businessmen, those professional people, who operate individually, but has just made a blanket ruling that a seminar should run for at least four hours. Neither do such people have access to in-house training like the professionals employed by large firms, but this Government does not want them to have access to training in seminar situations either. I should add that these seminars are followed not by dinners but by light refreshments, giving participants the opportunity to discuss what they have learned and other industry related matters. If any Government senators had ever bothered to go to a business seminar they would know jolly well that after these seminars what is discussed is not the price of eggs in China but business-but the Government could not care less about the small businessman.

How absurd it is for the Hawke Government to discourage small business self-education when its own commissioned statistics point to the fact that small business failure is closely related to the lack of any formal training. Last May the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce released a report on `Small Business Programs-Research and Evaluation'. These figures show that of 4,130 small businesses existing between 1973 and 1981 50 per cent had failed by 1981, and that of these 73 per cent of the owner managers had failed to attend any training course. This Government is saying: `It does not matter if you continue to go broke; do not go to any training courses'. Another survey showed that only 27 per cent of small business people had attended courses or had even read relevant books. Surveys like this are clearly a waste of time and money if the response of this blinkered Hawke Government is to further discourage self-education when it is so badly needed. If the Government is not prepared to advance detailed figures of its own, it cannot sit back and sneer at several surveys and predictions as to employment effects of its action.

On 1 August Mr Les Rogers of the National Restaurant and Catering Association warned that the elimination of tax deductions, causing a 10 per cent drop in business, could result in the closure of over 7,000 restaurants and the loss of 10,500 jobs. Shortly after the announcement of the tax package a survey by Horwath and Horwath predicted a 15 per cent loss in sales, confirming the loss of 10,000 jobs. By 19 October a survey by the Restaurant and Catering Association revealed that 5,000 restaurant workers in Australia had already been sacked a month after the announcement, with downturns of at least 30 per cent. It helps to recall at this stage that on 23 September the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) had predicted a fall in trade of 10 per cent and the closure of restaurants that had been set up as tax rorts-yet another Minister displaying a complete lack of understanding for the industry.

The American Express survey released on 24 October may have exaggerated projected job losses at 40,000, but at the same time we cannot ignore the fact that 70 per cent of the 304 restaurants surveyed expect to lose at least one-fifth of their business-and this Government simply does not care. Those restaurants employing over 19 people on average expected to cut numbers to 16, which must translate into a heavy loss of jobs, if not actual dismissals. Finally, as Senator Messner said last night, we are warned by a survey released at the end of October by BIS-Shrapnel on behalf of the Australian Tourism Industry Association that 11,000 jobs would be lost in the hospitality industry and over 7,000 jobs elsewhere, a total of some 18,000 jobs. When Senator Messner mentioned that in this place last night the Minister for Finance sneered at it and just laughed. So we can see that he is treating this whole thing as a joke.

This report strongly questions the assertion by the Government that $310m will be saved. Rather, there will be a loss to revenue of $105m in lost profit, and a rise of $34m in unemployment benefits. Reduced purchases by the hospitality industry could involve a loss of $77m in indirect tax revenue. This would cut the effect of the revenue gain by two-thirds. Even if the surveys were half right, an important section of the economy has taken a severe blow. One of the biggest lies being pushed by this Hawke Government is that the disallowance of entertainment expenses is most likely to affect the rich, the wealthy businessman, and the large firm. In practical terms, as I have already said, it is going to affect small business and professional people most-not large businesses, because large businesses have expertise that they can draw on.

I would like briefly to inform the Senate of exactly what is happening in Western Australia and to the whole infrastructure that supplies the industry in Western Australia. There are over 800 restaurants within the metropolitan area-a highly competitive industry that operates on low profit margins and in which the market-place removes inefficient operators. Proprietors of restaurants that I speak to do not need to be told by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh from Western Australia, that they are running tax shelters and indulging bludgers. The wage component of restaurants has increased from around 30 per cent to anywhere up to 47 per cent, and for this reason the erosion of profit margins through this government-induced recession is causing many restaurants to run at a loss. At the same time the average restaurant faces problems in borrowing its way out of any difficulty as most have so little collateral.

The cost squeeze is compounded by the fact that the most severe loss of business has been in the lunch trade, where penalty rates least apply. We must not think that the unusual Christmas upturn is different; it is not. All it is doing is delaying the inevitable. It is very much a short term reprieve. Many restaurants have already suffered bulk cancellations for Christmas functions and some of the others are surviving only on the remaining commitments they already have for Christmas. The point must also be made that job losses cannot be expressed only in terms of dismissals. The number of people who have had reduced hours is absolutely enormous. People in the restaurant industry do not want to be given the surprise news: `Whacko, you can go home tonight at 10 o'clock'. They do not want to go home at 10 o'clock. They are being paid an hourly rate and they have budgeted on an hourly rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —They want to work.

—They want the work. They want the input. Because they do not register on Commonwealth Employment Service figures, this Government has the audacity to say that the industry and the people whose livelihoods depend on this industry are not being affected. How much more blinkered can it get? The October CES figures are simply too early for anybody to deny that there is a problem. It is preposterous of the Government to use those figures as a yardstick with which to clobber restaurateurs over the head and beat them into silence.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me now cite some hard evidence of what is happening to a couple of businesses. Mr Gordon Traill, President of the Restaurant and Caterers Association of Western Australia, stated on 7 October that there had been a drop in business across the board of between 25 and 40 per cent. At his own restaurant, the Mediterranean, this had resulted in staff hours being cut by 166 hours each week, the equivalent of four full time jobs. This, of course, is a concrete example of how actual dismissals are being avoided or minimised. Another prominent and successful restaurateur, Mr Sandy Khoo of the Emperors Court, reports a 25 per cent loss of dinner clients with turnover down 30 per cent overall. The state of the lunch trade, at the time of the year when it is expected to improve, has declined drastically to a stage when on 19 November he had two customers and on Wednesday, 20 November, there were nine. This is a restaurant with a capacity of 200 and it is well known and very popular. This means that eight staff still had to work for nine customers. The result has been that one of four highly qualified cooks has been laid off, a drink waiter and a trainee have also gone, a bar manager has not been replaced and the hours of part time staff have been cut to a bare subsistence level.

It must not be assumed that this problem affects only the so-called high quality restaurants. There are consistent reports of reduced turnovers across the board. Nor should it be assumed that we are dealing with a problem that affects only our capital cities. In the regional centre of Bunbury in the south-west of Western Australia both suppliers and restaurateurs confirm a collapse of the lunch trade. Two leading restaurants report a drop of 40 to 50 per cent in lunch time business, causing one to reduce staff from six to four, with reduced hours for part time workers. While again it is true that the seasonal upturn is now stabilising the loss of business, the fact remains that business is still down at its traditionally best time of the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it undermines tourism.

—It has undermined tourism right across this country and will continue to do so. The tourist industry in this country is already suffering from this Government. We need more incentives, not disincentives.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, the businesses that back up the restaurant industry are being affected dramatically. A leading seafood supplier reports a 15 per cent drop in sales, with the decline most marked in the high priced items bought by restaurants, such as lobsters and prawns. The sales figures for the Central Oyster Supply have dropped and in fact are comparable with the weekly returns of October 1983 when the number of restaurant outlets was far smaller. When companies' sales are being compared with those of 1983, we are surely seeing a problem that cannot continue and cannot be allowed to continue. These reduced sales figures from an efficient supplier dominating the restaurant market tell a far more tangible story than any statistic from the CES or any Government senator possibly can. These losses to the Central Oyster Supply will also involve a loss to its carriers at some 9 per cent of the projected loss to the supplier. Inevitably, while this business will continue to survive, it will be looking to reduce its staff rather than to expand and double its staff by an extra 12 employees as was originally planned. I add that this particular company has built a new processing plant which certainly would not have been built had it been able to foresee the ludicrous action being taken by this Government.

The wine industry is yet another industry that has been affected. As I have already said, the South Australian Labor senator, Senator Maguire, showed absolutely nil respect for the South Australian wine industry. Fortunately in Western Australia we have more concern for the Western Australian wine industry. Sales to restaurants are down by one-quarter to one-third, with particular effect on the sale of premium wines.

TALK.START.PARA: —So the free lunch is a drunken binge after all.

—When such a firm does 40 per cent of its business through restaurants, it is faced with a 10 to 15 per cent drop in its overall turnover. It is interesting that the moment one talks about the wine industry, Senator Walsh pipes up and says that all one is doing is going on a drunken binge. That is the mentality that we are dealing with-the mentality of a Labor socialist Minister who says when one is talking about the all important wine industry that one is going on a drunken binge.
—He is very sensitive!

—Yes, perhaps he is sensitive to it. But the damage does not stop in the wine industry with the loss of profits; it goes right back to the Western Australian suppliers of premium wine who have been relying on restaurants as a major outlet. I ask the Senate to recall that the small wine producers were the worst hit by the imposition last year by the Hawke Government of the 10 per cent sales tax on wine. They have already been hit by that 10 per cent sales tax by this socialist Government. It is not a matter of reduced profits. We should realise that in the south-west of my State most vineyards are still within the 10 to 14 year establishment stage, before which steady profits cannot be expected-a stage that the Government is doing its best to prolong. If this Government is allowed to run rampant even further, the 10 to 14 year establishment stage will be prolonged even further-to 20 years at least. I doubt whether the ramifications of the disallowance of entertainment expenses received any consideration before this decision was taken, much less any concern.

SPEECH.PARA: Other suppliers to the hospitality industry cannot be ignored, such as the linen suppliers who do 90 per cent of their business with restaurants. One particular supplier has already retrenched two staff out of a staff of 22. A supplier of paper serviettes doing 75 per cent of business with the hospitality industry suffered severe losses in monthly sales. The point must be reiterated that when major suppliers suffer such downturns it is clear that the hospitality industry is suffering right across the board.

This legislation ought not to be dignified with the description of a tax reform; it is simply a tax change. It is an ill-conceived attack on business put forward without evidence of the dimensions of the misuse of deductibility or of the wider effects it would have. As a result we have seen difficulties created for the small business sector both in respect of businessmen who make valid commercial use of the business lunch and dinner, and in respect of the very large segments of Australia's hospitality industries and the service and primary industries that supply them. Thousands of Western Australians are being affected by this legislation. Let us make sure that no more Western Australians or other Australians will be affected. I urge the Senate to support the amendment that we are putting forward. There are legitimate lunches; there are legitimate claims. All we are asking is that this Government simply allow the same deductions for this section of the business community as for any other section of the business community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Jessop.
—This will be good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I immediately seek your protection from my left, from Senator Georges. I know that he can become rather violent on occasions, which has been evident in recent times. He has not had a haircut either.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been some very thoughtful contributions from Opposition senators to this debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) and allied tax Bills. It is of regret to me and to many people throughout Australia that the suggestions made by members of the Opposition in their very thoughtful speeches have not been regarded as significant by the Government. Moreover, and perhaps even more significantly, the Government has had no regard for the outrage expressed throughout the community of Australia about the damage that will inevitably be done and has already been done by the taxation measures that the Government has seen fit to introduce.

I am very disappointed that the personal tax deductions were not introduced immediately. That was something that needed to be done to encourage people to put more effort into their work, to spend more money, to generate more revenue for the Government in other ways. It just demonstrates how badly thought out this package has been. The Hawke Government has adopted this package, some of which the Senate is considering in these Bills. These measures are designed to raise money in order to provide Australian taxpayers with long overdue personal tax reductions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you object to that?

—No; I am saying that I am all for that. But I object to the manner in which this Government chose to do it. These reductions should have been provided, at least in part, immediately. I do not think the Treasurer (Mr Keating) did his sums correctly. People throughout Australia have to wait for the personal tax reductions until next year, with a little more the following year.

SPEECH.PARA: By the end of this Parliament, both the Treasurer and the Hawke Government will go down in history as the worst economic managers in Australia's history. Regrettably, many Australians will be forced to suffer at the hands of the Hawke Government because of the economic course that it has chosen to take. I add that the best thing that was going for this Government during its term in office was the wage freeze initiated and put in place by the Fraser Government. It was about the only thing that had any effect on the economy.

The people of Australia will remember 1985 as the year of the Hawke Government's taxation mess. It will be long remembered for a tax summit that revealed the decadence, disorder and disunity of the Hawke Ministry. It will be remembered as the year in which Mr Hawke was able to exercise his expertise in attacking entrepreneurial drive and businessmen throughout Australia who create wealth and jobs. For over a decade when he was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions he led the charge, creating inflation, unemployment and a record number of strikes. It was with that background that he came to lead Australia as Prime Minister.

During this year Mr Hawke and his Treasurer have attacked the restaurant business, the wine industry, the food and beverage industry, the fishing industry, the farmers, the hospitality industry, the convention industry, the travel industry, the tourist industry and the made in Australia car industry. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) is the result of confusion and ideological vindictiveness at the hands of the Hawke Government towards small business. Honourable senators ought to examine some of the effects of the tax measures in the Bill.

A lot has been said about this package, its alleged pleasantries and its unpleasant aspects. I start with the so-called pleasantries. The pleasantries are supposed to generate the need for the damaging unpleasantries of these measures. First, let us not forget that all the benefits are for the future. Only part of the promised tax cuts comes into effect in the next financial year. The rest are due in the following year. At the same time, the Government is fuelling inflation which will mean that the effects of the tax cuts will be cancelled out before they come into being. I mention the plummeting dollar and the escalating interest rates which today reached a record level, I think, of 19.75 per cent. These are combined with indexed taxes on items such as beer, petrol and cigarettes. It was a very clever move by the Hawke Government, was it not, in its first Budget to increase automatically the price of petrol every six months? It is an inbuilt inflationary factor, because no matter what commodity one deals with, transport costs are very significant. Fuel costs represent a major percentage of overall costs.

Beer, petrol-all these commodities-are consumed essentially by the working population, the people this Government purports to represent. Inflation means that, by the time the tax cuts arrive, most wage and salary earners will be in higher personal income tax brackets. Therefore, the revised personal income tax provisions will not give much relief at all. We will be back to our present terrible situation. In order to assuage the wage and salary earners, I have no doubt that it will be necessary for the Government to increase the rates of the tax unpleasantries in this Bill and to find other ways to milk the community. The present tax package must be seen in this light because the effects of this Bill will be cumulative. In other words, more of the same will be absolutely necessary if the Labor Party continues its present extraordinarily inept economic management.

The critical aspect of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) is that a substantially increasing tax burden will be placed on com- panies. Estimates of the figure vary from between 15 to 20 per cent. Corporate costs inevitably will be increased which, in turn, will adversely affect employment, prices and investment. The Government believes that corporate profits are such that business can afford this hike of 15 to 20 per cent in company taxes. This is not the case, even with a profit share of 15 per cent of the gross domestic product-not high by world standards. Businesses are still recovering from previously low profit levels. The mining industry, agriculture, the raw material processing industry and most of the manufacturing industry has not yet recovered from the slump of the early 1980s. The only industries that have made a small and fleeting recovery are the building industry, the motor vehicle industry and the service industries. The building industry has recovered mainly as a result of an injection of government funds. The motor industry and service industries are the very industries for which this Bill will create most dificulties.

I deal first with the motor vehicle industry. The tax on company cars is supposed to be a tax on salary packages. However, the majority of company cars are used by people such as salesmen, maintenance personnel and supervisory staff who must move from office to field or factory floor. Others affected are laboratory staff who are troubleshooters in industry and who have to go from the laboratory to their premises. The Hawke Government certainly had these industries in its sight and particularly the bosses or owners of businesses. They will not go without at all. Some in intermediate management may lose their Fairlanes or Fairmonts, but the boss will still buy his fully imported Rolls-Royce, Mercedes or Porsche. According to the figures I saw in Monday's Australian Financial Review the growth in sales of such imported luxury cars has not been affected by the tax on company cars.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not yet.

—No, it has not. That is right. But let us see where the industry is being affected. For the year to May growth in the upper luxury car market was 34.2 per cent. For the year to October it was 33.7 per cent, which is only a marginal change. However, growth in the market for average motor cars to May was 22.8 per cent. By October the growth rate had fallen to 5.9 per cent. The article I refer to is worthy of incorporation in Hansard.
—Oh, come on!

—It is only a small article. Is the honourable senator frightened of it? He is frightened to read it, frightened that the public of Australia will realise what a mob of phonies Government members are. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard this short article which sets out in detail the effects of the tax on company cars on car sales.
—Senator Jessop, the article does not look too short to me.

—It is. It is only very short. You can have a look at it if you like, Mr Acting Deputy President and, if the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who is at the table, agrees, I would appreciate having it incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators opposite are still getting upset about it. Sales in the car industry, which affect the average worker, plummeted from 22.8 per cent in May this year to 5.9 per cent in October. That shows what an incredible imposition this Government has placed on the motor vehicle industry. At this rate it will not be long before the growth of the motor industry will be negative. In other words, the Australian care industry will be shrinking, which will mean a loss of jobs, profits and taxes and various sorts of losses by the States in registration fees, by insurance companies in comprehensive insurance and by the State Government Insurance Corporation in South Australia in third party insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: At this very moment I suspect that a demonstration is being held in South Australia by the motor industry against the Hawke Government's devastating impositions which have created such a downturn in business. The industry would be demonstrating against John Bannon and the Bannon Government for their gutlessness in not standing up to the Hawke Government. It is no wonder that people in South Australia are extemely upset about the damaging effects of the taxation package this Government has introduced. It is all very well for honourable senators opposite to try to interject, but a considerable amount of anger is being demonstrated right now in South Australia against the Bannon Government. In Adelaide, just this week, a demonstration was held which was organised before the election was announced. It was a spontaneous revolution against the gutlessness of the Bannon Government. I believe that it is an endorsement of the assurances that have been given by the future Olsen Liberal Government which will be in control of the Treasury benches after Saturday.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It arises from the speech that the Treasurer gave yesterday to the Euromoney conference, which has already been referred to in this place. I ask: Does the Minister agree that the Government's reported intention to press ahead with legislation which would give the Australian Council of Trade Unions control of the Commonwealth Public Service superannuation fund makes a mockery of the Treasurer's assurances to the Euromoney conference that the Government believes not in employee control but in shared responsibility?
—Frankly, I am not sure what the arrangements are in relation to the Commonwealth superannuation fund.
—You have legislation before the Parliament.

—Yes, I understand that, but I think there have been discussions about that legislation. I do not think the honourable senator can rush to the conclusion that the legislation is necessarily going forward in its present form.

—Is the Minister for Community Services aware that the head of the child care studies course at the Prahran College of Technical and Further Education in Victoria wrote to all applicants for this course on 21 November advising them that intakes into the course may need to be drastically cut for 1986? The letter claims that this action is necessary because of the reduction in the level of subsidies which centres will receive as a result of the recent amendments to the Child Care Act. Is the Minister concerned about this situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. Senator Zakharov understates the situation when she suggests that I might be disturbed about this occurence. What in fact has happened is that Ms Bissland, who is the head of the child care studies department at Prahran College, has written to all potential young students who are applying for places in the child care studies course in her department advising that the number of people acceptable for that course in 1986 may need to be drastically reduced because of the Government's changes to child care funding.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe it is an appalling state of affairs when the head of a department, funded by Commonwealth and State governments, takes this attitude and writes this sort of letter for party political purposes to young people who are wishing to increase their opportunities of obtaining work in an area in which there are indeed increased opportunities for work.
Ms Bissland's claim that there will be a reduced need for trained staff in child care centres is absolutely false. It is of considerable concern to me that she should make such a statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sense of deja vu.

—It is a sense of deja vu, indeed, and those of us on both sides of the place have heard this sort of rubbish from people in Victoria such as Ms Bissland. I wish to point out that this is false. Centres in Victoria and elsewhere will still be required to employ qualified staff to maintain quality care, first of all to meet licensing requirements-I hope Victoria will soon have licensing requirements, like the other States-and, secondly, because they will not receive Commonwealth funding unless they do provide qualified staff.

ANSWER.PARA: Ms Bissland claims in her letter that the reduction in the level of operational assistance will mean that centres can no longer afford to employ qualified staff. Ms Bissland deliberately ignores the fact that whilst there is a reduction in the operational subsidy, there is in fact an increase in the fee relief subsidy and there will be an increase in the amount of fees received from parents, and centres will in fact receive the same amount of funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —What political party does she belong to?

—I do not know what political ties Ms Bissland has. I am not very interested in that. What I am concerned about is that young people who are seeking to improve their capacity to get a job, to improve their qualifications, are being dissuaded from doing so by individuals such as this.

ANSWER.PARA: I will be raising the matter with the Minister for Education in Victoria, Mr Cathie. In the meantime I can only say to the Prahran TAFE that if it does not wish to conduct this course I am sure Mr Cathie, and perhaps even my colleague Senator Ryan, will be willing to transfer the funds it gets to conduct this course to another institution which will. If heads of departments in TAFE colleges are going to play party political games like this, they do not deserve the funding that they receive and in future I will make every effort to make sure that they do not get it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I refer him to the statement made by the Minister for Territories relating to the local council to be established. He said that a guarantee will be included so that the existing level and range of services can be kept up for two years. I also refer to a statement made by the honourable member for Canberra on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio this morning, when she said:

QUESTION.PARA: You know, we have got a five-year guarantee. I mean in politics I think we are very fortunate in that we can say for the next five years this proposal will not cost people any more and the services will not be reduced.
Can the Minister tell us what the proposals are for the financial partnership between the Commonwealth Government and the people of Canberra once the council is established?

TALK.START.PARA: —The question comes within the Treasury portfolio and not the Finance one, but subject to the prevailing level of the Australian Capital Territory's own State-type taxation being maintained, there is a guarantee of maintenance for two years and, subject to confirmation by the Treasurer, I think it is to be negotiated from then on.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call on the next question I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of former Senator Neville Bonner. I welcome him back to the Senate.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether he has seen the article by Mr Ian Davis in yesterday's Age entitled `NZ forces face US military equipment ban'. Could the Minister comment, first, on the allegation that the United States has asked Australia to ban New Zealand soldiers, sailors and airmen from using American equipment in service with the Australian Defence Force? Secondly, could he comment on Mr Davis's claim that the Prime Minister has refused to see the New Zealand Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Palmer, during his visit to Australia this week, as a `signal of displeasure to the Lange Government'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The article in question is one that is riddled with inaccuracies. I am able to say quite squarely, so far as the first part of the question is concerned, that the Government is not aware of any such plan. It has certainly not been signalled to the Australian Government in any shape or form whatsoever. As a result we are not in a position to believe anything other than that the article is not factually based in that respect.

ANSWER.PARA: Perhaps more significant still is the claim that was made by the journalist that the Prime Minister had refused to see the New Zealand Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Palmer, who is now in Australia, and the interpretation attached to that, that this was to be construed as a `signal of displeasure to the Lange Government'.

I am able to say that those suggestions are utterly and absolutely without foundation. As the Prime Minister himself said in Adelaide yesterday, no request to see him was made by Mr Palmer and, accordingly, there has been no question of any decision being made not to see him. I am further able to say, having just had lunch with Mr Palmer, that from his point of view there is equally no substance whatsoever in that suggestion. There is enough mischief being created on this matter without it being contributed to by journalists engaging in wild flights of speculative fancy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs aware that out of the funds appropriated for the national Aboriginal trachoma program in the last three years-$1m each year-only half has in fact been spent? Further, is the Minister aware that 60 per cent of that half a million dollars has gone on administrative costs and not on treatment for the 4,500 Aboriginal people who are going blind from trachoma? Given the fact that the funds have been appropriated, that trachoma reports have argued for community based programs and that communities in high trachoma areas have already sought funds, I ask the Minister to explain why nothing will be done in this matter until March next year.

—I have some information on the administration of the trachoma program and its expenditure. The report on trachoma and eye health has been received and Mr Holding is having the report distributed widely to enable interested organisations the opportunity to comment on the report and to assist him in implementing the most effective on-going program to improve this area of Aboriginal health. During 1984-85, $524,611 was expended by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and a further $41,553 was expended by the Commonwealth Department of Health on the trachoma program. To date an amount of $200,600 has been allocated to State trachoma committees during 1985-86. These committees will continue to operate until Mr Holding is in a position to implement the most effective on-going program to combat trachoma.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked the Minister whether-the figures she gave confirm this-only half the amount of money allocated for this program currently is being spent. After all, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs had the trachoma report on 28 August this year. That means that although we have had the report for six months nothing will happen until next year. I ask: Will in fact that $1m appropriated, not only this year but last year, be spent?

—I will have to refer the request for specific information to the Minister. However, I am sure that Mr Holding is at least as anxious as Senator Macklin is to see that program effectively administered. I am sure he has been giving the matter his close attention. However, I will see whether I can get more detailed information on the program implementation for Senator Macklin.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. In view of the practice of the Queensland Housing Commission of raising the rents of tenants eligible for family income supplement, can the Minister advise the Senate whether this Federal supplement is intended to be assessed as income? If the supplement is not intended for assessment as income, can the Minister advise what steps the Federal Government intends to take to protect the living standards of low income families in Queensland who are also tenants of the Queensland Housing Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Black brings to our attention yet again an action of the Queensland Government, in particular acting through its various welfare departments, which is making life difficult for low income people and particularly unemployed people. What has happened in Queensland in this case is similar to what happens with its scheme of assistance to help those who have a disability, where the Queensland Government applies a much more stringent means test than does the Federal Government. The Queensland Government Housing Commission routinely sends all tenants who appear to be eligible for family income supplement a notice advising them to apply for this payment from the Department of Social Security.
—That is a good thing, isn't it?

—That is a good thing, as Senator Chaney says. As he was the Minister responsible for introducing the family income supplement, I think he should think it is a good thing. At the same time, the Queensland Housing Commission calculates what it considers the tenant's family income supplement entitlement should be and immediately takes that into account as income. I am not sure that Senator Chaney will agree that that is a good thing. The tenant then has some three to five weeks to produce to the Queensland Housing Commission written advice from the Department of Social Security as to his or her family income supplement entitlement, or lack of it. If this advice varies from the QHC's calculations retrospective adjustments are made. If the tenant does not produce a response the Queensland Housing Commission imposes a $20 a week fine until the tenant produces such a document. What is more, this penalty in fact can be increased each quarter. Therefore, the QHC, acting as judge and jury-without a trial in fact; if one can do that-imposes this fine.

ANSWER.PARA: I think this raises many questions about the Queensland Housing Commission's powers and rights over its tenants. No other State housing commission adopts such an attitude towards its tenants as to fine them for not applying for the family income supplement. In Victoria, New South Wales and South Australia family income supplement is not taken into account as income, nor is it taken into account as income by the Department of Social Security or the Australian Taxation Office. In the Northern Territory the Housing Commission advises tenants to apply for family income supplement. As Senator Chaney says, that is a good thing. If those people receive the family income supplement that is taken into account as income. If they do not receive that supplement, it is not taken any further. In Tasmania and Western Australia family income supplement is taken into account unless the tenant proves otherwise. People certainly are not in any of those States fined an amount above the maximum rate of family income supplement for one child, which is now $16 a week, if they do not apply. The supplement was not intended to be assessed as income. The fact that some housing commissions do assess it as income I suppose is a moot point. To what extent such housing commissions should encourage tenants who appear eligible to apply for family income supplement is a moot point. I happen to agree that the more we encourage people-they are all poor people-to apply for such supplements, the better off they will be and the better off we will all be.

TALK.START.PARA: —They often do not know.

—That is right. We suspect it has a low take-up rate. Certainly that encouragement is worth while. However, for the Queensland Housing Commission to fine people an amount more than the family income supplement maximum payment, and to continue to fine them more and more if they do not reply to the dictates of the Queensland Housing Commission I think is overstepping any reasonable boundary that any government of any political persuasion in this country would apply. I am advised that my colleague Mr Howe, the Minister for Social Security, has brought this matter to the attention of the Minister for Housing and Construction to see whether he can raise with the States the question of achieving a consistent policy towards counting family income supplement in determining rents for housing commission tenants. I believe that quite apart from this the Queensland Government should ask the Queensland Housing Commission to desist from this practice, although I suppose the Housing Commission in Queensland is carrying out this practice only at the instruction of the Queensland Government, which I am afraid is par for the course for the Government in that benighted State.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REMARKS BY PREMIER OF NEW SOUTH WALES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer the Minister to the comment by the Leader of the Government in the Senate last week which, in effect, criticised the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran, for publicly asserting the innocence of Mr Justice Lionel Murphy, who is now awaiting retrial. Those comments were a clear and deliberate attempt to influence the course of justice. I refer also to the Minister's admission this week, in response to a question from Senator Durack, that he did not know whether the Government was considering action against Mr Wran. Does the Minister yet know? Has he read Press reports that the Director of Public Prosecutions is undertaking investigations into Mr Wran's remarks? When does the Government expect to receive advice from Mr Temby on the nature of the action he will be taking or recommending, in keeping with the proper conventions, against Mr Wran?

—I have been advised by the Attorney-General that he in turn has been advised by the Director of Public Prosecutions that he is considering, as is his statutory duty to do, the remarks made by Premier Wran. I have no advice or information as to when that response will be received from the Director of Public Prosecutions. I make the point, as I did yesterday in answer to a question from Senator Puplick, that the Director of Public Prosecutions is an independent officer who exercises with robust independence all the functions that are part of his role.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware that both Catholic and Anglican clergy are committed to supporting eight Irian Jayan refugees who have made their way to the islands in the Torres Strait? Both clergy have received endorsement from their bishops, and many church members in north Queensland, and no doubt elsewhere, support their actions in offering a safe haven to these refugees. What plans does the Government have to resettle Irian Jayan refugees? How will the Government respond to this commitment when clergy in the Torres Strait are faced with the dilemma of defying either their consciences or their Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only information available to me on this matter is a brief supplied today by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on the whole question of unauthorised entry of Irianese in the Torres Strait, which is in the following terms: On 10 June 1985 five men from the province of Merauke in Irian Jaya crossed from Papua New Guinea to Boigu Island, which is of course Australian territory in the Torres Strait. Each of those five applied for refugee status. Their applications have been considered by the Determination of Refugee Status Committee, the DORS Committee, and its recommendation has been presented to my colleague the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs by his Department.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's position, as announced on 17 July, is that as a matter of policy the Government will not grant permanent resident status to any of the five. If it is determined that the five should be granted refugee status, they will be regarded as refugees temporarily in this country, pending their resettlement in a third country. Officials have been directed to review the policy framework for the handling of unauthorised arrivals in Northern Australia. I think the question also extended to eight Irian Jayan refugees, and there have in fact been another three Irianese men who arrived on Boigu Island in the Torres Strait during the weekend of 12-13 October. When an officer from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs conducted the usual screening for illegal entrants, it was established that the men in question were seeking refuge in Australia. Those three have since been interviewed as applicants for refugee status.

The Minister advises me that his attention has been drawn to recent Press reports that another 16 Irianese intend to cross from Papua New Guinea to Boigu Island. There are a small number of Irianese living in a Papua New Guinea village near Boigu. What their intentions are is for the present purely speculative. We assume and trust that they have heard what the attitude of the Australian Government is-an attitude I have now repeated on behalf of the Government here again today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Education agree with Professor Helen Hughes's recently reported comment that `Australia's neglect of intellectual values has meant that people in responsible positions often lacked professional qualifications and were thus unwilling to recognise the need for professionalism'? Would the Minister state what plans are being made to promote excellence throughout the whole schools system instead of the mediocrity and satisfaction with second best effort that pervades our education system today?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whether I agree with Dr Hughes's assessment is secondary to the fact that I certainly do not agree with the assumptions that underlie Senator Watson's question. I certainly do not agree that the second rate or the mediocre dominates our education system either at school or tertiary level. I am quite familiar with Dr Hughes's views on a number of issues relating to education. Some of them I agree with; some of them I do not. I think that Dr Hughes's general concern to see Australia become a leader in our region in educational and associated matters is an important concern, which I share. But I also think that Dr Hughes suffers the disadvantage of having spent most of her working life outside Australia and working in and dealing with an education system of an entirely different kind from the one we have here. I think that some of her criticisms of our education system reveal a lack of familiarity with what actually is happening throughout our schools and tertiary institutions. I hope that as she spends more and more time in this country and becomes more and more familiar with some of the developments that are being sponsored by our Government and by previous governments in recent years she will have a more realistic appreciation of some of the very fine things that are happening in our education system.

ANSWER.PARA: That is not to say that we cannot do better. Our Government came to office-indeed has come to office twice-with two very important values underpinning our education policies. Those are the values of equity and excellence. Through our education policies at schools level and in tertiary education we have pursued both of those values simultaneously. We have made education more accessible. For example, the greatly improved retention rate in upper secondary years demonstrates the success of the improved access to schools; and in terms of tertiary education we have also seen greatly improved access to TAFE colleges and universities by previously disadvantaged groups, such as students living in the outer western suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne, students living in regional centres, and particularly disadvantaged groups such as Aboriginal people. We have demonstrable and measurable improvements in access as a result of our policies.

At the same time we have concerned ourselves with issues of quality and relevance. In regard to schools, we have sponsored a major review of the quality of education chaired by Professor Peter Karmel, perhaps our most distinguished researcher and policy formulator in this field. Consequent upon that review, we are revising both our recurrent funding policies and our approach to special purpose programs in schools to ensure that the outcome of improved quality of education for all students is being met.

So far as tertiary education is concerned, we have now had instituted via the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission a series of discipline reviews which will ensure that the major disciplines in all our universities are thoroughly scrutinised by outstanding practitioners of those disciplines to ensure not only that high standards are maintained but also that where any problem of standards may be identified it will be overcome. It is very important that we concern ourselves with quality because as a social reform government, a government that is intent on bringing the benefits of education to all Australians and not just to those who by background or income can afford to purchase it, we want to be sure that improved access, which we are achieving, is access to the highest possible standard. We would have considered that we had failed in our program of social reform if improved access by disadvantaged groups to education was access to any inferior kind of educational opportunities. So we are pursuing these matters. Dr Hughes may not be aware of the success that we are having-but she may be, because I am not entirely sure that the paraphrase of her views presented to us by Senator Watson in his question is accurate.

I conclude by stating that we already have a very high quality education opportunity available to students throughout Australia. The fact that we have such a queue of students from overseas anxious to take advantage of university education in this country is but one demonstration of the fact that we have a high quality product here.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the queue of Australians trying to get education?

—Indeed, the fact that we have an increasing number of young Australians anxious to take advantage of higher education is further demonstration that what they want is of a satisfactory quality. We are an ambitious, reform government and we are determined we will reallocate, review and redistribute resources so that the quality of education at all levels is constantly improving under our administration.

—The Minister for Education will be aware that teachers in Aboriginal schools in the Northern Territory are today holding a 24-hour stoppage to protest the Northern Territory Government's proposed cuts in funding for Aboriginal schools. Will she comment on the claims made by the Northern Territory Minister for Education that, first, the Commonwealth restricts the participation of Aboriginal children in specific purpose programs; and, secondly, the allocation of Federal funds discriminates against Aboriginal communities? Also, what programs are being administered by the Commonwealth to assist the Northern Territory Government in Aboriginal education?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is convenient that Senator Robertson's question about what is happening in Aboriginal education in the Northern Territory follows upon Senator Watson's question concerned with the quality of education. There is no doubt that the most disadvantaged Australians in educational terms are Aboriginal Australians. It is certainly the case that the Commonwealth, under our administration, has given the highest possible priority to using the resources available to us to improve educational opportunities for Aboriginal children. However, because the constitutional responsibility for education resides with States, and the Northern Territory in this respect has undertaken State responsibilities, we cannot directly provide the basic educational opportunities in schools throughout the Territory. As Senator Robertson and perhaps other senators will know, I always recoil with great concern when I hear of teachers taking industrial action that involves withdrawing their services from the children-not that I do not support the right of teachers, like all other workers in our society, to withdraw their labour. But we all know that for teachers to withdraw their labour from the classroom creates problems for students, and it is with the students' welfare that I am always primarily concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: So I am aware of this stoppage and I am concerned about it but I must say that I have sympathy with the Northern Territory teachers' frustration over this issue. I share the frustration because we attempt to work in partnership with the Territory in education and other matters. The Commonwealth puts a great many resources into improving education in the Territory-I can instance for Senator Robertson what some of those additional resources are-but it does not have the responsibility for the basic administration of the schools. I have been engaged in correspondence with the Minister for Education in the Northern Territory for some months over matters concerning Aboriginal education, in particular the bilingual program, which is very strongly supported by Aboriginals throughout the Territory and by the teachers who have been working in that program. But because there has been some change in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs funding of various education initiatives in the Territory we have not been able to prevent the Territory from withdrawing some support from that bilingual program. I am not able to say precisely to what extent support has been withdrawn because I have had advice from the Northern Territory Minister that conflicts with the information given to me by teachers in the schools. Clearly there has been a rundown of support for the bilingual program and in those parts of the Territory where the bilingual program is absolutely essential to the early learning stages of Aboriginal children that is really crucial.
