But it is simply inaccurate and disturbingly misleading for the Northern Territory Minister to claim that the Commonwealth is not contributing more than its share to improving educational opportunities in the Territory, especially for Aboriginal children. For example, the disadvantaged schools program in the Northern Territory increased between 1981 and 1984 by 270 per cent, and the country areas program increased over the same period by 170 per cent. The disadvantaged schools program operates nominally in per capita terms but the Northern Territory, because of the greater disadvantage of Aboriginal children, attracts a higher per capita grant. The special disadvantaged schools per capita grant for the Northern Territory is $121 per eligible student whereas in Senator Chaney's State of Western Australia it is $79 and in Tasmania it is $84. The disadvantaged schools program serves 14 per cent of the most disadvantaged students nationally but in the Northern Territory it reaches 27 per cent of students. So it is quite clear that there is positive discrimination in our funding programs in favour of Aboriginal students in the Northern Territory. As well as that, we have a special Aboriginal capital program--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. The answer is reaching the proportions of a statement. Whilst it is a very valuable statement could I suggest that the Minister incorporate the balance of it in Hansard so that we can have the benefit of it at a later time?
—Order! The President has repeatedly asked Ministers to keep their answers concise. I think that Senator Ryan is extending her answer rather far, but how long her answer is is in her hands.

—The reason I am extending my answer is that the extent of the Commonwealth's positive involvement in the education of Aboriginal children in the Northern Territory is great. Senator Robertson asked me what it was and I have drawn attention to some of the major programs by which we give positive discrimination in favour of Aboriginal children in the Territory. If this bores Senator Chaney, I suppose I should take that into account; if it upsets him, perhaps I should be more sensitive to his feelings. But the fact of the matter is that in terms of Commonwealth programs there is no way that we can be assessed as having done anything other than completely fulfil our responsibilities to those children.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Sanders

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to order, Mr Deputy President. Standing order 100 clearly says:

INTERJECT.PARA: In answering any such Question, a senator shall not debate the matter to which the same refers.

This is obviously a debate. Question Time is being misused because of the debating tactics of the Minister. Question Time is for gaining information; it is the only way we have of getting information. I urge you to take my submission into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I have a supplementary question. Despite the fact that the only interest in Aboriginal education is obviously on this side of the chamber--
—Order! The honourable senator will ask his question without a preamble.

—I am making a statement. This is a fact. I am covering up all the nonsense from next door. Did the Northern Territory Government not undertake in 1978 to maintain the standard of education available at that time?
—I understand that it did and it is disappointing that it now seems unwilling to fulfil that commitment.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware that farmers applying for diesel rebates have been told that their claims will not be processed until `procedural adjustments' have been made within the Australian Customs Service? Considering that this initiative was first determined prior to August and announced in the Budget on 20 August-some 3 1/2 months ago-does this not indicate at best inefficiency of a government department and at worst an attempt by government to avoid paying its bills at the expense of the Australian farmer and fisherman?

—It does not indicate anything of the sort. If the honourable senator could persuade his Party to expedite the Senate program so that we could get the necessary legislation through the Senate, that would help for starters.
—It has nothing to do with the matter. Come on!

—Yes, it has. I am not aware of whether the farmers have been told that procedural adjustments in the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce have prevented payments to date, which is the allegation made in the question. I will have that investigated and let the honourable senator know.

—In view of the urgings by the Minister for Education, my question is addressed to her. It relates to her request to school leavers to consider tertiary education. What advice would the Minister give to a school leaver on the north-west coast of Tasmania, where unemployment is very high-indeed, the highest in Tasmania-who is a member of a one-income family of five, whose two older sisters are at the University of Tasmania in Hobart where accommodation expenses for her parents are $190 a week, whose two younger brothers are at school, whose mother has had her family allowance cut by the Government by $84.55 a week from 1 November this year, and whose parents have told her that they just cannot afford the extra $80 a week in accommodation expenses which she would face if she had to go to Hobart for tertiary education as well as a further cut of $39 a week in the family allowance? What advice would the Minister give to that child and to the parents of that child? Is it a fact that the north-west coast of Tasmania is the most highly populated area without easy access to a tertiary education institution?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing that Senator Harradine has recounted in his question suggests that any advice should be given to such a student other than that she should seek to gain access to tertiary education. It is difficult. There is a tertiary education assistance scheme or TEAS allowance which has been increased by our Government in successive Budgets and for which more increases are planned over the next few years. If the family is a low income family and there are a number of dependent children, it is quite possible that that student would qualify for TEAS if she is qualified to gain a place in the University of Tasmania in Hobart. The situation faced by that young student is one faced by many full time students throughout Australia, and they have to seek part time employment to supplement their TEAS allowance in order to undertake tertiary studies. It is difficult, but hundreds of thousands of students do it and indeed that is the traditional way in which students from anything other than affluent families have been able to get the benefit of tertiary education.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact that there are many more tertiary places available under our Government is an encouraging development for those students. The fact that we are looking at ways of making tertiary education available to students living in regional areas should also be a source of encouragement. We do not expect students to rely on their parents alone for income support. As was the case with most people in this place who had the benefit of tertiary education, it is usually necessary for students to seek part time employment. Because of the successful employment policies of our Government there is a great deal more part time work around than there was. Students have several months each year when they are not required to be at university involved in their courses, and during that time they can take advantage of part time work opportunities and they need to do so. If Senator Harradine would like to send me the details of the specific case he has raised, I will certainly investigate to see whether that student is eligible for tertiary assistance. If that student is not eligible for that assistance she is certainly not from one of the poorer families, because 40 per cent of students are eligible for some form of tertiary allowance. That is not to say that the people whom Senator Harradine mentioned are not struggling, but they are certainly not amongst the poorest families in our community because the poorest families are eligible for TEAS. My advice would be that if that young person has gained the marks to gain her a place in the University of Tasmania, she should take that place and get some part time work. Ultimately that would be the best possible decision she could make.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr Deputy President. Senator Ryan has not answered the last part of the question which was related to the north-west coast of Tasmania. Has she responded to the meeting of more than 200 such parents in the Burnie Civic Centre about this very question?

—I thought that the last part of Senator Harradine's question was to do with the rate of population growth in Burnie and I do not have information available to me that would enable me to confirm or deny that it is the most rapidly growing part of Tasmania. I am prepared to accept Senator Harradine's suggestion that it is. I have not seen any direct message coming from that meeting of parents to which he referred but it is certainly the case that the whole thrust of our higher education policy is to provide opportunities in regional areas and there may well be some plans already being developed to enable students who live further than travelling distance from the institution to undertake studies by distance education. It is always a possibility for students to enrol in external studies courses. Again, we have several institutions on the mainland which are expert-Deakin University, for example-and which offer a very high quality of external studies courses. Students can enrol in those if they really find themselves unable to live away from home. I am prepared to look at any requests coming from parents about these matters and would simply repeat that there are far more extensive opportunities for students, especially students from poorer families, to undertake tertiary studies under our Government than there were under the previous Government.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer him to the announcement on Monday of this week of a continuing blow-out in the growth of the money supply, despite the policies of the Hawke Government having already forced up real interest rates to their highest level in at least half a century. Is it a fact that this rate of increase in the money supply-more than 16 per cent on an annual basis-is far in excess of that which is healthy for the economy? When will the Government take the inevitable step, dictated by its own damaging overall economic policies, to increase interest rates still further in order to bring the money supply under better control? Will these increases take place this week or does the Government propose to delay the increases until next week, after the South Australian election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short referred to real interest rates and claimed that they were high. It is dead easy to get real interest rates down. Even John Howard could do that. The way to get real interest rates down is to push up the inflation rate and John Howard did that very successfully. He pushed the inflation rate up to 11 1/2 per cent at the time when this Government came into office, and for every 1 per-centage point one adds to the inflation rate one brings the real interest rate down 1 percentage point. That is the Liberal Party's formula for getting real interest rates down-by pushing up the inflation rate. Any fool can do that.

ANSWER.PARA: I had difficulty following the logic of the question because Senator Short seemed to claim simultaneously that the money supply growth rate was too high and that interest rates were also very high. Yet high interest rates are associated with a very low rate of money supply growth relative to economic growth. I am not sure where he stands on that question. More importantly, over the last 12 months or so it has been shown-and the Treasurer has frequently drawn attention to this fact-that these conventional measures of money supply growth, whether they be M3 or M6, are less meaningful than they were before the deregulation of the economy. It has long been a matter of considerable doubt as to whether they were very meaningful even in the pre-deregulated era. I am disappointed to find that in the years since 1975 when Senator Short left the Treasury and in the years he has spent in the Parliament, he does not seem to have weaned himself at all off the crude Friedmanite monetarist theory which holds that increases in the money supply, leaving aside the fact that these cannot be measured, are directly associated in a 1:1 ratio with changes in price levels. This completely ignores the fact that there are two variables on either side of that equation other than the price of goods and the supply of money-even if one could measure them, which one cannot do with any precision, either before or after deregulation.

Finally, on the question of interest rates, as I said, it is very easy to get real interest rates down. All one has to do is push up the inflation rate as Mr Howard did when he was Treasurer. I must point out that the highest interest rates ever recorded in any official way were recorded in April 1982 when the 90-day bank bill for first class borrowers hit 22 1/2 per cent. Interest rates are certainly higher now than the Government would like, but they have a long way to go before they equal that record.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Do I take it from Senator Walsh's answer that he would deny that even in nominal terms housing interest rates, bank prime rates and overdraft rates are at the highest level ever? Would he, by his answer, deny the view expressed by the Secretary to the Treasury in a speech last week that monetary policy and interest rate policy are critical to the success or failure of government economic policies?
—Before you answer, Senator Walsh, I point out that you are not obliged to discuss the remarks made by the Secretary to the Treasury which is not a supplementary question.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President, for that guidance. Senator Short mentioned housing interest rates. Housing interest rates are higher than a lot of people would like them to be, but they are nowhere near as high as they would be if the Liberal Party were to come into government. Mr Howard has promised to abolish the ceiling on bank loan housing interest rates. Of course it follows that that would be in complete conformity with his record as Treasurer. On 2 December 1980 he lifted the ceiling to 11 1/2 per cent from the previous 10 1/2 per cent. On 14 August 1981 he lifted it from 11 1/2 per cent to 12 1/2 per cent and on 19 March 1982 he lifted it from 12 1/2 per cent to 13 1/2 per cent. If he were to get into government, or if his policies were to be implemented by a Liberal government in any State, there would be no limit to housing interest rates at all.

—Does the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs agree that immigration can help economic development and create jobs? How has the Government countered the fear that immigrants are taking jobs from Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One often hears concerns from people in the community that we should cease the immigration program in order to protect jobs. I suppose one could argue that an unrestricted immigration policy, a complete open door policy, may affect jobs in the way that some people suggest, as Senator Elstob has pointed out. But a sensible immigration policy with a growth in immigration in the right places can help to stimulate the economy and assist jobs. The Government is supported in its program by various research projects which have looked at the economic consequences of immigration. A recent report of the Committee for the Economic Development of Australia makes it clear that an increase in migration can assist recovery and improve job prospects for some of the unemployed. It is important to say, as the report states, that this can occur. The report points out that a carefully designed program can give job prospects a relatively greater boost. The study found that expenditure by recently arrived migrants, partially financed by the funds that they bring with them, can substantially affect the pattern of consumer demand, including the demand for housing.

ANSWER.PARA: The increase in migration in 1985-86 is focused mainly on the economic categories of skilled labour, employer nominees and business migrants as well as the family reunion part of the program. In each of the economic categories there are specific requirements to ensure that the unemployed are not adversely affected by migrant entry. For example, skilled labour entry is available only in occupations in short supply in Australia and an employer nomination is accepted only if a position cannot be filled in Australia.

The Government uses every opportunity to inform the community that any fears of adverse employment opportunities resulting from the immigration program we have now are essentially misplaced. But, of course, it is obvious that, during times of economic difficulty, there is a tendency in all countries, Australia included, to blame minority groups and migrants are sometimes the easiest minority group to blame. As Senator Elstob's question implies, it is important that we, as members of the legislature, do not indulge in such scare tactics and I point out that this Government's migration program is carefully designed to avoid any adverse economic effects.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INDEPENDENT REVIEW OF ECONOMIC REGULATION OF DOMESTIC AVIATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation whether the Government is aware of a questionnaire being circulated by the Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation which is worded in such a way as to slant the answers in favour of retention of the two-airline policy and, specifically to indicate that lower air fares could be introduced only if there were slower planes, no meals and a reduction in seating space? Will the Minister allow the immediate importation of East-West Airlines of Australia jet aircraft? Furthermore, will he allow East-West to operate the Launceston to Sydney run as the previously issued licence from the Department of Aviation actually entitles it to do?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation is currently conducting a survey to discover what consumers think about domestic air services in Australia. It is the first such survey designed to establish customer preference; what passengers require from our domestic airline services. I gather that the question that I have been asked, that is, whether there are any objectives that would establish a preference for a reduced form of service in lieu of lower air fares, would be one of the questions asked of consumers to establish their general reaction to the existing services provided by the two main airline operators. I point out to Senator Sanders that 49 such questions are being asked in the survey and that is only one of the options that have been placed before consumers. The reason is that cost reduction avenues have to be explored to see whether they would involve any effective trade-off so as to establish their feasibility, depending upon the reaction of consumers. The survey, which is being conducted by an independent government organisation, has to have regard to that approach, bearing in mind the two-airline agreement, to which Senator Sanders has expressed his own opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: I have pointed out on previous occasions that the Government's hands are tied in respect of the two-airline agreement. It has no flexibility whatsoever. Whatever surveys are conducted the Government has to take its legal position into consideration. The two-airline agreement, which was entered into by the previous Government, binds this Government from 1985 until 1990. The Australian Government cannot certify that the importation of an additional F28 is justified having regard to the legal position it finds itself in. It is not a decision of this Government but a decision of previous governments which binds the views of this and succeeding governments until 1990 when the agreement will be up for renegotiation.

I repeat, as I did on a previous occasion when this question was asked of me, that East-West is fully aware of the restrictions of the two-airline agreement and the restrictions placed on services on the trunk route from Launceston to Sydney to which the honourable senator has referred. Of course, there are different views. I stress that, until 1990, there is no way in which this Government or any succeeding government can alter that existing three-way agreement between Ansett Airlines of Australia, Trans Australia Airlines and the Commonwealth Government. It is a binding contract. As such, East-West Airlines has no recourse to this Government to import any new planes or to operate any routes having regard to the existing arrangements in that two-airline agreement.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEREGULATION OF THE AUSTRALIAN LABOUR MARKET

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to public debate and random Opposition musings about the deregulation of the Australian labour market as an alternative to the Government's wages policy. Will the Minister say whether relevant experience in labour market deregulation suggests that such a policy would have economic benefits for Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Early last month, when I spoke at the Committee for the Economic Development of Australia annual meeting, I referred to the matter which Senator Cook has raised-that is, the deregulation of the labour market-and said that the Thatcher Government's experiment with a deregulated labour market has produced substantial increases in real wages for the employed, large increases in real labour costs and a forecast unemployment rate above 12 per cent by the end of the year. The actual unemployment rate is over 13 per cent which I think is a faster rate of growth than the growth rate of factions in the Liberal Party of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: For those in unionised employment in the United Kingdom, real wages have risen faster in the 1980s than at any other time in the post-war era. Between 1982 and 1984 real unit labour costs rose by 2.1 per cent. That is not real wages. Real unit labour costs rose by 2.1 per cent. Ironically, over the same period real unit labour costs in Australia have fallen to the lowest point since the late 1960s. While real labour unit costs were going up by 2 per cent in those 2 1/2 years, real wages increased by more than 5 per cent. That is the experience in one country of deregulating the labour market-big increases in real wages to those in employment.

We can contrast that with Australia's position, for example, where there was an annual fall of 3 1/2 per cent in our real unit labour costs between 1982 and 1984 under a regulated labour market and the prices and incomes accord. The experience of the two countries was that in Australia real labour unit costs fell by 3 1/2 per cent, under a regulated labour market with the prices and incomes accord, and in the United Kingdom, with a deregulated labour market, real unit labour costs increased by more than 2.1 per cent. Apart from that, the experiment in the United Kingdom has thrown more than three million people on to the dole queue and, as I said before, unemployment is already above 3 per cent.

It is disturbing, to say the least, that some people in Australia-I will not restrict it to the Liberal Party-have so little capacity to learn from what happened in Australia from 1981 onwards and what has happened overseas. The reality is that we do have firms with a good deal of monopoly power. We do have a unionised labour force. In that situation, even at a time-in the case of the United Kingdom-of economic stagnation there have been very large increases both in real wages, for those lucky enough to retain their jobs, and in real unit labour costs. That could be expected to be even more pronounced in a period of high economic growth.

Indeed, that is precisely what the Australian experience has shown. After the deregulation of the labour market by Mr Howard in 1981, real wages increased by 11 per cent in the first year and 14 per cent in the second year. That was at a time of reasonably high, although short lived, economic growth. There is every reason to expect that if that experiment were to be repeated in Australia we would relive the unhappy experiences of 1981 and 1982, when 176,000 jobs were destroyed, and we would relive the even more unhappy experience of the United Kingdom under the Thatcher Government's policy of labour market deregulation.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SUBMARINE REPLACEMENT PROGRAM: LEAK OF INFORMATION

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator MacGibbon asked me a question about alleged leakage on the subject of submarine tenders about which I undertook to seek further information from the Minister for Defence. In response to Senator MacGibbon, the Minister for Defence has replied that inquiries were made about the source of the leak, but the source could not be determined. Certainly, there is no basis in anything that the Acting Commonwealth Ombudsman said in his letter or anywhere else for Senator MacGibbon's assumption that, as he said, the leak obviously occurred from the Minister's office. While the leak was unfortunate, the Minister for Defence endorses the thrust of the reply given to Senator MacGibbon yesterday; namely, that since the discussions by the Caucus committee and the Cabinet endorsed the conclusions of the exhaustive examination processes of the Department of Defence, which processes were commended by the Ombudsman, there is no basis whatsoever for allegations of any improper influence affecting the outcome.

DEBATE.TITLE: REPATRIATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (EXTENSION OF OPERATION) BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to extend the period of operation of the amendments to the standard of proof in determining pension claims and appeals which were passed by the Parliament in May this year. The Bill will extend the period of operation for a further six months from 6 December 1985.
The need for the introduction of this legislation arises from the obstruction and intransigence of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats in relation to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill.

Mr President, the Government greatly regrets that it is being placed in the position where it is necessary to introduce this legislation. Without it, the previous standard of proof which applied to determining pension claims would again apply. This could have the effect of requiring that nearly all pension claims must be accepted.

The Government has acted promptly, effectively and responsibly to prevent such a huge and completely unacceptable misallocation of public funds. Moreover, it has in this regard received the support of major ex-service organisations and, at least until now, members of the Federal Opposition.

In this context, I draw the attention of honourable senators to a number of statements on the public record by persons who have played key roles in the community debate surrounding these legislative provisions.
The National President of the Returned Services League, Sir William Keys, said in a letter to the Prime Minister of 23 July 1985:
Ex-service organisations accept that the O'Brien case would result perhaps in an excessively high acceptance rate.
In a similar vein, Sir William observed in his August 1985 newsletter:

(T)he RSL the representatives of other veterans' groups . . . were determined to approach the matter of consultation in a positive way, recognising the Government's concern about the implications of the O'Brien case and the fact that this could lead to almost automatic acceptance of all conditions and a consequent and unacceptable escalation in the total cost of compensation payments.
The RSL National Secretary, Mr Ian Gollings, said in his address to the Annual Congress of the New South Wales Branch of the RSL in June 1985:

I believe that it was inevitable that the Government would move in the direction it has, following the O'Brien case, to change the standard of proof provisions. Since the Nancy Law case acceptance rates have moved from 35 to 40% overall to the order of 90%, while in death cases the acceptance rate is now almost 100%.
The Legacy Co-ordinating Council of South Australia, in a submission to me of 8 August 1985, noted:
Legacy recognises the difficulties stemming from the High Court decision in the O'Brien case and concedes that some amendment to the present Act was necessary.
Their Victorian counterparts stated on 16 September 1985:

Legacy recognises the inherent difficulties for the Government stemming from the High Court's decision in O'Brien and concedes that the precedent laid down went too far, making some amendment of the legislation necessary.
Similarly, the Queensland Branch of the RSL, in a letter of 21 August 1985 to the member for Leichhardt, Mr Gayler, observed:
Many veterans' organisations had realised that the provisions of Section 47 . . . had been defined in recent High Court cases to give entitlement to war pensions on an overgenerous basis.

I have on file several hundred other expressions in this vein from regional veteran organisations and individual members of the ex-service community. Many such communications have in fact been forwarded to me by members and senators, including senators opposite.

After one of the most elaborate and extensive pro- cesses of consultation ever undertaken by any Australian Government in relation to any legislative measures, a draft of clause 119 of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill, which deals with the standard of proof to be followed in determining pension claims and appeals, was agreed to by the Government and ex-service leaders. The Government is satisfied that the clause will negate the effects of the O'Brien decision, while veteran groups have agreed that it meets their requirements of imposing no onus on a claimant for pension and of not denying pensions to deserving claimants.
In confirmation of this, the RSL National Headquarters stated in a press release dated 18 October 1985:
The revised clause 119, concerning the standard of proof, was noted and considered to be generally satisfactory subject to its possible eventual testing in the courts of law.
The RSL National Secretary, Mr Gollings, wrote to me in identical terms on 21 October 1985.

Furthermore, I would particularly draw the Senate's attention to the fact that, in recognition of this substantial agreement between the Government and ex-service organisations, the Opposition leadership quite properly and responsibly endorsed the revised clause 119.
The Opposition spokesman on Veterans' Affairs, Mr Tim Fischer, MP, said in an interview on radio station 2CN Newcastle on 31 October 1985:

(The) O'Brien case, which was a High Court decision by one vote, which gave a whole lot of repatriation cover to someone who never left Sydney, caused a lot of difficulty. And this Bill seeks to responsibly wind that back. In the interests of the true veteran it does that.
He reiterated this view in the second reading debate on the Bill in the House of Representatives on 12 November 1985, when he said:
(It) appears that there has been an effective winding back of the O'Brien situation but that there is still provision fairly and justly for acceptance of war- related disability
Later in that debate he agreed that:
The position of veterans' organisations is generally to support the passage of the Bill . . .

Mr President, it is with profound regret that I observe the abandonment by the Opposition of this balanced, sensible and informed approach to its parliamentary responsibilities. Its actions in relation to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill and related legislation reveal that it now places cynical politicking ahead of both its professed commitment to fiscal responsibility and its previous reassurances to the Parliament and the taxpayer.

The Government will not countenance the misappropriation of hundreds of millions of dollars of public funds in paying compensatory pensions and benefits to those for whom in some instances there is not a scintilla of evidence in support of their claim for compensation. The Bill before the Senate is in the present circumstances the minimum measure that is necessary to honour this obligation.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY LAW REFORM FOR THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report concerning community law reform for the Australian Capital Territory deals with three specific matters-the community law reform program, contributory negligence in fatal accident cases in breach of statutory duty cases and funeral costs in fatal accident cases. I have only five minutes in which to address this paper which has been presented today. I will deal with only the first aspect of this report; that is, the aspect dealing with the community law reform program. Honourable senators will note that at pages 10 and 11 of the report the Law Reform Commission sets down a number of references which it feels should be made the subject of a reference by the Attorney-General to the Australian Law Reform Commission. Indeed, at pages 5, 6 and 7 it sets forward some 59 suggestions for references in respect of the community law reform program.

Page 10 of the report identifies four areas which it feels should be the subject of a reference from the Attorney-General under the community law reform program. Those areas are: Suicide, voluntary euthanasia and related matters; withholding of treatment to severely handicapped new-born children; consent of minors to medical procedures; and the status of children legislation. Honourable senators will also find that at page 9 the Commission suggested that a reference be given on de facto relationships. Then it discovered that the Human Rights Commission was already giving consideration to the recommendations made by the New South Wales Law Reform Commission on that subject. As far as I am aware, very few of us would have realised that the Human Rights Commission was in the middle of a detailed inquiry on the subject of de facto relationships.

The Human Rights Commission appears to be less restrained than the Law Reform Commission in jumping into areas of fundamental importance. I suppose one thing which can be said in favour of the Australian Law Reform Commission as opposed to the Human Rights Commission is that the Law Reform Commission has to wait until it receives a reference from the Attorney-General. If the Attorney-General, who has the ability to adopt an overall perspective of the workings of all the agencies under his control, declines to give the Commission a formal reference, that is the end of the story for the time being. Not so, of course, the Human Rights Commission, which is less restrained and has the ability to jump into all kinds of areas without first seeking the formal approval of the Attorney-General.

I give an example of that. On Monday or Tuesday night, I am not sure which-this is a long week in politics-I attended a meeting of 400 to 500 people in Canberra to listen to people expressing grave concern at the latest occasional paper from the Human Rights Commission entitled `Legal and Ethical Aspects of the Management of Newborns with Severe Disabilities'.

According to one expert this paper challenges existing legal concepts and their foundation in a framework of human rights. As I mentioned, that paper was from the Human Rights Commission. Further, it is claimed that the purpose of the Human Rights Commission paper is clearly that of providing an avenue for destroying the human rights framework upon which we base our ethics and our legal system in order to replace it with a more flexible system of reasoning which would allow human individuals to be treated as expendable if they failed to comply with `normal adult' standards of capability and functioning. Personal value and equal status would be judged not by who we are but by what level of function we can, at any given stage, achieve.

The arena of appointed non-elected, so-called experts is not the proper forum to which such fundamental issues should be relegated, particularly if the papers are prepared by a person such as Dr Helga Kuhse from Monash University, who has an axe to grind or who has a utilitarian philosophical attitude on euthanasia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later, Mr Acting Deputy President.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The annual report of the Department of Defence puts to rest the false propositions spread by the Government that it is actively expanding and increasing Australia's defence arrangements. I draw attention in particular to one paragraph in the report which is on page 38. It shows that this Government's activities are significantly reducing the defence effort and the defence target set by the previous Government. The report states:
In its budget for 1984-85, the Government introduced a system of cash limits to apply to the bulk of administrative expenditure of a non-salary kind.
The report continues:

For Defence, strict adherence to the cash limit has involved many economy measures, some of which have had undesirable effects because of the need to accommodate the full effects of inflation and the exchange rate depreciation occurring in the latter part of the year.

I want to dramatise to the Senate that the Defence Department is particularly subject to the problems arising from the mismanagement of the Australian economy which has resulted in such an enormous depreciation in the Australian dollar. The report continues:

Although economies were achieved in expenditure on travel, transport, freight, telephone and energy usage without seriously disrupting planned Defence activities, some constraints in military activities were necessary in order to manage within the cash limited allocations.
This is the significant part:
Unless the effects of these constraints can be overcome, longer term deterioration in military competence in certain areas could arise.

That is the Government's own Department stating what the consequences of the Government's defence strategies and what the policies applied to those defence strategies will be. We have the right to hear from the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) about what the Government plans to do to ensure that there will not be longer term deterioration in military competence in certain areas or, if it is the Government's intention that that should take place, what are the areas the Government is happy to see deteriorate. I further point out in denial of the Government's high posture-it is simply an empty posture on defence-that the report concedes that a substantial part of the real increase of some 2.8 per cent in defence outlays last year was directed towards meeting obligations for equipment and facilities entered into in previous years. It had nothing to do with the present Government; it was the result of proper and sensible policies which were put in train by the previous Government. The most important criticism of the Government appears at page 8 of the report which, in one of its quaintest expressions, states:

Australia's region of primary strategic interest-defined as comprising our surrounding ocean areas, seas and straits and the nations of the South-East Asia and the South-West Pacific-remains one of the most stable in the world.

Justification for having this extraordinary restraint on defence spending because our region is one of the most stable in the world seems to fly in the face of what has been happening in Thailand, Vietnam, Papua New Guinea, Irian Jaya, New Caledonia, Kiribati, Cambodia and so on. The report acknowledges that these are problem areas. It stresses the problems created by the Soviet presence in Vietnam which has continued to expand, the domestic political turbulence in the Philippines and so on. What is particularly fascinating in the report is this statement:
Among the many factors which have reinforced this intrinsic regional stability-
I have just established that it is not stable-
and the capacity within the region to maintain a satisfactory rate of economic development,-
we could tell that to the Philippines-
the continued cohesion of ASEAN . . .

This is really interesting, because one of the major activities of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) has been to try to destroy any cohesion of the Association of South East Asian Nations. ASEAN has consistently criticised Mr Hayden's activities. He has been disruptive and disturbing to ASEAN. If the Department of Defence feels happy about ASEAN and its growing influence in making the area a relatively peaceful one in its terms it must simply mean that, despite the activity of Australia's Foreign Affairs Minister, there is relative cohesion in ASEAN. I put it to the Senate that the annual report of the Department of Defence is basically very critical of the activities of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take note of Senator Michael Baume's remarks. He noted that in the annual report of the Department of Defence the Department feels that the primary strategic interest remains stable in our area. This brings up the whole question of what our defence is for-who are we defending ourselves against? I think it is obvious that our defence planners realise--
—Tasmanians; that is the answer.

—The honourable senator said that perhaps we are defending ourselves against Tasmanians. We certainly need defence against some Tasmanians in this chamber. Our Defence Department is recognising the fact that this is a stable area. The mere dealings of Russia with Kiribati in terms of a fishing agreement are not a threat to the area. A Russian base at Cam Ranh Bay is not a threat to the area. Of course it is not a threat to the area.
—What about the submarines that are cruising there all the time?
—The honourable senator asks: What about the submarines that are cruising around our shores?
—What about the nuclear-powered submarines?

—He brings up the issue of nuclear-powered submarines. Why are Russian nuclear-powered submarines here? They are here because the American fleet is here. This brings up the whole point of who is our enemy. Is it the Russians? Are they intent on invading Australia? Of course they are not. They cannot successfully invade Afghanistan. How can the Russians successfully take over Australia by warlike means? Certainly they would like to take over our economic system, but not to invade us. Our dangers are basically the presence of a United States battle capability, the United States bases, the United States nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered ships in our ports which make us nuclear targets and targets of the Russians.

SPEECH.PARA: ANZUS drags us further and further into involvement in World War III. Our whole defence strategy is based around the fallacy that somehow if we please the United States, if we buy its weapons and ships at great cost to ourselves, it will come to protect us. Frankly, ANZUS did us no good at all in 1961. When Indonesia moved into western Papua New Guinea and took over the area, we asked the United States to take some action under ANZUS and it said: `No, our interests are not in taking action in this area because we have interests in Indonesia in terms of oil, rubber and tin, and we do not want them to go commo'. So the United States will not protect us in our only possible confrontation. I am not saying that it will happen, but our defence analysts say that our only possible worry in this area is Indonesia, and the flashpoint could be as the Indonesians move into eastern Papua New Guinea.

Under our present defence strategy, which depends on the United States coming to our aid in times of this crisis, we have no capability of our own. Where are our close ground support aircraft? We have heard the Department of Defence say that we cannot use our FA18s for close ground support because they are too expensive and are too easily knocked out by ground-to-air missiles. Also, they have fatigue cracks. Where are the close ground support aircraft, and the helicopters and gunships, that we could use in a confrontation in Papua New Guinea? Where are our transport aircraft, our surveillance aircraft and our patrol boats? We cannot afford them because we are pouring all of our money into weaponry which matches the United States nuclear strategy-namely, nuclear-capable FA18s and nuclear-capable frigates; and now we are building six submarines, and the admirals say that we are building them to protect our sea lanes in time of the next war. That is 1942 thinking. The next war will be a nuclear war. We will not have sea lanes any more. Yet we are pouring billions of dollars into submarines and neglecting our traditional forces, neglecting the land forces and airborne forces which are what we need to protect Papua New Guinea and northern Australia. The present defence policies desperately need an overhaul if we are to truly defend Australia in this late part of the twentieth century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In what we call an accelerated debate, we each get five minutes to debate a very important subject. I must come to the defence of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Bill Hayden, and give him some credit for the initiatives he has taken. In our area, the initiatives have lessened tensions and opened up paths for negotiation between those powers that confront one another. I was surprised to hear from Senator Michael Baume a eulogy on behalf of the Association of South East Asian Nations. The ASEAN position is fairly clear and fairly partisan. If one reads about the positions that the countries of ASEAN take and the announcements that they make, one finds that they are partisan in being completely opposed to the Government of Vietnam. They take a position which is pro-Pol Pot and a previous regime. Their position is to arm and to continue to arm those forces which seek to continue the confrontation in Kampuchea, and they are working against the peaceful trends which are developing, of which trends Bill Hayden had been the leader.
—The peaceful trends in expansionist Vietnam, eh?

—Oh, Senator, if you are going to talk in terms of expansionism and Vietnam, you will be talking rather idle talk. That is what ASEAN says-that Vietnam is engaged in an expansionist program which threatens the regimes of ASEAN countries, regimes which are militaristic, dictatorial and completely oppressive of their own peoples. That is what the ASEAN regimes represent.
—But the Defence Department likes them.

—Yes, the Department of Defence may take the position that the honourable senator takes, but I have always found the Defence Department to be well behind the changing peaceful attitudes. In fact, I often wonder whether defence departments here and overseas have a vested interest in confrontation and take some comfort from the possibility of war. When the rest of us are endeavouring to solve the world's problems by peaceful means, the defence departments are thinking in terms of the past-and so is Senator Michael Baume. I have to use the word `Michael' because I want to separate the honourable senator from Senator Peter Baume, but maybe the latter thinks in the same way.
—Are you happy about Cam Ranh Bay?

—Cam Ranh Bay has been a development which has been forced upon the Vietnamese. There has been some change in the last days which ought to give the honourable senator some comfort. The change is that there is now developing an understanding between Vietnam and the United States. It is belated; it should have happened ages ago. Were it not for people such as Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Michael Baume, it would have developed far more rapidly. The honourable senators are behind the times. An understanding is taking place there that goes far beyond their thinking. Fortunately for us all, this is happening in spite of the honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: My five minutes is almost over. Here we have an opportunity for a wide-ranging debate on a very important issue and the clock cuts off just when we are starting to develop our argument. I am starting now to put the point of view that I would want to put, but I now have to cede to Senator Puplick. As I have said previously, the Senate will have to take another look at its Standing Orders and see that we have more time to discuss very important matters when they are raised in this place. I put it to Senator Michael Baume that he should take another look at what is happening, rethink his position, give some understanding to the position of Vietnam and to Cambodia, and realise that if they are taking a position with which he does not agree, we have forced them into that position by the fact that we have not understood them, we have opposed them, and we have fought against them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was intending to speak on one of the papers which appear later in today's list, but there comes a time at which one gets absolutely fed up to the back teeth with the anti-American drivel which appears to be the sole motivation of the Australian Democrats. I shall therefore say something about the ANZUS Treaty and, in particular, its value to Australia arising from this defence report. The first point I make is to refer honourable senators to a letter which appeared in the New Zealand Herald of 12 April 1985 written by Dean Rusk, a very distinguished former American Secretary of State, dealing with the way in which the Americans understood the operation of ANZUS. He says in part:

SPEECH.PARA: From the United States' point of view, we took for granted that if Australia or New Zealand were attacked, the United States would have to be involved in their defence.
He goes on to deal with history in relation to Indonesia, and he says:

When Sukarno, of Indonesia, was making hostile moves against Malaysia, I personally told his Foreign Minister, Mr Subandrio, that if elements of the Australia-New Zealand forces in Malaysia were subject to attack, that would trigger the Anzus Treaty because those forces would be covered by its provisions.
I turn now to comments contained in the House of Representatives Hansard for 22 May 1969. I put these comments to Senator Sanders:

The Prime Minister brought back a reaffirmation of the ANZUS treaty by President Nixon in such unequivocal and categorical terms that it gave heart to every member on this side of the House who still believes that the ANZUS treaty is the most precious piece of paper in Australian archives.
The statement goes on:
We have joined with the United States in the ANZUS treaty. The United States has given us a certain undertaking that it will help in our defence if we are attacked.
Yet further it continues:

. . . what sort of morality is to accept what the treaty gives and to give nothing back in return? We on this side of the House believe that we have this sense of morality. If we enter into a treaty for the security of the people of this country for the rest of this century, we cannot have it one sided. We have to give and take. For the assurance which we get under the treaty we are prepared and have the courage to run these risks and accept the responsibilities which the treaty imposes upon us.

Does Senator Sanders accept that as a valid statement about ANZUS and its value? I presume that he does not, but he ought to because those are the words spoken in the House of Representatives on 22 May 1969 by the then honourable member for Higinbotham, Donald Leslie Chipp. If Senator Sanders wants to tell us that now, all of a sudden, these views about ANZUS no longer exist, if he wants to tell us-as he did today-that as far as Cam Ranh Bay is concerned the position of the Soviet Union involves no security implications for Australia, let him do so. Clearly that Soviet base does have security implications for Australia's trading routes. What is exposed here is the craziness of the Australian Labor Party's decisions on things such as the replacement of aircraft carriers, the winding up of the Fleet Air Arm and the like. Senator Sanders really ought to take a far closer look at the security and strategic implications of his views.

All we hear from Senator Sanders and Senator Chipp these days is a one-sided diatribe against the United States of America, a one-sided assault upon everything American and upon all of our relationships with the United States. Implicit in that is a total view that Australia, Australians and Australian governments are all somehow craven and cowardly and are prepared to submit themselves supinely to whatever the United States wants and to take their orders from Washington without any degree of independence. If that is the sort of attitude which the Australian Democrats take towards the American alliance and the integrity of the Australian people, they collectively should be ashamed of themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a most regrettable occasion in that the report from the Department of Defence, which is one of the more important reports to come before this Parliament, was not available to the Senate at the time it should have been. I have had only the most sketchy of views of some photocopied parts of it.
—Don't let that trouble you. The rest of us had the same opportunity.

—Yes. There are a couple of points I would like to make. I reinforce completely Senator Puplick's views in respect of the views of the Australian Democrats. When Senator Sanders was going on in his usual shallow, superficial and vacant-minded way, asking who our enemies were, Senator Kilgariff interjected: `Well, Australia's enemies quite clearly won't be the sort of enemies you have'. I think that is very true.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Georges took us back to the early part of the 1920s and 1930s with a few of the old socialist Marxist views on international affairs and talked about the Vietnamese being frightened by the Kampucheans, the outrageous expansionists in the military regime in Kampuchea. The Vietnamese moved into Kampuchea on Christmas Day 1978, after they had signed a treaty of friendship and co-operation with the Soviet Union. They have been there ever since, murdering, turning people out of their homes and driving hundreds of thousands of refugees into the most abject poverty across the border in Thailand. Where is the threat to Vietnam in Kampuchea? Senator Georges has inverted the whole situation and talked about the Kampucheans threatening the Vietnamese, when the Vietnamese have about the third largest standing army in the world.

I wish to deal with the parts of the report that I have seen. I note with respect to capital equipment an entry for the Wamira, the new basic trainer aircraft. This is an important thing. The Australian Government has used about $48m-it is rumoured that that figure is probably up to $60m now-of taxpayers' money to build a new basic trainer aircraft for the Royal Australian Air Force. The Australian Aircraft Consortium has been disbanded and the management of this project has now been put in the hands of Hawker de Havilland Ltd or Hawker Pacific Pty Ltd. That was done because this project has been so badly mismanaged.

I believe the Parliament should have time to reflect on the wisdom of what we are doing here. We have invested four or five years work and, as I said before, between $50m and $60m of the taxpayers' money and we have got nothing for it. We may get an aircraft that is usable in time as a basic trainer, but at about half the cost we can buy aircraft overseas which fulfil the same role. Close ground support for the Army has been mentioned as a future role for this basic trainer. All I say about that is that it is absolute nonsense. If a highly sophisticated aircraft like an FA18 cannot live over a battle-field in the low level role-I believe that is true given the weapons systems we have today-an aircraft of about one-tenth the complexity and purchased at about one-tenth the cost simply will not survive at all. The solution does not lie in going to a cheaper and less technologically developed aircraft. The solution to the problem is to provide the requisite fire power for the Army by increasing both its armoury and its artillery capacity. That is something which this Government has shown no interest in doing at all. The previous Government did embark--
