DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 November, on motion by Senator Missen:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this matter was brought on on Friday there was no time for debate. My tabling statement was set down and the report was tabled in this Parliament. I think it is important that there be some short debate on this important clash between the National Crime Authority and the monitoring committee so that honourable senators can think about this matter over the Christmas recess.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, we must resolve this question when Parliament resumes. Unquestionably, a complete impasse has developed and has now gone on for nearly a year. The Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority is unanimous in the view that it is impossible to carry on like this and that all we are doing at the moment is providing a cosmetic appearance of monitoring an important Commonwealth authority while in fact we are not able to do so, for reasons which are set out in detail in the report.

I want briefly to expand on the remarks which I made in the tabling statement and to invite honourable senators to consider certain matters which I think are important. In the first place, as I have said, an impasse has existed for many months. It is clear that the National Crime Authority is not prepared to give to the monitoring committee the information it seeks, information which would enable the committee in any way to judge such things as whether proper use is being made of the country's money, whether a proper examination is being made in following up the Costigan inquiries, which were handed over to the National Crime Authority, whether proper use is being made of State task forces, whether the right procedures are being followed as far as the machinery is concerned and whether morale inside the organisation is correct. These are but some of the things which need to be considered.

I stress in the first place that we are not concerned to rehear or examine the particular ideas held by the National Crime Authority. I want to assure the Senate that it is not the intention of the Committee at any stage to do that, but it is its belief that it must make the judgment as to the necessary equipment and information which it may have.

I mention briefly that there has been a leakage of the Committee's report. I mentioned this when I tabled this report last time. I have had time to think about this and have come to the conclusion that it is certainly in no interest of the Committee members, at all, that there should be any such leakage. I stress that the leakage does not involve any information derived from the National Crime Authority being brought out into the public arena; it is merely that the report has been prematurely given into the hands of the newspapers. It is curious that that has happened since the report has been printed. The report has been in its final stage for some weeks. Since the Chairman is in one House and I am in another, there was a delay of some weeks before the report could be brought down in each House on the same day. It is impossible for us to tell who leaked this information, but it is clear that it is embarrassing to the Committee because of the very point that the Committee has made; that is, that it is necessary for it to have information.

One of the arguments used by the National Crime Authority against supplying information to the Committee was that committees of the Parliament tend to leak information and that information tends to get away from them. We already know that there is an intergovernmental committee. This means that a mass of people will have information coming their way. Therefore, there is a great chance of leakage from that source. I say specifically to the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), who is at the table-I see it is not the Minister representing the Special Minister of State (Mr Young)-that I hope that before this debate is over today we can have some assurance from the Minister that no member of his staff leaked or indiscreetly gave this information on the Committee's report to the Press.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seemed to be fairly detailed.

—It was certainly detailed information and there was clear knowledge of the report. We have checked with all senators and I have been assured by the reporter from the Australian since I spoke last about this matter that the leakage certainly did not come from the Senate at all. One can never be sure of these things and one cannot say exactly where it came from, but it was reported as coming from `government sources'. There was some discussion in the other House because one of the members of the Committee took it to be government members. I do not necessarily take that to be so, but `government sources' has a very wide implication. I hope we will have some assurance from the Minister before this day is out that it did not come from the Minister's office. I am not directly suggesting that he would have done this. I will put that matter aside. It is a problem which cannot be allowed to stop us from pursuing and resolving the whole matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is best to illustrate the difficulty the Committee is in by reference to an example in this Parliament. In the Hansard of 22 August Senator Siddons is recorded as asking a question of Senator Button about the taking of a large quantity of drugs. He wanted to know whether the finding and smashing of the drug ring by the Australian Federal Police had been due to the workings of the National Crime Authority and whether information came from the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Apart from the fact that we are told that it did not come from the Costigan Royal Commission, we have been able to find no information about this. In answer to Senator Siddons's question, Senator Button stated:

I am unable to say what the National Crime Authority has done in respect of that reference. I think it is a matter which the parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority would appropriately examine.
It may be quite right that he would think that, but in fact he is quite wrong because we have not been able to find out anything about this matter. Senator Button went on to say:
I think that is a matter which the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority would probably wish to look at.
Senator Chipp interjected:
How long has it had to look at it?
Senator Button indicated finally that he expected that the Committee would do something about it. In a supplementary question, Senator Siddons asked:
Can we get any assurance from the honourable senator that the parliamentary Joint Committee will be given the reference and will report on the matter forthwith?

Senator Button looked at me and saw that I was aware of the fact that the question had been asked. He gave an assurance that we would be able to do it. The fact is that we are unable to answer that question. Since that time, the Chairman of the Committee, Mr Alan Griffiths, has written to the Chairman of the National Crime Authority seeking information about this matter. In reply, on 11 October Mr Justice Stewart, while disposing of the question of whether information came from the Costigan Royal Commission, stated:

The Authority does not feel at this stage that it can provide details of the material which was in fact referred to it by the Royal Commission, nor of the role it played in the arrests which were referred to in the question.

So we are in no position whatsoever to answer the query raised in this Parliament and that question has remained unanswered since August. I take that as just one particular example of the difficulty in which this Committee finds itself. It can ask for information, but it has no way of insisting on having any information placed before it. The members of the Committee are unanimous that they must have that right, otherwise they will not be able to succeed. There are two parts to the recommendation of the Committee. The first part of the recommendation states:
The National Crime Authority Act 1984 should be amended to provide:

(a) that the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority should have the power to do such things and make such inquiries as it thinks necessary for the proper performance of its duties; and

The same provision applies to any other committee empowered in this Parliament. A committee should have the power to call for papers and the power to demand information to enable it to carry out the normal work of an ordinary committee of the Parliament. The second part of the recommendation states:

(b) that where information sought by the Committee is of such a nature that its disclosure to members of the public could prejudice the safety or reputations of persons or the operations of law enforcement agencies then it should be made the subject of a separate report to the Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Committee.

Neither the Chairman nor I particularly welcome having that task in hand, but it is felt that where there is a risk of damage being done to the reputation or life of a person we should receive such reports from the National Crime Authority which can tell us the reasons why this information should not be disclosed. We can then filter this information through to the Committee and ask the Committee whether it thinks it should persist with the request for information. The Committee, of course, must be asked. (Extension of time granted) We believe that this would solve the problem; it may not. It is a matter for the Senate to determine whether more immediate steps should be taken.

If honourable senators read the report and the remarks in it, they will see that an impasse has been reached which must be dealt with and dealt with quickly; otherwise there is but a charade of accountability. Let me make it quite clear what we seek. I make it clear that we do not seek any skirmishing through the facts, trying to rehear evidence and stating what we would have done sitting in the appeal, as it were. I will quote the remarks made by Senator Durack on pages 10 and 11 of the report during the debate in the Committee stage of the Bill. He stated:

The purpose of the committee will not be to get into the details of particular cases. I think it could be most undesirable for the Parliament to turn itself into a grand inquisitor of crime. This is a quite inappropriate role for this Parliament or any committee of the Parliament. The amendment specifically provides that it is not to investigate particular cases. It will not be second guessing what the Authority has done in a particular case. Nevertheless it will have the authority to monitor and review the performance and functions of the Authority; so it will have a wide brief.

The problem is that we are advised by Mr Chris Maxwell of counsel that we have that power under the terms of our charter. This is denied. That is a power which counsel set out. We can examine such things as:

. . . the Authority's decision whether or not to investigate the matter, and the reasons for that decision; whether or not a reference has been requested and/or given in relation to the matter, and the reasons therefore; the particular kind of investigation or other action under section 11 upon which the Authority has resolved to embark; the progress of such investigation or action; the likely or actual outcome of such investigation or action; the powers of the Authority under the Act being utilised for the purpose of such investigation or action; the adequacy or otherwise of such powers.

Unless we can do so, at the moment we can gain no idea of what the Authority is doing. We know that there are `references' for which the most vague particulars are given, for quite adequate reasons. But we know that we cannot tell whether the Authority is fully occupied. We do not know whether the morale of the staff is good. We cannot tell whether adequate attention is being given to references. From that point of view we put it to the Senate that answers were given by Mr Brazil on behalf of the Attorney-General's Department who, after saying that he did not think that we had this power, went on to say that it was not his concern as to whether this will make the monitoring Committee useless. That may not be his concern, but it is the concern of this Parliament.

I put it to the Senate that, therefore, it is necessary for it to act quickly on this report by the Committee. Unless that is done, the work against organised crime will be greatly weakened. The ability of the Committee to monitor on behalf of this Parliament is a charade which must be ceased.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, which is before us, is a matter of considerable regret to all of us in that it covers a situation which never should have arisen. It should and could have been nipped in the bud. It is my belief that the former Attorney-General should and could have obtained an understanding between the Committee and the National Crime Authority at the time the Committee was set up and when the duties of the Authority were being dealt with. That was not done. We are now left with a situation which, right from the first day, has been unsatisfactory in the best interests of the job.

SPEECH.PARA: To look at the Committee we must look at the Authority first and see what we expect of it. Why is there an Authority? What is it there for? How do we see that it produces the maximum performance? Unfortunately, the Authority got away to a very bad start because of the slack takeover from the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, the time taken to get staff, to get reorganised, to get premises, to get records, to set up methods of operation and so on. I think we all concede that the legislation is quite ineffectual and needs a considerable amount of stiffening if we want to have an authority that is capable of making a big impact on organised crime. I do not think anyone really believes that the Authority can operate to maximum benefit with the legislation it has now.

The problem before us has been outlined very considerably. However, the Committee and the Authority see the position of the Committee very differently. The Committee's tabling statement stated its views and requests very adequately. The tabling statement stated:
. . . the National Crime Authority Act should be amended to make it clear that the Committee has a right of access to the full range of information held by the Authority . . .
The next paragraph on page 7 stated:
. . . the exercise of the full powers of inquiry vested in a parliamentary committee.
On the top of page 8 the statement read:

However, I wish to stress the Committee's view that it must be the final arbiter of the extent to which information permissible within the terms of an amendment to the legislation . . . ought properly be provided.

That is an absolute request for everything that is vested in the Authority. I understand that that is what the Committee is seeking. If, as Senator Missen has put, the Committee is actually seeking considerably less than that and does not, in fact, want full access to all the records of what is happening, I prefer that we treat it accordingly. The report contains a recommendation that the Committee should be given `power to do such things and make such inquiries as it thinks necessary for the proper performance of its duties'. This view may well change very considerably between members of the Committee or between the current Committee and a committee that may follow it. I believe that if we really understand what relationship we wish there to be between the Committee and the Authority, we need to state it more carefully than in terms of having powers to do such things and make such inquiries as the Committee thinks fit. I request the Committee to reconsider this matter and see whether it can put together a better method to cover this attitude.

Of course, the Authority relies on the legislation. Section 51 (2) raises the problems that arise for members of the Authority if they divulge or communicate to any person any information. That section too is extraordinarily broad. It refers to `any person' divulging any information. Again, the Committee says that that provision precludes it from making disclosures. The Committee also has to rely on section 55 (2) which states:
Nothing in this Part authorizes the Committee-
(a) to investigate a matter relating to a relevant criminal activity; or
(b) to reconsider the findings of the Authority . . .

According to the views expressed by Senator Missen, that is not the Committee's intention. That is clearly covered by the request it has made in the suggested amendment. Because of the difference of opinion, of course there is a disagreement as to what will happen from now on. The report refers to the matter as what the `parliament intended'. I think it is important that we reconsider what the Parliament intended. The best place to go for that is the actual Hansard transcript of the debate. I do not wish to read it all to honourable senators. We were getting close to the end of a session in June 1984 when this legislation was being hustled through the Senate. What came clearly out of that debate was that Senator Evans, who was leading for the Government; Senator Chipp, who was interjecting on behalf of the Australian Democrats; and Senator Durack, who was speaking for the Opposition, were all very unified on the view that it was not a matter of getting involved with the cases the Authority was dealing with. I again request that the Committee put the matter together in a manner that will confirm that that is the case and specifically exclude any reference to these matters. It would be quite undersirable to go any further into the actual running of the cases and the reference the Authority may have.

The disagreement is most regrettable. It is certainly up to the Parliament as a whole to determine what will happen. Does the Parliament believe that the Committee should, in its own terms, have the power to do such things and make such inquiries as it thinks necessary and a right of access to the full range of information held by the Authority? Does the Parliament believe that section 51 of the Act, requiring secrecy in the performance of the Authority's duties under the Act and the denial of access to matters of detail that concern the Authority regarding security, personal reputations and safety, is respected? I trust that the Parliament can have regard to this matter in the near future.

However, whichever point of view we support, all honourable senators would agree that total confidentiality is absolutely essential in the vital matters handled by the Authority. Regret- tably, the media seem to be able to rely on weak and unreliable members of the Parliament or people elsewhere to get information of a confidential nature. We have seen it with the Age tapes, we have seen it here and we have seen it in many other cases. I regret that the more people who have access to this information, the more likely it is to get away. With this information in mind, I trust that the Senate as a whole is able to recommend to the Committee that we have another look at it, and please let us get the Committee into working condition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak for a moment or two on this motion to support what Senator Missen has said concerning the difficulties that the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority has faced since we have been monitoring the Authority. Early in the piece we had some information, publicly stated, that one of the employees of the Authority, a lawyer, had resigned because he felt that he was not fully occupied and because the morale within the Authority as far as he was concerned was not what it ought to be. We believe it is part of our responsibility to make further inquiries to ensure that the staff are fully occupied. This lawyer was being paid of the order of $700 a day and he felt quite guilty about receiving that amount if his talents were not being used in an effective way. We as a committee feel that it is very important to be able in our monitoring role to call for witnesses within the Authority without getting into any investigatory matters at all.
—That means that you are running the Authority day by day.
—No, we are not. The Authority itself is not held in very high regard in Australia at the moment. You read the Press and you will find--
—Look--

—Look, stop interjecting! I get fed up with your trying to disrupt me. What I want to say is that we have a very important role to play. We certainly do not want to get involved, nor do we intend to get involved, in matters with respect to investigation. We have never suggested that and it is not our intention to do so. It would be wrong for our Committee to get into that sort of personalised detail.
—Well, you have.

—We have not got into that personalised detail with respect to drug pushers. We know the types of cases that are being followed, but we do not expect any specific details at all. We have examined the computer system of the Authority and questioned whether it is secure. We have been assured that the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been to look at it and that it is as secure a system as possible in these days.
—Is it being properly used?

—That is another matter we want to find out. Is it being properly used for the benefit of the Authority? Is the law that has been prescribed by the Government sufficiently tight? Does it give the Authority sufficient power to do the job we expect it to do? That is one of the jobs we want to follow through. I can assure Senator Archer-and I am sure that I speak for the rest of the Committee-that there is nothing sinister at all about the report. We just want to be able to do our work, as any other committee does.
—I am not accusing you of being sinister.

—I think the honourable senator said that he did not want us to be involved in personal matters. We do not want to do that at all. We do not want to have our Committee getting involved in anything that is going to jeopardise the secrecy or investigative efficiency of the Authority. We want to be in a position to back it up and to report to the Parliament in an intelligent way. We have found it very difficult to get even general information.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Missen said, Justice Stewart has agreed, where there may be matters of some sensitivity, to consult with the Chairman, Mr Griffiths, and the Deputy Chairman, Senator Missen. As Senator Missen quite properly said, that information would be distilled and reported to the Committee and the appropriate decision could be made. We know that some staff of the Authority believe that changes could be made to the legislation to assist them in their work. I want to help them to follow through and deal with these major criminals in Australia who are creating so much concern throughout the community with respect to drugs and so on. I just wanted to support what Senator Missen had to say. I will be very happy to discuss the matter, as I am sure he would and the Chairman would, if there are any matters that are still in doubt; and I am sure that we can clear those matters up satisfactorily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-What we desire here is that this matter go to the responsible Minister and that discussions take place. With respect to Senator Archer, it is no good sending it back to the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority for us to look at it. He may not think that we have sufficiently spelt out what is necessary for the proper performance of our duties-that may have to be spelt out in the Act-but it is quite pointless to take this matter back to the Committee because we have reached an impasse in our communication with the Authority and it is important that we get some movement in the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: We made no particular reference to the words used in our recommendation. We have never desired to investigate individual cases or to reconsider the findings of the Authority, things which are not permitted under the Act anyway. Those two things are quite specifically excluded from us. But the Authority takes the Act to be so wide in its restrictions as to mean that we cannot ask what it is doing. We have to resolve, probably with longer language than is in the Act, exactly what the wording means. Consequently, I think it important now for the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), the Authority and the Committee to discuss the type of legislation required.

What we have done is to put the situation before the Minister because it is his problem now; it is not a problem we can solve. Consequently, we assure the Minister that the last thing we want to do is to delve into details, to say how we would have done it, to go into individual aspects or to do something of that sort. We want to know though that actions are being fully explored, that plenty of work is being done and properly done--

TALK.START.PARA: —And the morale of the staff.

—That the morale of the organisation is good and, as I mentioned by way of interjection, that the computer is being used for valuable purposes and not just to store material. That is just one example.

SPEECH.PARA: We want to make sure that the right methods are being used by the Authority. We cannot assure this Parliament of anything at the moment. Because of that, we believe it is our duty to put this matter before the Minister. This is merely a motion to take note of the report, but I hope that if anybody gets any ideas over the recess period they will bring them to my knowledge, to the knowledge of the Chairman, to the shadow Minister or the Minister so that we can get this resolved early in the New Year.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON THE NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 November, on motion by Senator Robertson:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the following amendment to the motion that the Senate take note of the report, which is in the terms of notice of motion No. 83 given by me on 14 November, when the report of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House was tabled:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after `that', and insert
`The Senate-
(a) accepts the necessity for the interior finish of the Senate chamber in the new Parliament House to maintain in suitable form the dignity and atmosphere of the present chamber;

(b) considers that it is appropriate for the new chamber to have a basically wood-panelled appearance, taking advantage of, and making use of the wide range of timbers to be found throughout Australia; and

(c) rejects the proposal, recently revealed to senators, for the walls of the new chamber to be lined with fabric of varying colours, not consistent with the traditional red colour common to Westminster-style Upper Houses.

In my view this is a debate of very considerable importance to this chamber. As I suspect is the case with many honourable senators, it was only recently that I had an opportunity to become interested in the design and the layout of the new chamber. I am indebted, as I am sure are all senators, to the President for providing a display model in his office which gave us all an opportunity to form judgments. I must say that for my part I was pretty much astounded and certainly very disappointed with the concept that had been put forward. One has to ask oneself where the architects got their ideas from.

Without being too critical in a general sense of architects, it seems symptomatic of architects that they have their own ideas of what is good for the rest of the world. One gets the impression that the concept of these architects was not drawn from a viewing of the operations of this chamber. I am seeking to be objective and I do not want to single out anybody in particular for the concept. One might be inclined to criticise the architects or the Parliament House Construction Authority. I make no judgment on where the responsibility up to this point rests. However, I have to say that I get the clear impression that the interior design of the Senate chamber in no way reflects or fully appreciates the functioning or operational systems of the Westminster tradition. If one were to accept the break away from the traditional Westminster red and the substitution of `Australian Pilbara reds', I can only say that the salmon pink shades that I have seen are not the colour of the Pilbara. I do not say that without some authority. I lived in the Pilbara for six years. Having looked at the design and the colours, I see no comparison between the stark basic red of the Pilbara and the anaemic--

TALK.START.PARA: —Balmain colours?

—One might say Balmain, but certainly the anaemic, modest, pale pinks that we have seen in the design. There is certainly no relationship between the two. Of course, the great tragedy is that in Australia we are going through a euphoric phase of wanting everything to be Australiana. Naturally, that will date everything that we do. Once we get over this inferiority complex we will find that the chamber in the new Parliament House and the Parliament generally will be dated. With regard to the reality and the intent of the chamber, I quote from the report:

SPEECH.PARA: In each Chamber the symbolic colour is maintained to present a unified interior, yet it is gradually lightened as it rises toward the light entering from the clerestories and skylight at the ceiling thereby unifying the whole space.
To me that gives a clear impression of the esoteric judgment of the architects.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't call it Utopia.

—One certainly would not call it Utopia. One realises from that extract what was intended by the architect. But having viewed the proposals for the chamber, they certainly give me an impression of being an absolute mish-mash of misunderstanding as to the purpose of the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I wished to raise other matters but there are other senators who wish to speak briefly this afternoon. I am very anxious that this matter be put to the vote. On that basis, I will decline to speak further. I hope that those contributing to the debate will do so in a constructive way and will support my proposition, and that following that we will have a quick vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to speak this afternoon or in fact today but I have been encouraged by the motion moved by Senator Crichton-Browne to make known my views about the complexion and cosmetics of the chamber of the new Parliament House. As he has pointed out, it is very important that continuity be sought in not only the functions carried out in this chamber but indeed the whole atmosphere in which those functions take place. I doubt very much whether we will be able to carry the sense of this chamber as a House of review with us to the new building unless some of the physical geography of this place is also transferred in symbolic and cosmetic terms. I am looking for something which will be conducive to recreating the considerable deliberative debate that goes on in this chamber. To help create that atmosphere, let us take with us some of the attributes of this beautiful chamber which I have grown to love and admire over the seven years that the people of Tasmania have seen fit to send me to this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I see much merit in Senator Crichton-Browne's proposition that we retain the wood pannelled walls and the effect around the galleries in the new Parliament House. The fact is that there is a variety of timbers all around Australia which are of immense beauty and which would themselves become a symbol of the Federation. If we had timbers from the various parts of Australia, they would add to the tradition of the wood panelled walls and galleries of this chamber. I see some symbolism in taking timbers from right around Australia instead of having the very weak, insipid pink, somewhat reddish, somewhat salmonish, fabric colours that are being foisted on us at the moment. In fact, Senator Crichton-Browne has made it very clear that in his opinion the so-called attempt to capture the colours of the outback has utterly failed and the suggested colours bear no resemblance whatsoever to the striking reds of the Pilbara region. I must say that to my Tasmanian eyes none of the reds or pinks have any appeal whatsoever. In fact, if I were looking for something more agreeable to my eyes, I would look to the beautiful greens and emerald colours that we so much admire in Tasmania.

I see there is interest on all sides of the chamber in this matter. What is required is a continuity of function, aided by a continuity of the geographical attributes of this chamber. We need wood panelling and red colouring. The red colour is symbolic of those good parts-I do not say that all parts are good-of the Westminster tradition transferred to the colonies. In fact, just this week we passed a Bill in this chamber which cuts off many of the traditional legal links with the United Kingdom. Nevertheless, we are inheritors of the Westminster tradition and ministerial responsibility. I believe that, insofar as the Senate colours at the moment reflect the colours of the upper House in the Westminster Parliament, that tradition should be continued and transferred to the new site.

I am delighted that Senator Crichton-Browne brought this matter to the chamber by way of an amendment. It is about time that senators took a bit more interest in what is going on in the design of their chamber. We saw what an awful orthopaedic mess was made of the seats and chairs that we were supposed to sit on in conducting the business of this place. Unless senators take control of the colour and the panelling of the chamber, it will end up looking like the foyer of a Sheraton hotel instead of a chamber of review.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by Senator Crichton-Browne. There are many things I would like to say about this but, bearing in mind that other senators also wish to speak, I will be brief. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter that I wrote to the President on 16 September 1985 which clearly outlines some of my views on this matter. I have shown the letter to the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), who is at the table.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
My dear President,
Thank you for the opportunity to view the plans and displays relating to the new Parliament House.
There are a few comments that I believe it is appropriate to make.

One of the advisers made the point that it had been deemed appropriate to shift from `Westminster' red and green to `Australian' red and green. The extension of this point was that after considerable research the `appropriate' green had been discovered. I understand this appropriate green is described as `young eucalyptus' and following on from that the appropriate red is the red in the veins of the leaves.

I am not enamoured with these ideas. I would be more than grateful to be given permission to see the research that led to each of these conclusions. I do trust that it will reveal what it is that has occasioned the Australian public to suddenly develop an abhorrence for Bottle-Brush (Senate) red and Bottle (House of Representatives) green. Additionally I will be interested to see whether the said research, in reflecting this desired shift away from Westminster colours also asserts a desired shift away from the Westminster system of Parliament. In my view the `red' carpet sample is more appropriately described as ochre/mud.

The adviser further explained that a fabric would cover the walls of the Chamber and that the colour scheme in the Chamber would extend from the dark colour of the carpet to the lighter covering on the walls in the public gallery. This graduation of colour and the use of a fabric was to achieve three things:
1. Acoustic benefits
2. Focus on the Chamber
3. Visually emphasise the link between Parliament and the people.
I make the following points:

1. Acoustic Requirements-I understand that in other Parliament Houses they have managed to have an acoustically suitable Chamber without using fabric on the walls. May I enquire as to the reason it is regarded as impossible to achieve the desired acoustic standard using timber.

2. From a purely domestic point of view I believe that timber is easier to keep clean and looking good. Fabric on the other hand is not easy to keep clean, it collects dust, shows grubby marks and furthermore deteriorates to a condition that can best be described as tatty.

3. The Press Gallery-If one wanted to truly represent the relationship between the Australian people and their Parliament may I be so bold as to suggest that we alter the plans and put the Press Gallery smack in the middle or rather between the Chamber and the people.

4. Wallaby Mentality-I personally regret that development in Australia of what I choose to refer to as a wallaby mentality. This mentality requires those afflicted with it to feel and believe they are not Australian unless they engage in a consistent and jingoistic rubbishing of aspects of our society that history has been so kind as to pass on to us. This resentment at acquired values is directed particularly to those things British and American. The burning passion to surround ourselves with things `Aussie' and to expel matters seen as being English or American reminds me of the phrase `unless ye see ye do not believe'. Are we soon to be presented with macrame vegemite jars to decorate our office walls? Will America's Cup tea towels be standard issue for each office?

5. The fabric shown to us by the adviser as being an indication of what will go on the walls and which was crafted or worked in some way, showed a distinct resemblance to table cloths I have seen in country hotels and reminded me of one of my late grandmother's shawls.

I further make the point that what an architect or designer believes is appropriate today, may well not be appropriate in five or ten years time. Given the expenditure involved I feel I should be forgiven for believing that it would be more appropriate to adhere to classic and basic requirements of style and function rather than pursuing today's ``flavour of the month'' image. Not to do so is to ignore the deep-seated traditional values within our society. All too frequently tomorrow's projections become yesterday's fad.

As you probably realise John Kennedy said `Civility is not a sign of weakness'. Let me steal his style and say that traditional atmosphere is not necessarily a rejection of challenge, change and reform.

Would you be so kind as to provide me with details of the access to the Chamber that staff will be provided with and the proximity to the Chamber of any areas in which Senators will be able to discuss matters with their staff.
I do hope that a forum will be provided for all Senators to discuss these matters together.
Yours sincerely,
AMANDA VANSTONE
Senator for South Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I would like to make a few comments specifically with respect to this report. Page 2 of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The design of the Chambers endeavours to create a sense of `intimacy' within spaces . . .

I may have a different idea of what is intimate in the archtiectural sense than do the architects and interior designers, but I certainly think they have failed in their endeavours in that respect. When one peruses the answers given at certain Estimates committee hearings one finds that the architects, interior designers or somebody from the Parliament House Construction Authority went to Europe to look at the Volvo factory because it was held to have some sort of similar arrangement with the Senate and House of Representatives chambers. So much for intimacy within the chambers. Also on page 2 of the report the point is made that the chambers are surrounded by lobbies for senators and members at ground level. I raise the point, as I did in my letter to the President, that there should be a space very close to the chambers for senators and members to discuss matters with their staff.

Comment has already been made about the use of symbolic red and green. I think we should stick with the traditional Westminster red and green. I accept that some people would say that we are not in Westminster; but I say that we are not in central Australia. The true analogy to draw is that we are in a parliament that runs on a Westminster-style system and accordingly, we should use Westminster-style colours. The next point I make is with respect to the fabric panels for acoustics. I simply cannot accept that it is not possible for architects to design the surface of wood panelling to achieve the same result they would achieve with the recommended fabric panels. The last point I make is that on page 4 of the report we are told in pagragraph No. 14:

Translation galleries are included in the design of each Chamber to provide facilities required on occasions when the Chambers may be used for mutli-lingual conferences. The translation system will be cabled to all floor level positions in each Chamber.

I register a protest at the Senate and House of Representatives chambers having money spent on them to prepare them to be used as convention centres. It is my view, which I have expressed before in relation to this Government using the chambers of this Parliament as convention centres for the assorted summits it has, that this is totally inappropriate. Each chamber of Parliament should be used for parliamentary business, and parliamentary business alone, in my view. Having made those points, I think it is fair that I not take up the time available to me and give it to other senators who wish to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I disagree with all the previous speakers. I am amazed, and I am sure that people who are listening to this debate are amazed, that the Senate is sitting a week longer than the House of Representatives with a huge legislative program before it, yet we are engaging in an indulgent debate about what colour the Senate chamber should be in several years' time when we take our places in the new Parliament House. The people of Australia are well and truly entitled to ask what the hell we are doing if we descend to that degree of indulgence. My dismay at this debate is eclipsed only by the fact that there seems to be a degree of bipartisanship across the chamber between the conservative-the traditionals-and the orthodox members of this chamber, all of them joining hands across-
—As distinct from the pinkos.

—I will deal with you in a minute, Senator Crichton-Browne. Don't worry, you've got it coming. There is a keen desire to turn one's back on modernity, on a contemporary view of the new Parliament House, and on the attempt to make the new Parliament House relevant to Australia, and to try to re-incorporate the traditional British model which is more relevant to Britain than to this country. It is about time we designed our chamber to suit Australia and Australia's needs and tastes. That is what the proposal for the new Parliament House attempts to do.

SPEECH.PARA: It is surprising that the conservatives-I use that word as a general term for all those who have argued for tradition-prefer Politburo red to any of the changes that are being suggested. It says something about the authoritarian view of traditionalism and conservatism that Politburo red-the red that surrounds us in this chamber-is the preferred choice of honourable senators who have spoken previously. The plans for the new Parliament House reflect contemporary taste and design. The new Parliament House is scheduled to be opened in our bicentennial year. The idea of the new Parliament House is to reflect a coming age, not an age that is past. It ought to reflect what the traditions will be in the future and not what the traditions have been in the past. It is about time we dragged ourselves, kicking and screaming, into the late twentieth century and set cornerstone on the new Parliament House which reflects a modern view of the world, rather than harking back to the age-old orthodoxies of the past. I think it would be a grave mistake to try to replicate this chamber in the new Parliament House on the hill behind us. It is my very firm view that the traditions of this chamber, particularly on 11 November 1975, should never be immortalised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose this amendment for the reason that it would lead to the destruction of yet more rainforest timbers.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the response we get in here-a braying and snorts of derision-when someone starts talking about Australia's heritage, rainforest timbers. This chamber is lined with rainforest timbers. There is mahogony and cedar in here-beautiful timbers. Unfortunately, we cannot now find enough cedar in existence in the rainforests of Queensland to line a chamber such as this. We simply cannot find this type of cedar because it has been logged out as we had no appreciation of the native woods and trees of the country.
—Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. This chamber is panelled with Tasmanian blackwood, not cedar.
—There is no point of order.

—If the honourable senator cares to do so, at a time of his convenience I will take him around and show him cedar in this chamber. I will also show him mahogony. Perhaps together we can find some fine Tasmanian blackwood. We will find the timber because it was put in this chamber many years ago. The honourable senator would be hard pressed to find the same type of blackwood or any other rainforest timber in Tasmania since the implementation of dangerous woodchipping and other exploitative policies. I point out that page 79 of a report tabled in this Parliament entitled `Rainforest Conservation in Australia' and presented to the Hon. Barry Cohen, Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, by a working group on rainforest conservation in September 1985, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The most significant of the areas liable to future logging are in northern Queensland, where 1986--
that is, next year--
will mark the end of an era of more than 100 years of virgin rainforest logging, as virgin areas available for logging will have been worked through.

According to this report, in 1986-one year from now-there will be no more virgin rainforests. They will have been logged through. There are also substantial areas of virgin rainforest in Tasmania, where logging has been deferred until 1988-three years from now-pending a comprehensive inventory and assessment by the State Government department. Previously in this chamber I pointed out that the State Government department in question is the Department of Forestry which has as its--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. At the risk of curtailing this debate, I say that I was rather hoping that in decency we could have had a vote. I put it to you, Mr Deputy President, that although Senator Sanders might be into virgin rainforests, they are irrelevant to this debate. I ask that he confine himself to remarks relevant to the debate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Paragraph (b) of the amendment reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: Considers that it is appropriate for the new chamber to have a basically wood-panelled appearance, taking advantage of, and making use of the wide range of timbers to be found throughout Australia . . .
Therefore, Senator Sanders's remarks are relevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. I will limit my remarks because I know that other senators wish to comment on this.
—We do not want to vote today. Give people an opportunity to think about it. You just keep talking.

—I will keep speaking while others discuss the merits or otherwise of coming to a vote. The point is that the chamber could be tastefully lined with some fabric or material other than wood. If it is to be lined with wood I suggest that the wood be obtained from present woodchip areas-from the logs which are now being chipped and taken to Japan. The wood could be fine Tasmanian oak. It could be other Tasmanian timbers, such as myrtle, which are being woodchipped and sent to Japan. This wood should be preserved. If the chamber must be lined with wood it should be lined with wood which is saved from the Japanese and saved from the avariciousness of the woodchip companies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My views on this are clear, at least in terms of colour. I have circulated letters to my colleagues supporting very much the use and the proposal of use of the colours that go to the heart of the central desert of Australia. In particular I have made reference to the colours in the Fred Williams Pilbara series. I do not believe we could do any better than that. If the dye mechanisms have not produced sufficiently satisfactory colours, that is perfectly open to further experimentation until we arrive at a perfectly lovely colour or series of colours. It has been explained very clearly to those of us who took the time to have a briefing from Ric Thorp and others from the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House that the acoustics of the chamber make it quite impossible to use timber panelling as has been proposed. I do not think Senator Sanders need fear for the timber because it is not possible to use it if we want a chamber of that increased size, compared with this chamber, and intimacy to allow conversations to be heard as they are with the acoustics in this chamber. We have been advised that all sorts of experts have deliberated quite considerably on that area, and I do not believe any honourable senator who happens on this by chance on the second or third last day of the session would be qualified to speak against that expertise. Our desires or preferences may be put but I do not believe we could claim expertise. I am further advised that the timber that is proposed to be used in the new Parliament House has already been cut down. It is actually to be taken from timber already felled. Senator Sanders need not fear for trees currently standing.

SPEECH.PARA: I strongly support the proposals for change. I think we are moving, on the occasion of the Bicentennial of Australia, to a time when it would be most appropriate to make some statements for the independence and significant difference of this Parliament House from the one we are in now. I also think we can continue sufficient traditions, particularly through the processes of what happens in that room. Therefore I think the colour of the room is largely irrelevant. One has only to visit the chambers in various countries that continue the Westminster system to see how each country has expressed that in its own different way. I think it is a monument to nonsense to lead arguments of tradition and continuity to justify those sorts of positions.

I have no qualms at all in disagreeing with Senator Tate. I find it remarkable, in a man of his perspicacity, to be so entrenched in this one small area. I ask members of the Opposition whether the red they are proposing is the red they so often find under their beds. I also must say that the honourable senators who claim not to be informed sufficiently to this point ought to be chided a little for not interesting themselves in the continuing process and review of construction of the new Parliament House. Those of us who have taken a little time to maintain an interest would understand what a fantastic and splendid building it will be and what a wonderful opportunity it is for Australia, which is now in the process of building what I think is the greatest building currently under construction anywhere in the world, to have that as a matter of great pride. I think-this is strongly in support of Senator Cook's remarks-that we are making a new into-the-future Australian Parliament House, not a memorial to times past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Crichton-Browne's amendment. As my understanding is that the time allotted for this debate is due to expire in about three minutes, can the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) indicate whether an opportunity might be provided before we rise, for a vote to be taken. I hope that is the correct method, otherwise-
—Sort out your priorities. It took three years to get this sorted out.

—I well recall being in this chamber when Senator Evans managed to detain it for more than an hour, as a member of the then committee reporting on the new and permanent Parliament House, because the matter was, in his view, of such enormous significance that he thought it necessary to seek an extension of time to tell us about all of his views on the importance of the aesthetic design of the building, about the architects and about all the work that he had put into the whole thing. I am not prepared to accept that Senator Evans finds it inconvenient to have matters decided now, because when he wants to have matters decided he believes that the Senate should make whatever time is available for him to express his views. Yet he believes that nobody else should be accorded the same courtesy. Under those circumstances I would not be prepared to take the opportunity of moving that the question be put, but rather I shall continue the remarks which I wish to make in support of Senator Crichton-Browne's amendment and in support of the ideas behind it.

SPEECH.PARA: I think in any institution which has certain values those values tend to be reflected in structures and in forms. Sometimes those forms are particular verbal forms in which motions are put; sometimes they are the structures of the legal processes, such as whether judges dress in a particular fashion or whether cases are conducted in a particular fashion. One of the fundamental reflections of the operation and the underlying value of parliamentary institutions has been the physical presence which surrounds the debate and the way in which it takes place. What is currently proposed in the recommendations of the architects and designers would, I believe, lead to some fundamental changes which the majority of honourable senators would not believe to be desirable. I believe that the motion as moved by Senator Crichton-Browne is more likely to preserve the reflection of the traditions and values of a deliberative chamber and House of review. He mentioned in his motion the use of the traditional red colour, whatever description is given to it-I think it is Westminster red. For Senator Coates's edification, I take that to be the colour of the older leather chairs in this place-

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your Leader's chair?

—I am not responsible for the avant-garde taste of my Leader. I am simply making some comment about the particular view. This is not a matter on which the Opposition has a party view, and when it comes to any vote on this, it will be a free vote. Mr Deputy President, may I seek leave to continue my remarks.
—There is no need. The time allotted under sessional order for this debate has now expired.
—Is it possible under Standing Orders for me to move for the resumption of the debate?
—The debate will automatically remain on the Notice Paper and will come up when ordered under General Business.
—Do the Standing Orders enable me to move that the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for Friday of this week?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It is within Standing Orders if you wish to do so.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Puplick) agreed to:
That the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for Friday, 6 December 1985.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the luncheon break and the ensuing debates I was referring to the effect of the Government's taxation package. At that time I was referring specifically to the motor industry. I now pose the question: How much revenue is the tax change expected to bring? There is no doubt that the losses resulting from reduced registration fees, sales taxes, comprehensive and third party insurance, not to mention losses in company profits and losses in personal income tax from those people who will lose jobs as a result of the tax package, will amount to a considerable sum.

SPEECH.PARA: I referred to the growth in sales of motor vehicles from May until October this year. I referred to the fact that sales of luxury cars did not seem to be affected quite as much as the sales of cars in the cheaper range. I sought leave to incorporate in Hansard a small article from the Australian Financial Review of yesterday. I think Senator Coates and my dear friend Senator Georges thought I wanted to incorporate the entire Australian Financial Review simply because I did not have time to trim the article from the newspaper. I have the article here and I hope that I can now persuade honourable senators opposite to allow me to incorporate it in Hansard. I seek leave to do so.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
KEATING'S TAX VICTIMS EMERGE IN CAR SALES
By Lim Say Boom
Taxes may come and (occasionally) go but the truly rich, it seems, keep putting small fortunes into four wheels.

While those who have made it may regard the tax designs on their company cars by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, as little more than a cheeky attack on tradition and a minor irritant, things have not been looking so peachy for the middle management and yuppie end of the luxury car market since the tax debate started this year.

The market performance of the different models vary considerably across the lower luxury end of the market, with some like the Mazda 929, Ford Fairlaine and Toyota Cressida bearing up better under the pressure than others. But the latest IDAPS motor registration figures for the 10 months to October suggest that the sportier imported Japanese cars and the more trendy European `yuppie-mobiles' have become the first victims of the decline in consumer confidence since the start of the tax debate.
The biggest losers in the luxury car market so far are the Japanese, many of whom have brought down huge, devaluation-related price hikes over the year.
On the other hand, the prestige marques like Mercedes Benz, BMW, Porsche and Saab have weathered the tax debate smoothly and with style.
Here is the casualty list:
Registrations for the Mitsubishi Starion have fallen for the year to October by a massive 36.8 per cent compared with the same period last year.
Registrations for the Mazda RX7 are down 18 per cent on last year.
The Peugeot 505 is down 5.9 per cent on last year.
The Volvo 240 is down 19.7 per cent.
The Nissan Skyline is down 15.2 per cent.
The Honda Prelude is down 4.3 per cent.

All this took place in a year in which the Australian car market has been booming. Although growth in the car market has slowed considerably in the past few months, the industry is still tipped to achieve a record volume of between 680,000 to 690,000 cars this year.
The latest figures show that car registrations are still 9 per cent higher for the year to October compared with the same period last year.
This compares with growth figures of 10.8 per cent for the year to September, 10.6 per cent for the year to August, and 12.4 per cent for the year to July.

While some luxury car dealers have been complaining about an alleged downturn in business, the IDAPS registration figures still show a dizzy 33.7 per cent increase in volume in the upper luxury market for the year to October compared with the corresponding period last year.
As the following figures indicate, the bottom appears to have indeed fallen out of the lower luxury car market.
Growth in the lower luxury car market for the year to:
Month...%
March...29.7
April...28.6
August...10.2
September...8.4
October...5.9
However, the upper luxury market figures show up the difference between being rich and nouveau riche.
Growth in the upper luxury car market for the year to:
Month...%
March...41.5
April...7.5
August...32.0
September...34.4
October...33.7

As BMW Australia's managing director, Mr Ron Meatchem, put it at the recent launding of his company's new model line-up for 1986: ``In times of stress, the luxury sector always bears up better than the mass market sector.''
Other BMW executives put it more bluntly in terms of senior management's perception of the company car as a ``right'' and a ``reward'' for excellence and performance rather than a ``privilege''.

Mercedes-Benz Australia's managing director, Mr Bernt Schlickum, says that in harder times, those who can afford to buy luxury cars will be more ``selective'' and look for ``quality'' products as an investment.
Mr Schlickum has much to be happy about this year.
Even with the tax funk, Mercedes-Benz has enjoyed a 35 per cent lift in sales for the year to date.
As one luxury car importer put it: ``The senior management guy is not going to cop the austerity drive in his company himself. He's obviously going to start by looking down the management chain.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate, particularly Senator Coates and, in his absence, Senator Georges. The article is headed `Keating's tax victims emerge in car sales'. That article contains a table illustrating what has happened since May this year. The motor vehicle industry has analysed the situation to date. It now believes that in a full year the extra tax on motor vehicles will result in a loss of 100,000 new motor vehicle sales each year. The car manufacturing firms know that this could mean a loss of tens of thousands of jobs. In addition to the losses of jobs of people employed directly in building those vehicles, there also will be a considerable loss of jobs in the support industries.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of the entertainment taxes the effect is even more widespread. That was detailed quite well earlier today by Senator Knowles in her speech. The entertainment tax will affect the whole spectrum of service jobs as well as the agricultural industries, such as the fishing industry and so on, associated with food production. Earlier in the debate the BIS-Shrapnel Pty Ltd study on the effects of ending tax deductions for entertainment was cited as proving beyond doubt that the adverse effect on various industries would be much worse than the Government has disclosed. I am aware that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has had his Department produce a counter-attack to this report. I think Senator Maguire mentioned that Treasury report earlier. However, Senator Maguire forgot to say that the Treasury report failed to show how Government claims could be proved. Knowing Mr Keating's predilection for shouting `cheat, cheat, cheat!'-which I have heard him reported as saying in the past-it is my belief that his estimate reflects his own cheating. Senator Maguire did not spell out that anomaly in his speech; he did not show how the Government could prove its claim.

The BIS-Shrapnel study concluded that the increase in tax revenue that the Government would gain from this particular impost would be closer to $79m than to the Treasurer's estimate of $310m. The report also predicted that there would be a loss of some 18,000 jobs, of which approximately 11,000 would be in the hospitality industry. The BIS-Shrapnel study assumed that business would cut its entertainment by 35 per cent to keep its outgoings on entertainment to pre-tax levels. I have it on good authority that many restaurant owners are keeping permanent staff intact until after the end of the year-we all realise that pre-Christmas festivities represent the peak time in the restaurant business-to see whether they can survive at their old staffing levels. After New Year's Eve trade in the entertainment industry always drops. I think, therefore, that early in 1986 we will see the demise of many restaurants throughout Australia. Senator Chipp and others have criticised high class restaurants and called them rip-off joints. I am surprised at that.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are the topless ones, are they?

—Senator Chipp may be able to tell the honourable senator about that; I am not sure. I do not believe that Senator Chipp is a noted businessman in this area. High class restaurants which draw trade from business entertainment are usually located in high rental premises with expensive furnishings, crockery and cutlery. Such restaurants also have to carry an extremely wide range and variety of wines. The interest that they must now pay on their overdrafts has increased dramatically and is causing them difficulties, even without the imposition of the tax we are dealing with now. It looks as though Senator Chipp has done a deal with the Treasurer. As Louise Dodson reported in the Australian Financial Review of 2 December, taxation analysts see few gains to taxpayers. Senator Chipp may feel that he is assisting the Government here but he is certainly not getting very much for the taxpayers of Australia. I believe the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) is disastrous. However, the people have voted the socialist Australian Labor Party into government for better or for worse.
—And will again, starting this Saturday.

—I would like to see what happens in 18 months or two years when we again go to the polls. The people by then will realise what we have suffered. Jobs and revenue have been lost. The increase in public borrowings has resulted in the public debt now being an all time record high. As Senator Townley often reminds us, we are paying in this Budget something in the order of $6.7 billion in interest on public debt. That will increase next year by at least 20 per cent, or I will be very much surprised. All of the people who are affected by this socialist Government's bad economic package will realise that the ALP Government was elected for the worse. They will realise that they were misled. They will realise that they were misled by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in relation to the capital gains taxes and so on. As soon as the election was over he tore up his promises and introduced this tax.

SPEECH.PARA: When our Party resumes government after the next election we will rescind that tax. That has been made perfectly clear. The taxation Bills we are dealing with will further reduce the number employed in the private sector by diverting the community's resources into unproductive areas. This is where the Government is destroying jobs in the private sector. Of the 711,000 additional jobs created in the past ten years, 517,000-or 73 per cent-are outside the private or market sector and are thus heavily dependent on government expenditure. A large number of the services produced by these government employees actually reduce expansion and development in the private sector. When the Liberal-National coalition resumes government we will put in place a package of tax legislation which is fair and equitable and which encourages a move towards the private sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —It won't be done by the ACTU.
—We will not let it.
—The partners in government.

—The Australian Council of Trade Unions dictates to honourable senators opposite all the time. It is important to realise that in 1969 51 Australians were employed and paid for by the public purse for every 100 employed in the private sector. In Australia today there are 100 people dependent on the public purse to every 100 in the private sector-and, of course, private enterprise is the sector that generates the revenue to sustain public servants in their jobs. My colleague Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle established a principle which I believe is important and relevant to these Bills. In October 1983, amongst other things, she said:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that it is accepted that a government is entitled to expect the passage of a normal Budget and budget type legislation and other legislation that is an essential part of its financial program. However, there will be rare occasions when an Opposition will feel compelled to reject or substantially amend such legislation, within the constitutional limitations of the Senate, where it is demonstrated to be capricious and arbitrary or vindictive legislation, or where it creates new tax burdens of a retrospective kind.

I think that many of these tax changes are bordering on the capricious; many of the measures contemplated by the Government are bordering upon the arbitrary; and certainly they could be considered to be vindictive ideologically. But, as I said earlier, the people elected this Government and the Government has a right to the funds on which it governs. This Bill, like others, is bad. I only hope that the people will understand that the way to get rid of this and other offensive tax Bills is to vote the Hawke Labor Government out of power.

I repeat what I said earlier in my speech that the Government should have been prepared to provide the people of Australia with an immediate private personal tax reduction and perhaps to provide the rest of it next year. Australia is one of the highest personal taxing countries in the Western world and we are one of the lowest in terms of indirect tax. Senator Townley today mentioned the subject of flat tax and some Labor senators tried to refute that concept, but it is a worthwhile alternative to examine. I noted that John Stone came out in support of it in an article not long ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does that prove?

—I think it proves that he knows a bit more about economics than does Senator Coates. I have carried out some research on this matter, although I have not completed it. There are a few little problems to be overcome. A 20 per cent tax is proposed. There is a problem in the $14,000 to $17,000 salary range but that can be overcome, and we must also look at the possibility of spreading the burden of indirect tax a little more profitably.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Maguire said that no undertakings had been given by the Opposition with respect to repealing the so-called free lunch. However, Senator Messner has indicated in an amendment that the Opposition is thinking on this question, and we will certainly be acting on it in government. He suggests an amendment which would foreshadow a Liberal-National Party Government policy in future, which is that the Commissioner of Taxation should be able to decide whether a luncheon with a business associate is contributing to assessable income. That is a policy forecast that I will support. I will continue to be in the forefront in encouraging that next Liberal-National Party Government to move quickly to repeal those thoughtless and damaging measures introduced by this big-spending, disastrous socialist Government as soon as possible after the next Federal election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard Senator Jessop's justification for his vote on this package of tax Bills. Judging by some of the things he has said in the past, one would have expected him to have supported some of these measures, including the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), which I presume the Opposition will oppose. The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, justifies the Opposition's position on these Bills by saying that Opposition members will vote for the good parts and oppose what they see as the parts with less popularity. In other words, he wants to support the tax cuts that will be introduced in legislation next year to take effect in the next financial year and the one after. He did this on the amazing justification that that was part of the Budget and that everything else in these tax measures is not. If he thought about the matter for more than a moment, he would appreciate that no one part of the tax measures is any more or less part of the Government's Budget than any other. He is grasping at straws with that justification for the messy position into which the Opposition has got itself in its attitude to these Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: One could be forgiven for thinking that there was primarily only one tax measure in this package, judging by the comments made so far. They have tended to concentrate on the effect of restaurants of the abolition of tax deductibility of business lunches. However, I would point out that the Senate is dealing with six Bills together, five of them tax Bills and the other a social security Bill. They generally bring in some of the measures announced by the Government in the tax package in September, some other matters that were announced in the Budget in August, and several other less significant tax measures. Other parts of the tax package have already been passed, and other parts again will be in groups of Bills to be introduced next year to cover items such as the capital gains tax, negative gearing, and so forth.

In dealing with these six Bills, I will concentrate mainly on two of them, the Social Security (Poverty Traps Reduction) Bill and one aspect of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4). There are relatively few government speakers in this debate, although not because of any lack of commitment to these Bills by the Government. In fact, these measures are among those that find us most wholehearted in our support. There are Government members who would have spoken in this debate if more time were available, but we are being reasonable about the matter and not dragging the legislative program nearer to Christmas. Unfortunately, following my contribution to this debate there will be six Opposition speakers in a row before the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) will sum up the debate. Much of the debate from the Oppositions has been unnecessary. There has been a lot of repetition, and some strident comments by speaker after speaker on one aspect of the tax package-that is, the business lunch.

Before I get onto that issue in order to answer some of the assertions that have been made by the Opposition, let me deal with the Social Security (Poverty Traps Reduction) Bill, which was announced with other tax measures on 19 September by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). The proposals alleviate some of the problems caused by poverty traps and this is done in the overall tax context. People on pensions and benefits in certain parts of the income scale can be affected both by income tests on their benefits or pensions and by taxability, and they gain relatively small net amounts from increased amounts of income. So the separate income test on rent assistance is to be removed, and that will be of great benefit to something like a million Australians.

Senator Peter Baume in his comments on this Bill said: `Yes, that is a good thing, but the Government is doing nothing about the other two poverty traps'. I acknowledge that despite the changes there will still be a trap affecting people higher up the income scale, but that hardly means that the Government is doing nothing about it. We have not said that we are abolishing poverty traps, as much as we might like to do that. But we are alleviating the poverty traps and ensuring that they are at a level of income at which they are of less significance. It is not as if Senator Baume came up with any solutions on this matter. He knows the difficulty of actually abolishing poverty traps because of the problems of the fading in and fading out of benefits. That is especially a problem, as we all know, with respect to entitlement to fringe benefits. There is, if you like, an absolute poverty trap at the point at which people with one extra dollar of income lose benefits which are of much greater value to them than that dollar, although, of course sometimes people penalise themselves unreasonably by attributing greater value to those fringe benefits than they really have.

To answer Senator Baume, who pointed out that these poverty trap alleviation measures will not take effect until the end of next year, I point out that because they are part of the tax package they will take effect at the time that the tax rate changes come in. All these measures are linked and are designed to come into effect towards the end of next year. I would have preferred these charges to have come in earlier, but let me point out that it is the Opposition that insists on there being less expenditure by this Government and not more. Yet people such as Senator Baume come up with suggestions which would, if implemented, affect this year's deficit. While he accuses the Government, because of that time lag, of not having compassion, I point out that the Government of which he was a member for seven years did nothing about this problem at all. Senator Baume pointed to some other tax decisions which do take effect from the date of announcement but again, as he would well know, some measures have to take effect from the date of announcement because if they did not they would distort all sorts of investment decisions and other aspects of the economy by virtue of the fact that people actually had notice of them.

I again refer briefly to the problem of the income test taper in the Social Security Act. Poverty traps exist because the taper comes into operation at a level of 50 per cent, but that is a reasonable percentage at which to withdraw benefits when other income is earned. If, for instance, the taper came in at the reduced level of, say, 25 per cent in order that the withdrawal plus the tax effect was smaller and therefore not an effective poverty trap, that would mean that the income level at which a part pension was still payable would be double what it is at present. We would have people still being entitled to a part pension when they were earning something like $400, $500 or $600 a week. It would ensure that we would be including many people who did not need such a part pension. So there are definitely pros and cons in this argument about the pension income test taper. I indicate my support for the Government's action in alleviating poverty traps and congratulate the Minister for Social Security, Brian Howe, for winning these very significant benefits for those particularly affected in this area.

I now turn to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), which deals with something like 15 or 20 different changes to the Income Tax Assessment Act, in particular the measure which requires substantiation of employment related expenses as from 1 July next year and even more importantly denies income tax deductions for entertainment expenses incurred after 19 September 1985. This is the aspect of the tax package which seems to have stirred up the Opposition most of all. In some ways Opposition members are even more upset about this than they are about the capital gains tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill doesn't cover capital gains tax.
—I know it does not implement the capital gains tax.
—We are not debating it because the Bill does not cover it.

—I am not talking only about this debate this afternoon; I am talking about the Opposition's general attitude to the tax package. I merely point out that perhaps Opposition members acknowledge that the capital gains tax proposal is so mild that they have very little with which to argue.
