Clause 8 (Application).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 5, at the end of clause 8, add the following new sub-clause:
`(2) The amendments made by sections 3, 6 and 7 do not apply to instruments executed before the date of commencement of this section.'.

This amendment and other amendments that will be moved to another Bill relate to the point I made this morning as to the belief that the Australian Capital Territory Stamp Duty Act as drawn is possibly-unintentionally, I hasten to reassert-retrospective in its operation. This amendment and the others which have been circulated in relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1985 need to be made in this way to make certain that the legislation is not capable of being interpreted as being retrospective in its operation. This morning I incorporated a paper submitted by the Law Council of Australia in support of this proposition. Perhaps the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) would care to respond to the proposal at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the amendment, for no particular reason except that we think it is redundant. Both the Bill and the amendment share these words: `The amendments made by sections 3, 6 and 7' and there they diverge. The Bill states: ` . . . apply to instruments executed on or after the date of commencement of this section'. Senator Reid's amendment states: ` . . . do not apply to instruments executed before the date of commencement of this section'. I suppose there is a trivial difference but, in fact, it is really a difference of words because in neither case can the amendments apply until the instruments have been executed. In the original Bill the words are `on or after' the date of commencement and in Senator Reid's amendment it is stated that the amendments cannot be executed `before the date of commencement of this section'. We will not go to the barricades on it. I think it is quite superfluous.
—We agree with you.

—There is a considerable body of legal opinion-lawyers who deal in this particular area have expressed this view to us-that the Bill, as it is presently drawn, is capable of being construed retrospectively. I am heartened to hear the Minister say that the amendment is redundant. It is certainly not the wish of the Opposition to hold up the Bill; the amendment has not been brought forward with a view to holding up the bringing into effect of the Bill. The Minister gave an assurance that the amendment is redundant. It would be helpful if the Minister gave an undertaking that if it became apparent at any time that there was any likelihood of its being interpreted in a way which meant that it was retrospective, the necessary legislation would be brought in to clarify the situation. Certainly, moving the amendment is not intended to delay the Bill as a whole. We would like an assurance that, if necessary, the amendment moved would be introduced if it became apparent that the legislation was being interpreted as some fear it will be. I think that would be of value.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just checked with officials from the Australian Taxation Office. They have confirmed my understanding that the Bill-the Act as it will become-will become operative on the first day of the month following the royal assent. That refers to all sections of the Act apart from section 5, which apparently is different. Clause 2 (2) of the Bill states that section 5 of the Act shall be deemed to have come into operation on 1 July 1969. Clause 2 (1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this Act shall come into operation on the first day of the month next following the month in which it receives the Royal Assent.

Given that, in my layman's opinion, which has been confirmed by the Taxation Office officials, section 8 is wholly prospective. It will come into operation, assuming the Bill gets the royal assent within a week or so, on 1 January 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not persist with the amendment. I hope it will not be necessary for the matter to be raised again. I think it was better to raise it now, however, and present the proposition rather than run the risk of problems occurring. I seek leave to withdraw the amendment circulated in my name.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment-by leave-withdrawn.
Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1985
Clauses 1 to 7-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 8.

TALK.START.PARA: —The circulated Opposition amendments to this Bill flow from the same proposition as I put previously. The arguments are the same as the arguments I used in relation to the Australian Capital Territory Stamp Duty Amendment Bill 1985. I ask whether the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) will give the same assurance in relation to this Bill.
—I am not sure whether Senator Reid has moved those amendments formally, but my advice is that this is different from her previous withdrawn amendment to clause 8.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 9, clause 8, proposed new sub-section 58P (2), at the end of the sub-section, add the following words:
`or was executed before the date of commencement of this section.'.

(2) Page 10, clause 8, proposed new sub-section 58R (1), lines 1 and 2, leave out all words after ``debentures'' (last occurring), insert `issued in respect of any amount subscribed for in the Territory shall be deemed to be duly stamped and any such debentures issued in respect of any amount subscribed for outside the Territory shall not, subject to sub-section (6), be liable to duty under this Division.'.

(3) Page 10, clause 8, proposed new paragraph 58R (2) (a), lines 9 and 10, leave out `issued during that month and are connected with the Territory', insert `subscribed for in the Territory during that month'.

(4) Page 10, clause 8, proposed new paragraph 58R (2) (b), lines 14 and 15, leave out `issued during that month and are connected with the Territory', insert `subscribed for in the Territory during that month'.

(5) Page 10, clause 8, proposed new paragraph 58R (2) (c), lines 19 and 20, leave out `issued during that month and are connected with the Territory', insert `subscribed for in the Territory during that month'.
(6) Page 10, clause 8, at the end of proposed new section 58R , add the following new sub-section:

`(6) Where a person resident or domiciled in the Territory becomes the holder of a debenture referred to in sub-section (1) which was subscribed for outside the Territory, that person is liable, on the day on which he becomes the holder of the debenture, to duty, as duty on a loan security, for an amount equal to the duty payable on a loan security for the amount to be repaid under the debenture except where ad valorem stamp duty has been paid or is payable in a State or another Territory in respect of the issue of, or subscription for, the debenture.'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first proposal would free from stamp duty liability a collateral security executed after the commencement of the amendments, even though it is collateral to a primary security that was executed before the commencement date and so has not borne duty. It is true that the legislation provides that collateral securities are not ordinarily liable to duty but that is on the basis that duty would ordinarily have been paid on the primary security. The aim is to avoid the imposition of double duty, not to free collateral securities from duty regardless of the circumstances. Subjecting collateral securities to duty where the primary security has not been so subject is consistent with the treatment of collateral securities in New South Wales and is the right, proper and intended outcome. In all these Australian Capital Territory charges the intended outcome was to apply either the identical or comparable tax laws of New South Wales in the Territory. Therefore, the Government opposes that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments (2) to (6) apparently reflect the Law Council of Australia's suggestion that the option to pay duty by a monthly return procedure in the case of corporate debenture issues should provide for a more effective territorial connection and make it clear that a credit is available for duty paid in other jurisdictions. The proposition is of a complex technical nature and the Government has not yet had sufficient time to have the points examined in detail, the Law Council's submission having been made available to officials only last week. In the circumstances, the Government is clearly unable to accept the amendments now under consideration merely on the basis that the Law Council thinks they are a good idea, and the issues raised are not of such significance that the Government could consider not proceeding with the legislation in its present form. Nevertheless, the issues will be examined further and any appropriate action taken.

The purpose of foreshadowed amendment (7) appears to be twofold: First, to ensure that a loan security executed before the legislation comes into operation does not have to be lodged for assessment of stamp duty; second, to ensure that a loan security executed before that date does not attract duty. The Government's view is that the amendment is not necessary. It is only those securities on which stamp duty is imposed that have to be lodged for assessment and the application provision for the Australian Capital Territory Stamp Duty Amendment Bill makes it clear that the only securities on which stamp duty is imposed are those executed on or after the date the Bill becomes law. Therefore, the Government opposes that amendment. In short, the Government is opposed to amendments (1) and (7) and, if I can draw this subtle distinction, it will not support amendments (2) to (6) but gives an undertaking to examine the technical points raised to see whether any subsequent review is justified.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note the words of the Minister that these matters will be looked into by the Government. I understand that in New South Wales the proposition works in reverse. It is for that reason that this matter has come forward. I accept the Minister's undertaking. I would like him perhaps to give an indication that a statement will be made by him on the matter early in the next session. If he would do that I would seek leave to withdraw those amendments and await the Government's response to these matters.
—The Australian Democrats had a look at the amendments moved by Senator Reid but we felt no real concern about the matter she was raising; so we will not be supporting those amendments.

—I still ask the Government to adhere to the undertaking the Minister gave because it is a matter of concern. The principle behind the original Australian Capital Territory Stamp Duty Act and this Bill is that the Government is bringing the Australian Capital Territory into line with other States and, although it did not name New South Wales, the legislation clearly is based on the New South Wales legislation. It is on that basis that this set of amendments is drawn. The Bill seeks to bring us more into line with New South Wales, but it goes further than that in that we will be paying duty while not getting any of the concessions. I mentioned two other matters this morning in relation to which I have not brought forward amendments. A person who surrenders a lease for any reason, perhaps for a change of purposes clause or for a consolidation of several leases, may have to discharge the mortgage to allow a new lease to be issued and then get a new mortgage, which in fact involves the same amount but a different document. In New South Wales one can do this by having the change noted, without being charged twice. I believe that it would be possible to effect this change by an amendment to the Real Property Ordinance. I ask the Minister to undertake also to have that concession which operates in New South Wales brought into effect here. I have not brought forward any amendment in relation to that; I would just like the Minister to undertake that that would also be examined.

—I will undertake an examination of the last matter that Senator Reid raised. If I could just say something about amendments Nos (2) to (6), I gather that the fear, or suspicion, expressed by the Law Society of the Australia Capital Territory is that there is a possibility of double taxation being applied in both the Territory and in New South Wales. As I said earlier, even the professionals say it is a complex technical question. Senator Reid asked for an assurance that the Government would make a statement. I cannot absolutely commit the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to making a statement-it is his responsibility and not mine-but I am advised by the officials that prior to the Act, which we expect it to be soon, becoming operative on 1 January, the Australian Taxation Office expects that the question that Senator Reid has raised could be examined and a statement made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to withdraw the amendments presently under discussion and in doing so accept the Minister's undertaking.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments-by leave-withdrawn.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 9 (Application).
Amendment (by Senator Reid) negatived:
(7) Page 12, at the end of clause 9, add the following new sub-clause:
`(2) Nothing in the amendments made by section 8 shall be taken-
(a) to require an instrument of loan security executed before the date of commencement of that section to be lodged with the Commissioner for assessment; or
(b) to make liable to duty any loan security executed before the date of commencement of that section.'.
Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address a few remarks to clauses 22 and 41 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1985. These clauses deal with the change in the exemptions being made for taxation relative to the Australian film industry. Clause 22 deals with the exemption of certain film income and clause 41 deals with deductions from certain withdrawals from film accounts. Honourable senators will recall that the deduction arrangements for the Australian film industry were introduced some years ago by the Fraser Government. That Government provided concessions on what was known as the 150:50 rule. This was later changed to 133:33 and it is now being changed again to 120:20. That is to say that there will be a deduction of 120 per cent for investment in the film industry and that the first 20 per cent of the profits of the film concerned-once it has been produced, granted a provisional certificate and then a final certificate, has been released and has started to make money-will be exempt from taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: Over a number of years the Government has been progressively reducing the financial support given by way of taxation concessions to the film industry. I believe that this is the correct step to take. This industry has greatly profited from having the original 150 per cent concession introduced. That concession helped to restore the viability of the Australian film industry at a particularly critical time in its history. Since then it has had the opportunity to stand on its own feet and, rather than the whole of the taxation concession being withdrawn in one go, it has been progressively phased down from the 150:50 level to the 120:20 level proposed in this legislation.

Nevertheless one should not think that the change in the arrangement will not have some impact on the film industry. In simple terms the effect of these changes will be to increase the investor's margin of risk after tax from 20 per cent to 28 per cent, assuming a 60 per cent marginal tax rate and 100 per cent eligibility. In practice the level of pre-tax return required to bridge the after-tax margin of risk will be greater because a proportion of the bridging return will now be taxable. The prima facie effect of the reduction is to put upward pressure on pre-sales requirements. This will lead to a downturn in the level of fund raising to the extent that such pre-sale requirements will be unable to be met, and ultimately to a downturn in production activity. While production activity as a whole will be affected by this change, perhaps more seriously, from the point of view of the film industry, there will be a further regrettable decline in the provision of money for experimental film makers. This Bill has the effect of increasing pressure on film makers to make purely commercial films. That may or may not be a good thing. I think that a commercial discipline needs to be applied to the Australian film industry, but I believe that the pressure that will be put on young and experimental film makers will not be in the best long term interests of the film industry as a whole.

Under the new concession a pre-sale guarantee of up to a figure of around 68 per cent may be needed and it is extremely difficult to get such pre-sale guarantees, particularly in the film industry in Australia at the moment, as it is running out of steam somewhat and, indeed, running out of a degree of creativity which was previously around. Pat Lovell, the producer of such films as Picnic at Hanging Rock and Gallipoli, has recently lamented the fact that money will be harder to find for high quality film production. I think there is a real danger that the effect of this will be to depress further the quality of the film industry and, in particular, to increase the pressure on film makers to make films for television showing rather than theatrical distribution. I think that is a great shame because television films do not have the same long term investment in the Australian film industry that theatrical release films do. It is true however-the Government is to be congratulated for this-that Division 10BA will still remain virtually the only tax shelter in the Income Tax Assessment Act available to individual taxpayers. Certainly, it also ought to be conceded that the concession given under Division 10BA is probably the most generous film tax concession given anywhere in the world.

I regret to say that we will continue to see the end of year financial rush. I noted in the Australian Financial Review of 25 June this year that it was anticipated that as much as $75m might be raised for investment in the film industry in the course of the last few weeks rush because the money has to be invested before the end of the financial year in order to fit in with the legislation. It turns out, when we look at the report which was given in the 26 September to 9 October issue of the authoritative film magazine Encore, that somewhere between $100m and $130m may well have been committed to the production of films in order to obtain the most generous level of taxation concessions.

I think it is important to understand that some steam has been going out of the Australian film industry. Last year Australia released only 15 major feature films not one of which, it is my understanding, actually made any money, and I think that is regrettable. While the Division 10BA tax concessions were set up by the Government to give power back to individual film makers, the irony of the whole thing is that it has put a lot of the decisions into the hands of accountants and into the hands of those in the boardrooms. I must say-I have no doubt that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) would agree with me-that there are still a large number of people in the film industry who are less than entirely reputable investors and operators and I think it is a pity that they continue to prosper in the way that they are. The way in which they prosper and take money out of the industry is harming the long term viability of the industry.

There are only a couple of other very quick points that I want to make. One is that I think it is to be regretted that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation has not played a more constructive role in the production of Australian feature films. Secondly, I very much welcome the announcement made quite recently by the Australian Film Commission that it has established a co-productions program to permit up to seven international co-productions per annum for a trial two-year period beginning 1 January 1986. Provided the co-productions have a majority of Australian participation and financial equity of not less than 40 per cent from Australian sources that will be a step in the right direction. The final point is that I think the film industry needs seriously to address the question of continued investment in the script side of the industry. Australian films still suffer, to a very large extent, from a failure to produce enough creative writers to produce scripts which are of sufficient quality. One very much regrets-although it must be a subjective judgment-that a film which was as technically and artistically satisfying and pleasing as Burke and Wills was nevertheless marred by a very second-rate script.

Finally, I drew attention to the fact that in the recently released report of the National Film and Sound Archive Advisory Committee-a most excellent report which was brought into the Senate last week-a number of recommendations are made regarding deposit arrangements in Australian film archives. The Advisory Committee, after discussing legislation which is in place in other countries dealing with the mandatory deposit of published moving images and sound recordings in a designated public archive, has ended up recording that instead of a mandatory system the Archive should continue to utilise, codify and extend comprehensive voluntary mechanisms for the deposit by donation of the national production in the Archive collection and that their effectiveness be kept under periodic review by the Collections Policy Advisory Panel.

I hope that all Australian film makers will be depositing in the National Film and Sound Archive at least two copies-one a negative copy and one a release copy-of any film that is produced and that they will also be depositing in the Archive a final script and a finalised cast list. However, I think that the Government has the right and should have taken the opportunity to require the mandatory deposit of films in the National Archive. After all, I think that the makers of those films which are made using public moneys by way of taxation concessions do, in fact, have an obligation to assist in the building up of the national collection. I would very much have supported a move by this Government at this stage to include as one of the terms and conditions of the continuation of this very generous film tax concession the requirement for mandatory deposit of the various parts of the final production with the National Film and Sound Archive.

On behalf of the Opposition, I say that we welcome the continuing investment which is going on in the film industry. We are grateful that the Government has not withdrawn the support entirely. Changes will occur as a result of the amendment to the legislation, including the introduction of what amounts to an incentive for the 120-20 investors to defer film income until the beginning of 1987-88, when the new 49 per cent marginal tax rate becomes applicable, or at least until September 1986, when the 55 per cent rate becomes applicable. This change will have some quite profound impact on the future shape and direction of the Australian film industry, but I believe it correct and proper that the concession should be wound down over a period. I hope that serious investors in the Australian film industry will continue to make use of this extremely generous concession.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to several clauses relating to four particular matters. I start with petroleum and general mining group loss transfers, to which clauses 24, 25, 29, 31 and 35 refer. I can see no disadvantage to anyone in this sensible arrangement which, in fact, will cost the Government $70m next year and, I think, $65m the year after. My slight reservation is that I am concerned that in the arrangements involved which permit the transfer of losses within a company group-this enhances that capacity-there is an occasional difficulty, as I remember it, with those companies which are not 100 per cent owned as a result of difficulties involved in getting outstanding minority shareholders off their share registers as a result of failures of takeover bids to totally wipe out a distant shareholder or where there are estate problems. I think there are some instances of one per cent or 2 per cent shareholdings in such companies denying them the benefit, as I recall it, of the transfer of losses within a company group.

SPEECH.PARA: The principle established here is a very sound one. It is a principle which the Government has totally rejected in relation to farmers. Yet it happily grants it in relation to big business. I happen to be in favour of the businesses involved having this principle applied to them, but it is quaint that the Government accepts the principle here but denies it to farmers, to whom the quarantining of losses is applied so that these kinds of transfers, when they apply to the man on the land, are not permitted to take place. What an extraordinary moral position. The Government is looking at a farming community which is in trouble, which has basic problems, stemming largely from the Government's own anti-rural policies. The Government applies a friendly approach to the transfer of losses within mining and oil companies-I am glad that it does-but it refuses to apply exactly the same principle to the man on the land. I hope that the rural voters of Australia keep that very much in mind.

The next clause I want to refer to is clause 38, which relates to the rebate for moneys paid on petroleum mining shares. This rebate has been very little used and it seems reasonable that the Government should take this action. It has been taken in conjunction with the removal of tax deductibility of calls on afforestation shares. That is referred to in clauses 19, 26, 27 and 28. Together these two changes, which apply from 20 September 1985, will collect an extra $10m, I think, next year and $15m the year after. Those are not very substantial amounts. However, when the removal of calls on afforestation shares is taken in conjunction with the quarantining of losses one gets a serious assault on the forestry industry which will be damaging, if not destructive, to that industry. Many people may say: `Good thing; it has been a ramp'. For example, the Minister is overjoyed to see every bit of rural activity which has received some stimulus as simply a ramp. If governments seek to encourage activity by providing tax benefits it is only reasonable that those people who follow the rules at the time should expect those rules to persist throughout the time of the arrangement that they entered into.

Even this Government recognises that trees take many years to grow-25 years or even longer. Certainly hardwood plantations take much longer before they will provide an adequate return. Yet the Government is once again changing the rules in mid-stream. People have entered into obligations because an incentive was provided-sure it was by previous governments-to enter into that kind of obligation. It seems quite improper that governments can in the midst of a project like this change the rules not simply to disadvantage or to remove a special advantage that people have but to destroy the viability of the operation. The chamber has to recognise that, taken in conjunction with quarantining, the removal of one third of the calls on afforestation shares, in effect, destroys the viability of the great bulk of the forestry industry in Australia. It has an effective retrospective impact because people are already locked into long term developments.

What will happen to this industry now? Will people be able to afford to maintain the forests which are one-third, half or three-quarters developed but which will not be bringing in returns until they are thinned and timber is collected? The Government is now damaging the prospect of any future investors in Australia having any response whatsoever to any incentives any government may in the future seek to offer if it will involve some long term investment on which one would not get a return for a fair while and one which will have to depend on the continuation of that government incentive. If we are going to have in Australia a continual situation of an incentive being provided and later taken away before the project is completed, and when the Government is perfectly aware of the fact that it takes a long time for that project to be completed, private investors should not trust any government, particularly a Labor one. Even when the coalition is in office and we provide an incentive, the fear that one day there could be a Labor government may well be enough to discourage any sensible investor from putting his money in long term projects which are clearly in Australia's long term interests. This Government is clearly much more interested in the quick quid industries which do not take the same long term view.

As I have said, even though the amount of money involved in this matter is relatively small, taken in conjunction with quarantining it is massively destructive. The honest, decent and honourable way for this Government to operate if it wished to remove this incentive-it is certainly not the way it does operate-would be for it to remove it from any projects starting from 20 September 1985, if it is so attracted to 20 September. But to make it apply to those that are under development now is improper. It involves a misleading of the people concerned, and I suggest that it is destructive to an industry which is of great benefit to Australia.

Clause 40 relates to the prescribed payments system. It involves $105m in the first year, I think, and $45m in the second year, and it is to apply from 1 July 1986. I congratulate the Government on this matter. It is one of those on which it introduces the legislation before it takes effect. This is a change of pace for this Government. It is extraordinary. The Government is behaving decently for a change. A considerable number of items of legislation are introduced by this Government in a dishonest, improper and disgraceful manner. It involves the introduction of legislation six months after, in many cases, the non-existent law became operative. That is so in relation to the capital gains tax. We still do not know what the terms of the legislation are and yet people are being affected by it, sent broke by it, and have had to sell at losses as a result of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —They cannot plan.

—They certainly cannot plan. They have no idea what will be in the legislation, and, depending on what sort of deal is done with the Democrats, that legislation-which does not exist-under which they have had to operate can be subject to changes before it is introduced, anyway. It is a most extraordinary and improper situation. We wonder what further deals the Labor Party will be obliged to do with the Democrats in the interim before this legislation comes up. Who knows? There may be other bits of legislation that the Government wants to sneak through, such as the petroleum legislation, on which it is keen to do any kind of deal that it can to buy a Democrat vote. We do not know what that legislation will be like, yet it has been operative since 20 September.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the prescribed payments system will apply from 1 July 1986-and what a pleasant change that is. However, I simply say on that matter that the recent report of the Commissioner of Taxation outlines problems with the prescribed payments system, particularly with people who are claiming rebates. For a variety of reasons, I think, the Commissioner takes the view that some people are not filling in forms properly. It may well be that it is another example of where the enormous pressures on the Department as a result of the expansion of activities, such as this collection of so-called reforms, have meant that the Department is short of skilled workers. That lack of skill in the Department is dealt with in the annual report, where reference is made to how difficult it is to get people with experience. What intrigues me is to see that in the Forward Estimates of March of this year, I think, the Government indicated that the number of people in the Australian Taxation Office would increase substantially over the next two years. All of a sudden we found in the Forward Estimates published last month that that increase will not now take place. The Forward Estimates show, for example, a fall of 100 in employment in the Taxation Office next year, and in the year after that there is to be a reduction of about 6 per cent-because the numbers will remain steady-from the original Forward Estimates of the number of people to be employed in the Taxation Office.

How on earth will the Taxation Office cope with this additional work when its numbers are being held down by this Government? I am not saying that I want to see a great expansion in the numbers in the Taxation Office. I do not want to see this enormous additional burden of work imposed on the Taxation Office. Many of the provisions of these taxation Bills, which are a pay-off to the Australian Council of Trade Unions, have no right to exist. But the Taxation Office has apparently been stabbed in the back by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), because the additional numbers needed-and clearly needed in view of the muck-up in the prescribed payments system-to handle the additional work are not to be provided, if one can take any notice of the Forward Estimates produced last month. As I said, those Forward Estimates involve a massive revision downwards from the Forward Estimates that came out in May relating to the Taxation Office.

Overall, while not opposing these matters in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No 3), I say that there is no doubt that they indicate a lack of understanding by the Government of individual matters such as the impact on the forestry industry-the major impact comes from the quarantining provisions-and a certain lack of understanding in general of the proper requirements of the right way to conduct taxation legislation, which is to introduce legislation before it is operative. For members of the Government to pretend that they are simply following the lead of the previous Government is to delude themselves and to seek to deceive the Australian people. In every instance when the previous Government said that legislation would operate from the date of announcement, it was to close loopholes in existing legislation, the policy of which was clearly stated. It did not involve massive changes of direction.

I remind the yawning Minister opposite, who obviously finds the matter of morals in the tax issue too much to handle, that when the previous Government sought to change basic principles of tax in 1981 it gave, in effect, six months notice. It introduced changes which involved the extending of tax to the so-called essentials, which the Australian Democrats chose to oppose, and gave the Senate the opportunity to defeat it, which it did, before the due date of operation. I just say in passing how quaint it was that the Democrats and the Australian Labor Party could take the view that clothing and footwear were essentials when they were parties to arrangements involving tariffs which imposed something like a 100 per cent tax on those items.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first meaningful section of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) which speaks of the disallowance of entertainment expenses for tax purposes, which is the main thrust of this legislation. I merely say that the Opposition will be opposing this clause, which refers to in-house dining facilities as it is part and parcel of the further substantive amendment that we will be moving in respect of clause 9. I hope that other senators will involve themselves at that stage of the debate on the substantive issues of the Bill.
—On behalf of the Australian Democrats I indicate that we will be opposing the Opposition's stand on this clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not be following my Party colleagues in this matter. I do not believe that there is such a thing as a free lunch. I believe that the so-called entertainment tax is a tax which falls disproportionately on small business. It is a tax on the hospitality industry; it is a tax which falls, to a larger extent, on the ethnic community, the restaurateurs, the taxi drivers and the small traders of this country. It is a tax which falls more heavily on these who are prepared to `give it a go,' to work irregular hours, to split shifts, to work on weekends and still be happy to work hard to make other people happy. In other words, it is a bad tax.

SPEECH.PARA: I will support the Opposition's stand on in-house dinners. I wish to stop the rorts which are currently going on in these areas but still allow proper deductions for expenses incurred when they are necessary to earning an income.

In 1983-84 the hospitality industry represented 4 per cent of gross domestic product and 7 per cent of total employment. The end result of the entertainment tax may be that many of the most successful, best value restaurants will be forced out of business, causing considerable personal pressure on restaurant owners and an overall decline in Australia's hospitality industry. A progressive phasing-in of the tax, which we suggested to the Government, would have gone a long way to allowing business to adjust to the effects of this tax and would have avoided the drastic effects which are now being felt in the restaurant, hotel and catering industry generally. We tried to negotiate this.

The Government has pressed its argument that a public subsidy through the tax system for the hospitality industry is contrary to the notions of equity in the tax system and that the entertainment allowance is a benefit enjoyed by a small number of privileged people. However, those abusing the system are not the only people who will be affected by this change. The effects of the tax will spread much more widely and in my belief these effects have not been properly taken into account by the Government. The tax will impact on the tourist industry, which in the year to June 1985 earned $1.5 billion in foreign exchange. It will flow on to all the other small businesses which support the hospitality industry. For example, the wine industry, already weakened by the tax on wines and wine stocks depends mainly on the restaurants for sale of its high quality, specialty wines. This will have a particular bad effect in my State. This industry has already experienced a 35 per cent fall in bottled wine sales since September. The laundry industry, which is another small, family-based industry, will also be badly affected. The taxi industry-as the cost of taxi travel to and from restaurants is no longer deductible-will also be affected. We could go on and on.

The anticipated decline in business resulting from the entertainment tax since September 1985 is as follows: In the seafood industry there is an 11 per cent decrease; the meat and poultry industry, 6 per cent; vegetables, 6 per cent; dairy produce, 3 per cent; laundry, 16 per cent; advertising, 17 per cent; wine, 9 per cent; and beer, 8 per cent. It will decrease employment overall within the community. The effects are already being felt, although Christmas is delaying the real impact. American Express reports a 30.6 per cent decline in card member revenue for October in the restaurant trade, and it has 6,500 members. The hospitality industry represents 7 per cent of total employment according to the 1983-84 Australian Bureau of Statistics' figures. The hospitality industry is one of the leading groups in the creation of new jobs. Last month 4,000 new jobs were created, which explains Senator Bolkus's problem with the CES figures. The opening of both the Intercontinental Hotel and the Jupiter Casino helped this job creation. I believe that we will hit the real problems after Christmas.

The hospitality industry receives no subsidy from the taxpayer, although it is the backbone of our tourist industry which is a $1.5 billion export industry. One of our major earners of foreign exchange is the tourist industry. We must contrast this with the motor trade which is subsidised by taxpayers to the tune of nearly $15,000 per employee, yet it exports very little. I believe that the Government should be looking at where its money is spent. From the Government's point of view, the cost of collecting this tax is likely to be more than it has estimated, and the returns much less. One estimate is given in the executive summary of the BIS-Shrapnel Pty Ltd report. I seek leave to incorporate that executive summary in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
THE ECONOMIC IMPACT OF DISALLOWING BUSINESS ENTERTAINMENT EXPENSES AS TAX DEDUCTIONS
Executive Summary

BIS-Shrapnel Pty Ltd were commissioned by the Australian Tourism Industry Association to undertake a study to identify the likely economic costs of the Government's decision to disallow all `business entertainment' expenses as tax deductions.
Using the Impact Project Input-Output model of the Australian economy it was estimated that the effects of the measure would be to:
Reduce GDP by $434 million
Reduce employment in the economy by 18,600 persons
Reduce employment in the hospitality industry by 11,100 persons.
Further, the net gain to Government revenue would be only $79 million and not $310 million as estimated by the Government.

Business entertainment has long been widely recognised as a legitimate business expense. It has been seen as being a very effective marketing tool. In the past, business entertainment has played a vital role in the sale of goods and services, the gathering and dissemination of information, and the development and maintenance of business and professional relationships. Both the magnitude and distributional impact of the economic costs of disallowing business entertainment expenses as tax deductions will be partly determined by the legitimacy and importance of business entertainment in conducting business transactions. If the Treasurer has under-estimated the legitimacy and importance of business entertainment, it would seem reasonable to conclude that he has also under-estimated the full costs of disallowing business enertainment expenses as tax deductions.
The non-quantifiable costs of the Government's measure include an adverse impact on economic efficiency.

The sectors of the economy to be most severely affected by the Government's action include the hospitality industry and `supplier industries' to the hospitality industry.* Additionally, the disallowance of business entertainment expenses as tax deductions will particularly disadvantage those firms which rely extensively on this form of marketing. This would include many small businesses and firms competing in export industries.

Total disallowance of business entertainment expenses as tax deductions on the grounds of `excessive' administrative costs must be evaluated on the basis of whether the costs imposed on society by this measure are less than the costs of administering an alternate sysem which could distinguish between legitimate expenses and abuses. The substantial magnitude of the probable economic costs to total disallowance of business entertainment expenses identified by BIS-Shrapnel in this study, would strongly suggest that a re-consideration by the Government of alternate systems would be appropriate.
* The `Hospitality Industry' refers to Restaurants, Hotels and Clubs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has stated that no employer will be exempt from this tax except churches. Yet the Federal and State public services are not now assessable by the Australian Taxation Office, nor are many other exempt employers such as schools and charitable bodies. These people will need to put in taxation forms and this will cause an enormous extra load on the Taxation Office. The concept of collecting taxes from such bodies and paying them back out of the taxpayers' purse to cover the cost is, I believe, laughable. It cannot be justified. It is an administrative nightmare.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a lack of precise detail in the legislation. I take just one example-entertainment is not defined. There is no rationale for having a commencement date of 20 September 1985. It is not an issue like everybody rushing to buy liquor or something else that will be taxed at a later date, as with sales tax laws. The Taxation Board of Review has already a substantial backlog and these clauses will add to it. I believe that this tax is much more of a problem than it is worth in revenue. Thus the tax can be considered only to be a tax on business-on small business at that. The tax will bite hard long before there is any tax relief, as the Government claims. The flow-on of extra money into the economy will happen only a long time after the restaurants have been hit and possibly gone bankrupt. It is meaningless to consider that future tax relief will alleviate in any way the effects of this tax.

The Taxation Office already has the right to collect tax from employees on benefits that they derive from their employers. The Taxation Office is not doing that. The reason is that the cost of collecting such taxes is much more than can be returned. I believe that this tax is all wrong. This situation will not be changed by moving the burden onto the employers, where already multitudinous schemes are arranged for disguising entertainment under other categories of allowable deductions. This, indeed, will be a very costly tax to administer. Already most large companies provide subsidised canteen facilities for their employees. They will be able to entertain as before, without any accounting entry distinguishing entertainment from normal running expenses. There is absolutely no way that the terms of this clause can be policed. We have no answers from the Government, and we have asked the Government for answers.

It is the small businesses which depend on the restaurants to provide entertainment facilties which they cannot justify supporting permanently within their organisations that will be hit. It is actually a cost-effective method of doing business-to use restaurants as catering facilities. In this area the provisions of the next clause will bite. Thus small businesses will find it much more difficult to compete with large corporations in the marketing of their goods and services. Such small businesses are, in fact, the major employer group in Australia.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Overseas Aid Program-Retirement of Mr Des Smith-Aboriginal Children: Education-Centre for the Intellectually Handicapped, Geelong

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to use the opportunity afforded by this adjournment debate to comment further on the text of a statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) which was made in the House of Representatives on 28 November 1985 and which concerned Australia's overseas aid program. Debates in this chamber on foreign aid issues are relatively infrequent because of their largely bipartisan nature. In fact the Public Accounts Committee report No. 201 on an efficiency audit of the administration of bilateral overseas aid recommended that the Minister for Foreign Affairs make a policy statement to the Parliament on overseas aid annually. I know that the statement was a response to a report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and to the report of the Jackson Committee to Review Australia's Overseas Aid Program. It is pleasing to have this document before the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's aid program is really a very complex network of elements which are designed to bring assistance to the Third World and to bring international credit to Australia. I think the statement recognises that Australia is a developed country in a region which is notable for high levels of poverty and related problems where many economies have been inhibited by inadequate standards of infrastructure and a shortage of administrative skills. Unfortunately aid alone will not answer all the problems, but at least it can point the way by feeding the hungry, by treating the sick, by improving administrative skills or even by just enabling fruit and vegetable produce to reach particular markets.

The world's resources are distributed inequitably both internationally and within nations and societies, but social and political factors also exacerbate the problems which increase the gulfs between plenty and poverty. But assistance must be of such a nature that it will not perpetuate the present problems of gross inequity. In the relief of poverty, programs with the best of motives quite often exacerbate existing inequities and injustices rather than always alleviate them. Some programs in the past have often tended to serve a number of different and often incompatible purposes-for example, as diplomatic instruments for maintaining friendly relations, for countering influences from competing powers, and because of their usefulness to particular businesses-as well as responding to the needs of the poor and underprivileged.

Rich nations have an obligation to assist poor nations. Australia's aid program is very worthwhile, and the assistance generally has been of a very high standard. Despite Australia's own economic problems, I believe there is a great reservoir of support for the provision of aid and the principles of its distribution as laid down by successive Australian governments. Australians by nature are a generous people giving freely in specific appeals to alleviate suffering. Our region, the Pacific Basin, particularly the small island states of the Pacific, receives the most aid per capita in the world, although compared with other areas the need is often marginal. However, their small size and the fragile nature of the island economies of the South Pacific and the Indian Ocean render such aid as is given very necessary. The largest recipient of our aid is, of course, Papua New Guinea, and that will remain so in the foreseeable future. Also the Indian Ocean states are of strategic importance to Australia given the continuing dependence on Gulf oil and the sea lanes of communication with Western Europe.

Unfortunately the Jackson report on Australia's overseas aid did not adequately address the problems of confusion concerning the objectives of the current aid program. At times food aid can be a disincentive to local food production. An example of this is wheat aid to Egypt. Other African countries often have a greater need yet their allocations have been cut on a global basis.

A controversial and perhaps discredited view on education assistance is based on the trickle down theory that assistance should be given to those near the top of the educational pyramid. Unfortunately, while this theory might be right, the practicalities of human nature provide too many examples where unfortunately the reverse has been true. The aid distribution must avoid an inbuilt tendency for the benefits of aid to flow to the more powerful and more affluent in our community. Mr Hayden says that there is no reason why industry should not take part in our aid program so long as equity and effectiveness remain primary considerations and so long as this guiding principle is strictly observed.
In conclusion, I think it is pleasing that the Australian Development Assistance Bureau is being restructured to allow the delivery of aid to be carried out in a professional manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual in the last week of the Budget sittings of the Senate-or we hope it is-we have a rush of reports coming in for consideration of the Senate and time does not permit us to give them scrutiny. One report that is before the Senate is the annual report of the Australian National Railways Commission. A motion was moved that the Senate take note of the paper which means that it cannot be discussed now but will be brought on for debate some time in the future. The only remark I make about it is that it is very pleasing to see that Australian National Railways, which in the previous financial year made a loss of some $9m, this year shows a surplus on operation profit of $10m. That is a tremendous turnaround and the report warrants closer attention.

SPEECH.PARA: Looking at that report today reminded me that, as someone who to a degree represents the people of the outback, I should make some brief mention of Mr Des Smith. Mr Des Smith is an engineer with the Australian National Railways who, my notes tell me, has a reputation second to none within Australia and who is recognised overseas for his competence in planning, design and construction of new railways. Now that the standard gauge line from Tarcoola in South Australia to Alice Springs is completed-as I understand it, it is running economically-Des Smith has retired. The people of the outback, and indeed the people of Australia, certainly owe much to Des Smith because he has done much not only to develop the outback but also to bring railways into a more efficient operation than has been the case in the past.

Des Smith has worked in Australia on the Marree line in northern South Australian, the Port Augusta to Whyalla line, the Tarcoola to Alice Springs line and the proposed Alice Springs to Darwin line. He has also established himself as a recognised authority on the maintenance of railways in a desert environment. His services to the railway industry have been recognised by the Australian Government through an Imperial Service Order and an Australian award. He has also been honoured by an Aboriginal council with an award relating to the protection of sacred sites. This indicates the type of man that he is and that he has been able to get on with all people in the construction of these lines.

Des Smith joined the Commonwealth Railways on 3 October 1955 at Telford. He worked on construction of the standard gauge line to Marree. He became construction engineer in 1957 and completed construction of the track into Marree. In 1962 he was appointed maintenance engineer. This position covered the central Australian railway and the trans-Australian railway, some 3,100 kilometres of track. In the 1960s he was responsible for a 10-year rehabilitation program of the trans-Australian railway which involved the virtual rebuilding of 1,800 kilometres of track. In the early 1970s he planned and designed the Port Augusta to Tarcoola railway and the Tarcoola to Alice Springs railway. He was also responsible for the construction of the Tarcoola-Alice Springs track. He completed that project on time and within budget. After its completion he became civil engineer for the northern region and in November 1979 he became chief engineer in Adelaide for the Australian National Railways Commission. He was then placed on special duties to undertake the planning and design of the proposed Alice Springs-Darwin railway. This work was substantially completed in June 1984 when construction was deferred and funding withheld.

I make this commendation on behalf of the people of the north and the outback. They would wholeheartedly support the comments I have made and would thank Des Smith for the work he has done. Des Smith is a most unusual character. He is a real bushman. He built the enormous line from Tarcoola to Alice Springs. I understand that it is one of the longest railways that has been built for many decades. The railway is a most efficient link and standard gauge line. Many of us hope to see the continuation of Des Smith's work with the construction of the line from Alice Springs to Darwin. I guess that he has walked over every kilometre of the line from Tarcoola to Alice Springs. It is my guess that he has almost done so between Alice Springs and Darwin on the line that he has surveyed, graded and marked for future construction.

As I have indicated, it is quite a considerable achievement that Des has been able to work in conjunction with all the people of the outback. Station hands, railway gangers, pastoralists, Aborigines-all people-look upon Des Smith as their personal friend. He has that quality. Des has now retired from the construction of railways in Australia. It was he who designed the method of constructing modern railways in an efficient, mechanical operation which kept manual labour to a minimum. He was able to lay sections of line in this way, perhaps some 300 to 400 metres long. He was able to lay the concrete sleepers in Port Augusta mechanically. He was quite an incredible man. Senator Jessop and I have travelled with him on many occasions along the track through the bush. I hope that Australia will recognise the feat of this most remarkable man. We wish him all the best in his retirement.

I do not wish to hold the Senate long, but I feel that I must comment tonight on a matter that arose during Question Time. It related to the education of Aboriginal children in the outback, particularly the Northern Territory. It is not my wish to dwell on the remarks that were made today. I believe that they are too controversial. Frankly, it is time that controversy was taken out of Aboriginal affairs, particularly Aboriginal education. Aboriginal education in the outback is going ahead apace and it is tremendous to see young Aboriginal people in the various areas of education, whether it be in a primary school, a high school or in the teacher training college in Batchelor in the northern part of the Northern Territory. They are coming on well. There is a tremendous future for them in education. I believe it is a matter that we must take much more seriously. We must take the controversy, the political point scoring or whatever, away from Aboriginal education for I believe it does not do the Aboriginal children any justice; nor does it give them encouragement.

I was interested to see the other two Federal representatives of the Northern Territory, Senator Robertson and Paul Everingham, who is the member for the Northern Territory, both reported in the Press in the last two days indicating that while it is the nature of the beast that there be controversy between the Federal Government and State and Territory governments, there should be an endeavour to cut down on that controversy and not have it just for the sake of it for there is much to be done. I note there is to be an endeavour to bring about more liaison in carrying out these various developments quickly. I think it is necessary to assure people that Aboriginal education is going ahead. It certainly has difficulties, but they are not being ignored. We must look to these young Aboriginal people who are being educated now because many of them are going to be in the forefront of Aboriginal affairs in the future, and they are to be encouraged.

The total number of Aboriginal schools in the Northern Territory is now 82. This represents 52.6 per cent of the total number of schools in the Northern Territory. Aboriginal schools are defined as those with more than 50 per cent of the students being Aboriginal students. Of the 82 Aboriginal schools, 75 are government schools and seven are non-government schools, I think the liaison between the Federal Government and the Northern Territory Government is working well in the Aboriginal schools. Of course there are differences of opinion at times but by and large there is this liaison which is bringing about this result. Twenty schools at outstations are planned for construction in 1985-86. The Commonwealth Government will provide most of the funding for these. Four post-primary facilities are planned for 1985-86. However, negotiations are still being held with the Federal Government as that Government has said it will not provide funds for housing. This is a difficult point. If further negotiations do not resolve this, the Northern Territory Government will have to provide the necessary funding and the planned facilities may not all go ahead at the one time. Two further post-primary facilities are planned for 1986-87. In the last couple of years two Aboriginal schools have been upgraded. Five of the 82 schools were constructed during the last few years.

I have seen the senior Minister in the Senate tonight, the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), regarding having two letters incorporated. One is a memorandum from the honourable member for the Northern Territory, Paul Everingham, regarding the attacks by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) on Aboriginal education in the Northern Territory. This memorandum in effect gives information on that. The other is a letter addressed to Mr C. A. Blanchard, MP, Chairman of the Select Committee on Aboriginal Education, Parliament House. This letter was written by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, indicating his pleasure at having the opportunity of bringing before the Select Committee on Aboriginal Education matters relating to the Aboriginal people. I do not think it is necessary at this late hour to comment on those two letters because they are self-explanatory. I seek leave to have those two documents incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
27 November 1985
MEMORANDUM
To: All Senators and Members.
MINISTER FOR ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS ATTACKS ABORIGINAL EDUCATION IN THE NORTHERN TERRITORY
In the current financial year, the Northern Territory has sustained funding cutbacks of $60 million at the hands of the Federal Government.

Nevertheless, education in the Northern Territory gets 25% of the recurrent budget. As an economy measure this financial year, staffing of the Department of Education head office was cut back by 10%, and school staffing formulas are being enforced. Even so, 163 new positions were created to cater for expanded demand in urban and rural centres, and 43 new positions were specifically allocated for Aboriginal people. In the Northern Territory the staffing formula is applied across the board on a basis of average attendance +15%.
The Schools Commission found, two years ago, that the numbers of teaching and staffing positions in schools in Aboriginal communities in the Territory, is three times the national average.

Staffing of urban Territory schools is as good as any in Australia, and schools in Aboriginal communities are much better staffed than urban schools. Public service staff includes teaching assistants and other people involved in the bilingual program. Let me give some examples:
Shepherdson College, Galiwinku (Aboriginal Community)-Enrolment 235; Average Attendance 157; Teaching Service staff 17 (1:9.2); Public Service staff 13 (1:12).
Tennant Creek Primary School (Urban)-Enrolment 205; Average Attendance 174; Teaching Service staff 9 (1:19); Public Service staff 3 (1:58).
Sanderson Primary School (Urban)-Enrolment 280; Average Attendance 250; Teaching Service staff 14 (1:17); Public Service staff 3 (1:83).
Lajamanu (Aboriginal Community)-Enrolment 197; Average Attendance 140; Teaching Service staff 12 (1:12); Public Service staff 9 (1:15).
I attach a copy of a letter from Chief Minister Ian Tuxworth, to the Chairman of the Aboriginal Education Committee, which I think gives some background to the matter.
PAUL EVERINGHAM, M.P.
Member for the Northern Territory
13 September 1985
The Hon. C. A. Blanchard, M.P.
Chairman
Select Committee on Aboriginal Education
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Mr Blanchard
I refer to your letter of 23 August 1985 seeking clarification of a number of issues relating to Aboriginal Education in the Northern Territory.

While I appreciate that you have been contacted by a number of sources, I am pleased that you have raised the matter with me so that I may take the opportunity to put the record straight and to ensure that you receive accurate information, and not that based on self interest and misunderstanding.

There has not been a review of the staffing formula in Aboriginal schools in the Northern Territory. Rather, in line with all Government Departments and as a result of the reductions in funding provided by the Commonwealth, the Education Department has found it necessary to review its overall expenditure and to ensure that schools are staffed strictly according to formula.
Staffing entitlements are determined by a generous formula and the staffing formula for Aboriginal schools in the Northern Territory is the best in Australia.

The position of Principal at Lajamanu has been reclassified according to the level to which the school is entitled. This is determined by the operation of a formula which has been in use for a number of years. As a result in 1986 the school will be classified at the Band III level. According to the formula Lajamanu is in fact extremely close to becoming a Band II school.

Lajamanu school is currently staffed by one Band IV principal, one Band III assistant principal, two Band II senior teachers and four Band I teachers. Additional staff include a teacher held against a teacher librarians' position, a teacher linguist, six full time teacher assistants, four part time teacher assistants and three full time and two part time ancillary staff. The home liaison officer recently resigned. Overall the school has twice the number of staff which an urban school of similar attendance would have.

You must agree that for a school with an enrolment of 171 students but an attendance average of only 124 students that the staffing allocation for 1985 is very generous. You should also be aware that for a school to be entitled to a Band IV Principal an average attendance by at least 255 students is usually required. You should also be aware that the changes mooted will not take effect until 1986. If the attendance rate improves then staff entitlement will be reassessed.
In retaining the staff at the level accepted for a Band III school in 1986, the Northern Territory Government is more than adequately demonstrating its commitment to Aboriginal education.

With respect to Aboriginal assistant teachers, adjustments are being made because of enrolment fluctuations. Some schools with falling enrolments are losing staff while others will be gaining staff. There is no attempt being made to reduce the overall number of assistant teachers. Indeed, this is likely to increase as attendance rates improve.

I do not agree with your assertion that the RATE program will suffer. This program is currently conducted principally through the auspices of a lecturer who travels to the community from Batchelor College. This will continue.

The same situation applies to the Bilingual program. It is true that the number of linguists has been reduced by two-one of these positions having been vacant for some time. This means that new work may have to be staged but existing programs will not be prejudiced. The Bilingual Unit within the Department of Education has not been disbanded. The Bilingual program has been operating for several years and has been an outstanding success as was stated to you during your time in the Northern Territory. It is continuing to operate.

Overall, the Northern Territory Budget provides several major developments in Aboriginal education including provision for establishment grants for 43 Homeland Centres and the employment of the additional 43 assistant teachers. This is despite having had to absorb substantial reductions in Commonwealth funding.

I feel sure you will agree that this information clarifies the issues to which you have drawn my attention, and confirms previous policies as stated to your committee by the Northern Territory Department of Education.

Finally, I note with great disappointment that your government has again made only a token attempt to implement the recommendations of the CSC/NAEC report, `Funding Priorities in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education.' Officers in the Northern Territory spent a great deal of time and effort working with the Commonwealth on this report and once again the hopes of schools have not been realised. I trust your Committee will actively support the CSC/NAEC recommendations as they greatly benefit Northern Territory school children.
Yours sincerely,
I. TUXWORTH

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Finally, as a further indication of what is happening and how encouragement can be given by people of all walks of life-people in industry and what have you-I refer to a report in the Northern Territory News of 30 November 1985 entitled `Executive plan to help Aborigines'. It is about a plan for an executive training course designed exclusively for Aborigines. The scheme will take young Aboriginal people from all walks of life and train them to a level which it is hoped will make them acceptable as executives to government, private enterprise and Aboriginal organisations. That is an indication of the steps being taken now. It is another step forward. As I said once before, if we could only take the controversy out of Aboriginal affairs and Aboriginal education I believe the problems which exist in this area could be put aside, perhaps more readily than they can now, more readily than if we continue to deal in confrontation. I seek leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard the news item I referred to.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
Plans for an executive training course designed exclusively for Aborigines was revealed by the Chief Minister, Mr Ian Tuxworth yesterday.

The radical scheme will take people from all walks of life and train them to a level which it is hoped will make them acceptable as executives to government, private enterprise and Aboriginal organisations.
Mr Tuxworth sees the development of executive talent as an important step towards ending Aboriginal reliance on so-called white advisers.
``It's time to focus on developing Aboriginal executives,'' he said.
Plans are far from finalised, but Mr Tuxworth hopes to implement the scheme early next year.
Career path guidelines will be laid down by an Aboriginal working party.
The working party met Mr Tuxworth and Public Service Commissioner, Dr Keith Fleming, this week.
Individual
Mr Tuxworth forsees an initial intake of about 25 trainees.
Training will take from 18 months to four years depending on the individual.
It is anticipated successful applicants will enter the training scheme on a contract basis.
Educational qualifications will be no bar for acceptance to the scheme.
``They could be nursing sisters or truck drivers,'' Mr Tuxworth said.
``The sort of people we're looking for must have a desire to succeed, a will to win and the ability to do things most executives can do.''
Leadership qualities will be another sought after attribute.
Mr Tuxworth said once they gained full-time employment the executives would provide important role models for other Aborigines.
How candidates for the scheme will be selected is one of the matters still under consideration.
``We're happy to be guided by the working party on that,'' Mr Tuxworth said.
Mr Tuxworth is confident those who complete the course will find employment.
``There is a demand in the private sector for Aboriginal executives,'' he said.
Despite this, Mr Tuxworth acknowledges the Public Service will be the major employer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief tonight. I want to raise the subject of a centre for the intellectually disabled in the city of Geelong in my State of Victoria which is made up of a training centre and various residential units. I have raised the matter with the Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, who I am pleased to see is in the chamber as he is the responsible Minister. The point I raise relates to the financial difficulties that Karingal finds itself in. Of course, being the type of centre it is its residential component is financed 50 per cent by the Federal Government and the remaining 50 per cent by residential fees, fund raising activities conducted by the centre itself and so on. At the moment Karingal has a significant current deficit. This financial year it is expected that the deficit will blow out further. The Karingal committee has, I am advised, been pursuing that matter with both the Federal and State governments. The Victorian Government, which under existing arrangements does not contribute to such centres, has said that it is not a matter for it.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that about a month ago the Karingal committee decided that it would have to reduce its residential accommodation drastically at the end of February 1986 unless it could obtain some additional funding. If it is unable to do so, of course some of the residents will face the problem of not being able to remain at the centre. In the Victorian Legislative Council on 26 November last week in reply to an adjournment speech by the Victorian shadow Minister for Community Services, the Minister for Community Services, Mrs Caroline Hogg, reported that she had met with Senator Grimes last week. She reported in the adjournment debate that Senator Grimes had given an assurance that he would send an officer of his Department to Geelong to look at the matter, as well as giving this undertaking:

. . . resources would be found to alleviate the plight of Karingal and that interim provisions would be made until the proposed Commonwealth legislation is enacted next year that will take care of these situations of residence for intellectually disabled and the physically disabled residents.

That statement has been taken very seriously in Victoria, given the significant problems facing Karingal. On behalf of the residents of Karingal and the committee I would welcome a public assurance from Senator Grimes that Mrs Hogg's report in the Legislative Council is a report with which the Minister agrees in terms of its content, and that the Federal Government will be providing additional resources this financial year to meet the problems facing Karingal as promised in the discussion as reported by Mrs Hogg. Obviously it is an important and vital matter for the residents and the committee of Karingal and a very important issue for the city of Geelong and for the whole area of the intellectually disabled in Victoria. I would welcome any assurances the Minister can give.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer the matters raised by Senator Watson to Mr Hayden, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, and those raised by Senator Kilgariff to my colleague Senator Ryan, the Minister for Education. I have no particular expertise in those areas and there is no point in indulging in polemics at this time of night.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short raised a matter which he kindly mentioned to me earlier this evening, the matter of Karingal in Geelong, which is one of the residences for the intellectually handicapped which my Department assists in funding in Victoria. In fact, as Senator Short probably knows, there are, from memory, 50 such residences. None is finding life easy at the moment, because of economic difficulties in the past and the difficulties involved in organisations raising funds for this sort of project. It entered into a contract with the Federal Government that it would be funded 50 per cent by the Federal Government, and it now has, as Senator Short indicated, a significant deficit for two reasons-increasing costs and the difficulty of raising that 50 per cent which they need to contribute. I say to Senator Short-this is something he will remember from his days in the Treasury-that another problem in Victoria is that there is a separate parallel program run by the Victorian Government in which it funds 100 per cent of salaried staff, which makes life difficult for the Federal Government.

As Senator Short said, Caroline Hogg, the Minister for Community Services in Victoria, came to see me about the specific problem of Karingal, though I must say that I think it will be a problem for other such residences. I told her, as was reported tonight, that I would send a senior officer to Karingal to see what assistance we can provide. It is my understanding that that senior officer has been down there this week, but I was not able to check up on that tonight. If he or she has not, then we will find out why there has been a delay, but I understand that the intent was that a senior officer would go to Karingal this week to see what sort of assistance we can give.

I have every intention within my capacity as a Minister and within the capacities of my Department to assist Karingal or any other organisation that is in difficulties, but as Senator Short will also know, as an ex-Treasury official, my capacity is sometimes limited in this area. We have not the flexibility particularly at Federal level which sometimes the State governments have, but I feel sure that we will be able to provide assistance to Karingal-both in cash, I hope, as well as in kind in the form of advice and assistance on how that residence can be run within the budget with which it has been provided. We are faced with the difficulty that all Ministers for social security and community services are faced with at Federal or State level-namely that organisations which are providing good service and which receive assistance sometimes run into difficulties. Those organisations hope that they can get out of difficulties by appealing to the government that is assisting them to provide even more assistance. They are always assisted, as Karingal is being assisted in this case, by the local Press and by State and Federal members of parliament. That is the sort of pressure that we expect to get. I have taken note of that pressure, I have had consultations with Caroline Hogg and, as I have said, a senior official of my Department has been there and as soon as I get a report we will see how best we can assist Karingal and how best we can assist some other organisations in this situation.

All I say is that this does not mean that every organisation funded by my Department that gets into difficulty will necessarily get assistance if it can raise sufficient noise and sufficient support from local Press and members of parliament. But I think that in the case of Karingal, which to my knowledge and to the knowledge of my Department is a very worthwhile organisation and a very worthwhile community facility, it is important that we do not see that facility get into too much difficulty, whatever the cause. For that reason we are taking the matter very seriously, and for that reason I hope to be able to report to the Senate, or if the Senate is not sitting at least to the local people in Geelong, on the action we will take to make sure we can assist Karingal on a pro tem basis before any improved disability legislation comes through next year.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.02 p.m.
